Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at an Alderaan site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is forfeit +1 (and power +1 if your general is on Alderaan) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Alderaan from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Information:
Sonn in the PC Rules Questions Forum Mon Aug 28, 2006 7:19 am

Values will only ever represent the actual number on the card by saying "printed value," otherwise it is always what the value currently is. So if a starship has maneuver 4 with a +3 from an astromech and you use Darklighter Spin, it's a destiny 7.

Maneuver number means the current Maneuver value of your unique (•) starfighter in that battle.
The advantage of 'replacing' a battle destiny draw with the maneuver number is that opponent may not cancel your 'draw' (because it is no draw).

Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.

Twi'lek Advisor
We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-1)
When capturing a just forfeited character using this Dark Side Effect, that character is captured after applying forfeit value but before being placed on the Lost Pile. When captured, the character's values that would normally be restored upon leaving table (e.g., forfeit being reduced by 2, power being reduced to 0) has those values reset. In this way, cards deployed on that character (for example, Bounty or a
weapon) are not placed in the Lost Pile. Additionally, if the card was 'hit', it is no longer 'hit'. This is a specific exception to the just lost ruling.
This card merely requires that the bounty hunter be present at the location. He need not be present with the forfeited character.
Gametext: Deploy on your side of table. We Have A Prisoner and Oo-ta Goo-ta, Solo? play for free and are immune to Sense. If opponent's character is about to be forfeited, your bounty hunter present may capture that character (character is first restored to normal). (Immune to Alter.)

Lore: Independent mercenaries operating out of Anoat work with some of the locals, such as Ugnaughts. These operatives inform the Empire of all suspected Alliance activities.
Pulls: One site to Anoat
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at an Anoat site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your Ugnaught is on Anoat) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Anoat from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Gametext:
Deploy on Death Star: Trench.
During your move phase, you may make an Attack Run as follows:
Enter Trench: Move up to 3 of your starfighters into trench (for free). Dark Side may immediately follow with up to 3 TIEs (for free).
Provide Cover: Identify your lead starfighter (Proton Torpedoes* required) and wingmen (if any). Turbolaser Batteries and TIEs with weapons may now target your starfighters (wingmen first, then lead if no wingmen remaining). Hit starfighters are immediately lost.
It's Away!: Draw two destiny.
Pull Up!: All starfighters now move to Death Star system (for free). If (total destiny +X +Y -Z) > 15, Death Star is "blown away."
X = ability of lead pilot or 3 if Targeting Computer is present.
Y = total sites at largest Rebel Base (Yavin 4 or Hoth).
Z = highest ability of TIE pilots in trench.
*Your proton torpedoes are immune to Overload.

(AR 1.7.1, B-2)
This Light Side Effect remains on table and allows you to use any amount of your opponent's Dark Side Force during each of your turns. At the end of each of your turns, if you chose to use zero or 1 Dark Side Force that turn, the Beggar remains on table; if you chose to use 2 or more Dark Side Force, Beggar is lost (even if inactive). Force used by your opponent never counts against your Beggar. For example, some Jawas require the use of Force by both players when deploying. Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, F-3)
Podracing - Race Destiny And Race Total
If a podrace is not being run, treat all race totals as being an unmodifiable 0. This is a specific exception to the normal rules of undefined values. "Here" on a podracer refers to a race destiny stacked on that podracer, not any other. For example, when Dud Bolt's Podracer is lost, only the race destinies stacked on that podracer are placed in Used Pile.
-----
(AR 1.7.1, B-2)
While you are free to use your opponent's copy of this card to initiate a podrace (even if both are in play), you must specifically note this at the time you initiate the podrace. If you do not, you are assumed to be using your own copy. The winner of a podracer is determined automatically when either player has a race total > 24 at any time during any move phase.
Gametext: Deploy on Podrace Arena. Once per game, either player may initiate a Podrace: During your control phase, each player may draw one race destiny. Each player may place any drawn race destiny on their Podracer (or on Podrace Arena if they have none) or in their Used Pile. During any move phase, winner is any player with a race total > 24 and greater than opponent's highest race total. Winner retrieves 6 Force and loser loses 6 Force. Place all race destiny cards in owner's Used Piles and all Podracers are lost.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Bothawui site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is forfeit +1 (and power +1 if your Bothan is on Bothawui) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Bothawui from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: One of the most profitable occupations in the galaxy is hunting down and capturing wanted beings. The more notable the quarry, the more profitable the venture.
Information:
The real strategy with the Bounty card will come out through careful placement of sites and using docking bays to provide a means of moving the hunters and captives between systems.
To pull off the combo of both collecting a Bounty and then freezing the captive, the Dark Side player would do well to place the Cloud City: Carbonite Chamber as close to the Cloud City: Security Tower as possible.
Finally, it is pretty likely that the Cloud City: East Platform (Docking Bay) should also go in that line. That way, a turn can go like this: docking bay transit to (or better yet, land Slave I at) the East Platform. Take a Lift Tube to the Security Tower and retrieve the Bounty. Walk next door to the Carbonite Chamber with all your little Ugnaught friends and have Han ready for freezing next control phase.

Lore: BoShek nicknamed this male Siniteen 'Brainiac' due to his ability to calculate hyperspace coordinates in his head. "He's the brains, sweetheart!"
Combo:
Brainiac + Mantellian Savrip
Brainiac's forfeit is equal to the total number of cards in your opponent's hand, so he may often be sacrificed to the Mantellian Savrip to cover all battle damage and attrtion against you.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-3)
Brainiac counts as a card in hand when computing Y to determine his own deployment cost. He may provide nav computer capability on a starship as a passenger, but Brainiac is not an astromech and thus cannot occupy astromech capacity.
Imaginary numbers (which have a negative number within the square root) result in a minimum power of 1. Also, players must use the positive root (thus, the square root of 4 is 2, not -2).
Brainiac's destiny and power should not be rounded. If you're comparing this number to a certain value, examine it to see if it meets the requirements. For example, if Alter targets Luke Skywalker and Brainiac is drawn, Alter succeeds (because p is less than 4), and if All Wings Report In targets your three YWings, it also succeeds (p is greater than 3). If Brainiac is drawn for battle destiny and a player must satisfy p attrition, that player must forfeit at least p points of forfeit value (usually meaning 4 must be forfeited). However, you must round whenever you are required to do something which is impossible in partial amounts (e.g., you cannot retrieve, activate, or lose an irrational amount of Force, you cannot cause an irrational number of characters to be lost, etc.). For example, Vader initiates a duel against Luke using Vader's Obsession ("Each adds two destiny to power. Winner retrieves lost Force equal to the difference. Loser loses same amount of Force, plus the character."), and one of Luke's destinies is Brainiac. Vader's total is 14 and Luke's is 14.14159..., which means that Luke wins and retrieves Force equal to the difference (0.14159...). Because that's impossible, Light retrieves 0. Dark loses the same amount, also rounding to 0, and Vader, because even though no Force was lost or retrieved, Luke's total was still higher.
Gametext: * Power = Sqrt(3(X-Y) +2 (A-B)+pi) (minimum power=1). X = Dark Side hand cards; Y = Light Side hand cards; A = total number of (Dark Side Force icon) icons in play; B = total number of (Light Side Force icon) icons in play; pi=3.141592653589793238462643383...

Lore: Chewie's life debt to Han forced him to act, retaliating unexpectedly against his captors.
IsPulled: Corellian Retort
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-3)
When using this Light Side interrupt, the captive is temporarily placed on the Light Side of the site (even if enclosed) to participate normally in this battle. This relocation does not count as being 'released'. If you have other characters at the same site they also participate in this battle (where applicable). All normal battling conditions must be observed. For example, characters can participate in only one battle per turn and presence is required on both sides of the location. For this reason, if the captive is a droid (or the escort is a droid, for example IG- 88 With Riot Gun) and no other ability is being provided, then the battle would end immediately. If the original escorting character and the captive (who was not captured or sent missing during the battle) survive, then the captive is returned to being escorted by that character at the end of the battle.
Cancels: Force drain bonus from IT-O (Eyetee-Oh).
Gametext: USED: Cancel Force drain bonus from IT-O this turn. LOST: During your battle phase, any of your escorted captives at same site may initiate and participate in one battle (they may not use weapons or devices and you may not voluntarily forfeit or relocate them).

The same applies if Light is playing There Is Good In Him and only has Luke or You Can Either Profit By This... and only has Han.

Rules:

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Clak'dor VII site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is forfeit +1 (and power +1 if your musician is on Clak'dor VII) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Clak'dor VII from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: High-speed collisions are a constant danger during chaotic starfighter dogfights. Scanners can be jammed. Pilots rely on vision, increasing the chances of such accidents.

Gametext: Use 1 Force if opponent has at least two starships present at same system or sector. Draw destiny. If destiny < number of those starships, opponent must lose one of them.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-4)
This card allows you to exchange a card drawn for destiny with a card stacked on this effect. When this happens, any modifiers to your destiny are now transferred over to the new card, regardless of when they were played. Because this card was exchanged, it is considered to have been "just drawn" for all purposes (except, obviously, for modifiers that you have already applied to the card) and is not considered a substituted destiny (meaning it can be modified, canceled, or reset as normal).

Lore: Pilots are often reassigned at the last minute for a variety of tactical reasons. Darth Vader ordered DS-61-2 and DS-61-3 to accompany him to the Battle of Yavin.
Information:
The most obvious use is against the Rebel Leader cards. A destiny draw of 3 or higher will knock out any starfighter's permanent pilot, and Red Leader In Red 1 or Gold Leader In Gold 1 are most annoying
Unfortunately, Han, Chewie And The Falcon is immune to Come With Me.

A more subtle use is to use Come With Me on one of your own starfighters to add a better pilot aboard. For example, you could deploy the Obsidians, then use Come With Me on Obsidian 8, and replace it's permanent pilot with one of the myriad ability 2 pilots available to keep a destiny draw together.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Corellia site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is forfeit +1 (and power +1 if your Corellian is on Corellia) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Corellia from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Corporal Prescott could drain at a prison even if there is no Light Side Force icon.
Even if you cannot cause Force loss, you are not prevented from initiating a Force drain of 0. So Prescott can use his retrieving game text at the Coud City: Security Tower with Jabba's Prize imprisoned there for example.

Having a force icon at a location is not a requirement for force draining. You can force drain for zero if you like. So, in this case, you could take advantage of the character's text even without icons there.

Lore: Imperial stormtroopers use tactical training to regroup and mount a surprise counterattack, such as when they halted Han Solo's wild pursuit.
Information: Counter Assault can be one of the more powerful cards in the game, if used correctly. The ability to cancel a Force drain is terrific in any circumstance, and the added ability to nail your opponent for additional Force loss makes this card even better. However, there are several factors that make this card a risky proposition. First, there is a possibility that your opponent will match or beat your total, potentially increasing the damage. Also, the Light Side tends to have a higher destiny curve than the Dark Side does. Finally, due to the present rulings, Counter Assaulting in space is a risky proposition at best.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-4)
The total power and number of destinies to be drawn is determined immediately when this Interrupt card begins resolving, and neither changes during the resolution. Thus if a character, starship or vehicle is introduced to the location during resolution of the Assault (such as via Tauntaun Bones) it does not add power and does not permit an additional destiny draw. Similarly, if cards are removed from the location during the resolution (such as by a Program Trap), they will still contribute power and still add a destiny draw for purposes of resolving the Counter Assault. This Interrupt does not cause a battle and thus cards may not be forfeited to reduce Force loss. Remember that, at a system location, characters and vehicles aboard starships are not present at the system. Therefore, for Counter Assault there will ordinarily only be one destiny draw per starship at the system but none for any cards aboard. Counter Assault may technically be played at a holosite but, since there are no characters present (only dejariks and holograms), no destiny will be drawn and zero will be compared to the opponent's total power.

Especially if your running troopers, since two destiny draws in a second battle can account for some serious attrition, since your opponent has already lost someone from the first battle.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-5)
This card explicitly allows characters, vehicles and starships at the targeted location to battle again this turn (and since this is a battle, they may fire any applicable weapons). It does not allow any characters, vehicles or starships to 'react' a second time this turn. When determining the order of actions for this second battle, treat it as though it were the turn of the player who played this Interrupt. If a card was excluded from the previous battle, it may participate in this battle unless it is still prevented from participating (e.g., was targeted by Imperial Barrier).
Gametext: If a battle that opponent initiated just ended, initiate a new battle at same location. 'Reacts' are allowed only for opponent, but cards may not 'react' away or hide from battle. Loser ignores battle damage. If your trooper present there, add one battle destiny.

The other methods of achieving this result - Frozen Assets and Beggar - are each canceled by the Fanfare shield, so Treva is probably the best way to abuse Draw Their Fire in this way. (Psychobabble)

Lore: Corrupt Pacithhip businessmen. Report to the Empire on who makes contributions to the Alliance.
Pulls: One site to Dantooine.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Dantooine site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your thief is on Dantooine) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Dantooine from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-5)
For purposes of cards that require you to use a pilot's ability, Vader provides 6 ability, and DS-61-2 and DS-61-3 both provide 2 ability. This card utilizes persona rules as well as squadron rules. If these rules conflict, the persona rules take precedence. Thus the Death Star Assault Squadron may be taken into hand from the table for 4 Force with Hunt Down And Destroy The Jedi as that card may target any version of the *Vader persona. Death Star Assault Squadron is deploy -6 at a Star Destroyer: Launch Bay.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-6)
The reduction this Effect applies to Force retrieval is an automatic modifier, and as such applies before any other comparisons or actions are made. This means that the value of X on Secret Plans is reduced by the number of cards stacked on this Effect. Note that a retrieving card is stacked on this Effect after the retrieval is completed, and is optional (thus automatic actions may occur first, such as placing the card out of play). A card that "retrieves" a specific card by name is still retrieval, and can be reduced. For example, Baragwin says "Once per turn, if the top card of your Lost Pile is a weapon, device or transport vehicle, may use 1 Force to retrieve it." If there is at least one Interrupt or Utinni Effect stacked upon Do They Have A Code Clearance?, that will reduce the Baragwin retrieval from 1 card to no cards.

Lore: News of Imperial defeat inspires the citizens of the galaxy. A major loss seriously undermines the Empire's ability to function.
Information:
Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.
-----
Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

This is much better than the dark side version, A Day Long Remembered (V), because it doesn't hurt you if you decide you want to keep it on the table. When facing Imperial Justice (V), the immunity reduction is good because otherwise it could be problematic cracking Lord Vader's immunity < 6. Also, since you are battling you can count on making your opponent lose lots of Dark Jedi as well as lots of battles, so the additional Force loss is important. Furthermore, the card is destiny-6 and easily cycles back into your Reserve Deck for easy tracking. If you generate enough Force - and every mains deck should have solid generation - it will be an easy thing to pay the 3 Force "upkeep" cost if you should need to.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:
ADLR is #2 on my DS listing, and I have to take exception with DWTE being better than it. These cards aren't meant to stay on the table- this card is wonderful to cycle through your deck for destiny of whatnot. The upkeep is manageable, but I can't think of any time I've used this card and kept it on the table by paying for it.
-----
Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

Deploy on table. All immunity to attrition is reduced by 3. You may not fire permanent weapons. Whenever a Jedi is lost, or opponent loses a battle, opponent loses 1 Force. During your draw phase, lose 1 Force or place this card in your Used Pile. (Immune to Alter.)

Much like my #1 pick, I like the DS card a little more than the LS version. There are more Jedi that see play than Dark Jedi, and many have little immunity or none at all, which can mean guaranteed Force loss. This card is not meant to stay on the table, but cycle through your deck to show up as a big destiny draw or to deploy again for more Force loss. This works well w/ #1 as well, since you can't fire with your EPPs. The attrition reduction is a two-edged sword; so make sure you have some fodder. I can't tell you how many times it has turned a weak destiny draw into a site clearer. A great card that is fun to use along with other battle winning cards like Insignificant Rebellion.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
I agree completely with your assessment of the strengths of this card. The light side version made my list, but for dark side I just think there's far better battling helpers available. The strength of most of the powerful light side decks is EPP hit-and-run. I really only see the dark side version of this card being useful if you keep it on the table for a turn, so your opponent loses a Force from their EPP strike, or if you are going against an immunity-mains deck like Profit, which is unpopular at best, or the Careful Planning (V) Endor deck, which this card would work quite well against.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.

Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

The reason this card is on the list is because it makes light side immunity mains good again. Now instead of dropping your EPP and taking out a couple of characters, you can drop down your immunity main and take out a couple of characters and still have the immunity main around next turn to drain on the location. This also stops your opponent from messing with your destiny draw via the senate objective, which is important if you want to really cause some battle damage. Although this card appears more defensive in nature it can actually be a very powerful offensive card.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:
This ranks just outside my top 5 on both sides. CD/AAA have already conditioned you to getting more mileage out your immunity mains, this just reinforces that principle. I don't like this in the early game in case a key card gets trapped under the Effect, but mid-game onwards it is a welcome play. I think this will also give those decks that rely solely upon immunity mains (THGG, WHAP, Invasion) a little bump into playability. Remember, total battle destiny can still be affected!!
-----
This is the card old-school Star Wars CCG players have been waiting for since Reflections 3, a card that finally makes it to where your opponent can't use Boba Fett, Bounty Hunter, IG-88 With Riot Gun and 4-LOM With Concussion Rifle aboard Zuckuss In Mist Hunter to instantly end the game in a battle destiny-adding frenzy. Play this card - which you can start - and three battles per game you can limit both players to one battle destiny. Play two of this non-unique card and it's good for six battles per game, and few games have more than six battles (and not many have more than three).

So besides limiting destiny-adding fetishes, what does this card really mean for light side? For one thing, it means light side immunity mains are back. Ben Kenobi being immune < 5 used to mean nothing when he was facing multiple draws. Now immune < 5 can only be cracked by a solid destiny draw. Luke Skywalker, Jedi Knight armed with his saber is basically immune to attrition. Obi-Wan Kenobi (V) is even better.

This card also works well in space. Playing I'll Take The Leader to give your Outrider immunity < 6 is huge now. The Millenium Falcon with the same Admiral's Order out is only going down to a draw of 7 or better. Home One is basically invincible.

This card really brings SWCCG back to where it should be - when main characters are able to stay on the table for more than a turn or two, and your opponent really has to bring the beats to get rid of a big, bad main. Matching pilot starships are also a lot stronger now, and all of this is tempered by the fact that you can't play Bright Hope (V) and Tantive IV (V) and rule the sky by cancelling your opponent's only destiny draw. This is also a great card to use if you find yourself going against a destiny-cancelling team, as using this effect will prevent your destiny draw from being cancelled.

This card is going to make a lot of light side decks viable again, as they won't have to worry about the Super-Fett beatdown as much. Dont' get goldenrody though - your opponent will still be able to brign a lot of power in your direction. Below is a deck that takes advantage of the newfound respect light mains are going to get due to this card.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-6)
This Effect 'expands' game text to the adjacent sites, but it does not expand card titles, marker numbers etc. Thus, for example, it does not allow docking bay transit to or from a non-docking bay site. If Expand The Empire causes a site to have two copies of the same modifier, this does not violate the cumulative rule. For example, if a site has "Force drain +1 here" in its game text and adds another copy of the same game text ('expanded' from an adjacent site), then Force drains are +2 at that site. If game text expanded to an adjacent location contradicts the existing location game text, then the existing game text takes precedence.
Gametext: Deploy on any site. 'Expands' your "game text" for that site to add to your "game text" at the adjacent sites.

Lore: "About twenty guns. Some on the surface, some on the towers."
Information:
Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005
Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

Much ballyhooed when first released, these "offensive" Defensive Shields became a popular staple among most Shield lists. It's very easy to play since its initiation conditions are similar to another standby, Battle Order/Plan. These shields work to discourage cowardly play, like running away from battles on your turn (Watch out for Honor reducing this!) or not fighting you when they deploy to the table. Many decks have been built so that they can take full advantage of this gametext. [...]

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
Excellent choice, this was actually #6 on my list. It barely missed the cut because the second portion of the text requires that you control a site and a system to make it work, and hardcore battling decks rarely do this. The part of the card that makes the opponent lose Force can be good, but frankly if your opponent has a choice between taking a beating and losing a measley two cards (which, as you point out, is reduced by Honor Of The Jedi), they're going to lose the 2 no questions asked. In other words, those this is a card that should be played in every battling deck, it doesn't actually help your big battles happen because the opponent is still able to use their "escape" cards, they just have to lose a couple of Force to do so - which oftentimes is a fair trade.
Combo:
Firepower (V) + Ability, Ability, Ability
During opponent's deploy phase, opponent must choose to deploy a card with ability or lose 2 Force.
-----
Firepower (V) - Defensive Shield + Set Your Course For Alderaan/The Ultimate Power In The Universe
Gametext: Plays on table. If opponent moves from a location you occupy during your turn, they lose 2 Force. At end of opponent's turn, if you control two battlegrounds (a site and system) and opponent deployed a card with ability and did not initiate a battle, you may retrieve 1 Force.

Combo Card: Battle Order & First Strike.
-----
Cheap Force retrieval, and to make the best use of it, don't deploy it until right before you wish to initiate a battle. The Effect's additional ability is that during a battle you initiate, the opponent must use 1 Force before playing an interrupt. If the opponent has no Force activated, they won't be able to play any Interrupts during the battle.

It is possible to use this card in conjunction with Jawa Pack to prevent your opponent having enough force to use Houjix or another Interrupt which will save them from a big beatdown you have prepared.
However, your opponent won't always have saved up 3 force which is where you need to get sneaky.

http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=6428

General Solo (V) Interrupts (Read Note)
What complicates this is Gen. Solo's ability being a top level action and the nature of interrupts. For example, Whoooo! can be played by Han to take an N-1 starfighter into hand during a battle, but it can't be played to make Droid Starfighters power -1 because it would have to be played in response to a battle; likewise a card like The Signal has one part that can only be played at the start of the game, yet clearly is only in the deck to be used in its other aspect as a Used interrupt. So, this list is going to have to come with a big caveat emptor that the player read the card and ensure they are going to use it in a legal fashion.

Lore: "Traveling through hyperspace ain't like dustin' crops, boy!" Gravititational phenomena cast shadows in hyperspace, posing a serious threat to lightspeed navigation.
Information:
Almost always a surprise to your opponent.
You move or deploy a huge fleet to a system your opponent occupies and wait for his move phase when he tries to move all his ships away.
Unless your opponent is really savvy and moves them one at a time, you can choose which will be the target of Gravity Shadow. And even if he does move one at a time, grab one of the last ones. It's now your huge fleet vs. his one ship for a beatdown, made even better with Lateral Damage. This card can also be used to manipulate a Light Side deck whose ships are running around on you.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-7)
Gravity Shadow may target a starship whenever it attempts to move through hyperspace, even during a battle (for example, using a card such as Hit And Run or Hyper Escape). This Interrupt targets a starship and its highest-ability pilot (whether a permanent pilot or a character acting as a pilot). See Starships - Permanent Pilots, Ch. 9.
Gametext: If opponent's starship has just begun to move through hyperspace, draw destiny. If destiny > pilot's ability, starship must return to original location and may not move this turn. If destiny = pilot's ability, starship is lost.

The last line of this Jedi Test reads: "Place on apprentice. All opponent's Force drain bonuses are canceled."

(AR 1.7.1, B-8)
(Errata) Targeting a mentor, as well as targeting (or deploying) an apprentice is considered part of the initiation of this Jedi Test. Thus If a Dark Side player uses I'd Just As Soon As Kiss A Wookiee to return either the just-deployed Great Warrior (or the apprentice just deployed with Great Warrior) to hand, both cards return to the Light Side player's hand.
Gametext: *Deploy on a Dagobah site. *Target a mentor here. Also, target or deploy (regardless of location deployment restrictions) an apprentice here. *Attempt when targets are present at the beginning of your control phase. Draw training destiny. If destiny + apprentice's ability > 12, test completed: *Place on apprentice. All opponent's Force drain bonuses are canceled. Mentor: Your character of ability > 2. Apprentice: Your non-droid, non-Jedi character of lesser ability than mentor. Each time you complete any Jedi Test, you may exchange one card in hand for one Jedi Test in your Lost Pile.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-8)
See Prepared Defenses.

(AR 1.7.1, B-12)
Prepared Defenses
Effects that are "always immune to Alter" means any Effect which is unconditionally immune to Alter according to it's own game text, as these conditions must be met before such an Effect is on table. Therefore cards that are immune to Alter based on a condition in their game text (such as Come Here You Big Coward) cannot be deployed with this starting interrupt. Cards which are immune to Alter in their game text but can have that immunity canceled by other cards may be deployed using this Interrupt. For example, Prepared Defenses could still be used to deploy Mobilization Points even if Don't Do That Again was on table. When deploying Effects using this Starting Interrupt, each Effect deploys separately, and all automatic actions resolve normally. Thus if this starting interrupt is used to deploy Naboo Occupation, No Escape, and Imperial Arrest Order, Naboo Occupation may be deployed first (and will be immediately lost), followed by No Escape (which allows the dark side player to take the top card of the lost pile into hand) followed by Imperial Arrest Order.
Gametext: USED: Add 1 to your battle destiny just drawn. STARTING: Deploy up to three Effects if each of them deploys for free, is always immune to Alter and has "deploy on table" (or "deploy on your side of table") in its game text. Place Interrupt in Lost Pile.

(AR 1.7.1, B-8)

(AR 1.7.1, B-5)
Counterattack
This card explicitly allows characters, vehicles and starships at the targeted location to battle again this turn (and since this is a battle, they may fire any applicable weapons). It does not allow any characters, vehicles or starships to 'react' a second time this turn. When determining the order of actions for this second battle, treat it as though it were the turn of the player who played this Interrupt. If a card was excluded from the previous battle, it may participate in this battle unless it is still prevented from participating (e.g., was targeted by Imperial Barrier).
Gametext: If a battle that opponent initiated just ended, initiate a new battle at same location. 'Reacts' are allowed only for opponent, but cards may not 'react' away or hide from battle. Loser ignores battle damage. If your droid present there, add one battle destiny (two if C-3PO).

Lore: Sebulba is willing to utilize a variety of 'tactics' to maintain his lead position. Mars Guo learned this lesson the hard way.
Information:
Now you can use the same devious methods to win a podrace that Sebulba tried in the film. During your Control Phase, you can attempt to damage and slow down an opponent's Podracer whose race total is within 4 of your own. This means you can either try to overtake a racer who is slightly ahead of yours, or you can try to create a setback for a racer gaining on one of your own. Since race destiny is drawn during the Dark Side's Control Phase, the Dark Side player has the option of playing this card before or after race destinies are drawn, although playing Hit Racer first is wise, since you may eliminate your opponent's race destiny this turn.

If you successfully damage your opponent's racer, you get the immediate benefit of causing the Light Side to skip a race destiny. But even better than that is the added game text. Until the target racer is repaired, the Light Side will have to lose 1 Force in order to use any race destiny. This will potentially cause them to gradually fall behind your racer as they make hard decisions about what race destinies to keep.

This card is probably best used when you are within reach of winning the race. After all, since the Light Side will retrieve 6 Force for winning the race (and even more if they're playing with cards like I Did It!), he probably won't mind losing a couple of Force in order to use race destinies that will take him across the finish line first.

Of course, your opponent will need to be playing Anakin's Podracer for this to work, since Hit Racer cannot be played on a generic podracer. But with the importance that racing is likely to have in the game, it shouldn't be surprising to see Anakin's Podracer showing up in many decks.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Gametext: During your control phase, use 2 Force to target opponent's Podracer with a race total within 4 of one of your race totals. Draw destiny. If destiny > target Podracer's destiny number, opponent may not draw race destiny this turn and target Podracer is 'damaged.'

(AR 1.7.1, B-8)
This Interrupt's first function may retarget only one of the targets of an Interrupt or Utinni Effect. For example, Elis Helrot specifies two targets: a group of characters and a destination site. Thus, you may select either a different destination of the same side of the Force as the original, or a different group of Dark Side characters together at any site (which may not include any of those originally targeted), but not both. An "appropriate" target or location is one which meets the targeting or deployment requirements of the card being retargeted or relocated. The second function of this Interrupt does not relocate Utinni Effects, Mobile Effects or Immediate Effects.

Lore: "I can arrange that. You could USE a good kiss!"
Information:
These unique Lost Interrupts (I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee and its counterpart It Can Wait) can be quite annoying, and somewhat helpful despite their low destiny numbers. They play if the opponent just deployed a card (except Immediate Effect), using 3 Force to return it to the opponent's hand.
The Force they spent remains used, and on the next turn they must redeploy that card (if possible) for free using the same target(s). This is a great way to delay the opponent's strategy for a turn when they try to deploy a very powerful card. That alone can be worth stocking a destiny 2 card in your deck, as it gives you an extra turn to prepare for it. These cards are also great to use in an old-fashioned manipulation deck. Following up with a Grimtaash / Monnok (Used or Lost) or Recoil In Fear / Uncertain Is The Future can get rid of the "bounced" card for much longer than a single turn! If the bounced card was a character, Scanning Crew, M'iiyoom Onith, or Oola becomes even more effective!
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-9)
(Errata) No matter where the targeted card is being deployed from (from hand, from Reserve Deck, from Bargaining Table etc.), that card is "bounced" to its owner's hand. The card that is "bounced" has been deployed (immediately before being bounced) for any triggers or automatic actions dependent upon that event. For example, an objective may flip when the character is deployed if dependent upon controlling or occupy. Similarly, if Daughter of Skywalker is being deployed from Reserve Deck (using Mind What You Have Learned), Leia will be targeted by that objective for remainder of game, even if subsequently "bounced". See Simultaneous Deployment, Ch. 5.

Protector
Who's Scruffy-Looking?
CardName: I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee
Gametext: Use 3 Force to place an opponent's just deployed character, starship, vehicle, weapon, or device in opponent's hand. On opponent's next turn, that card (or one card of same title) may deploy for free.

Information:
Try this: start Hidden Base, Squadron Assignments, Insurrection and one other (I'd go Battle Plan, Menace Fades or something defense myself). What you now have is a fairly basic Hidden Base deck, drain at the systems and the lots - of - generic - docking-bays. Your pilots get beefed (insurrection) and they match their ships.

Now drop down I'll Take The Leader and watch what happens - your ships are all immune to attrition < 6 (they match), you drain for two on the ground and all your ships regenerate. Plus your opponents 'no-brainer' counters (e.g. Dreadnaught, Bossk etc...) all get the shaft.

They key to this is that the deck doesn't *rely* on the AO (which can be over-ridden), it just moves up a gear into a deadlyier version of itself. This is how the Admirals Orders are best used. Try it, you'll be pleasently surprised.
IsPulled: Admiral Ackbar
Gametext: Unique (•) starfighters without permanent pilots are immune to attrition < 4 (or add 2 to immunity if starfighter already has immunity). Starships without pilot characters aboard are power -2. At docking bays related to systems you occupy, your Force drains are +1. Once per turn, your starfighter just lost from a system may be relocated to a related docking bay.

Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005
Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

It's a destiny-6 card that can be pulled from your deck using Masterful Move, and can reduce Force drain damage with the only stipulation being that it must be a planet site (so no Cloud City locations). There's really no easier way to reduce damage, as it requires no commitment from the Dark Side player other than that they commit a card slot to a destiny-6 Effect. If Vader's hanging around an adjacent site, this card will obviously become even more powerful. Simple Effect that can make a huge difference in a game.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:

Wow, talk about an obvious miss on my part- great idea for a damage controller. The LS version (Projection of a Skywalker) was played quite a bit for similar reasons. The one thing that I don't like about this card is its fixed location. If you temper a drain at a planet where there are multiple sites, your opponent can always move around it. It works best at key drain locations where the enhancers (unlike lightsabers) are fixed as well.

Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), but harder to use due to the fact that you can only play with Imperials if you use this card. In addition to offering some solid character retrieval, this card also does a decent job of causing your opponent to spread out quickly so that they can suspend the gametext of this card. The battle destiny limiting may seem like a bad idea for a battling deck, but in reality there aren't a lot of ways for all-Imperial decks to get multiple battle destiny anyway, and this way you can use characters like Lord Vader and have the immunity to attrition be worth more than if you had to worry about your opponent drawing 5 battle destiny and basically making your immunity worthless. Another reason this is a solid battling card is because if you draw battle or weapon destiny and accidentally flip a character, you can take it into hand and try again, allowing you to play with more characters than you would normally be able to get away with while still maintaining the integrity of the deck's destiny.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:
Wow, great minds think alike. This is my #5 as well. I really like the versatility that this card brings to an Imperial deck and think that as stronger Imperials are created this card will see more and more play.
Armaedes made a bunch of good points about this card above, but there were a few things I also wanted to add. First, two copies of this can be played for maximum use, which means twice as many benefits heading your way. It may be overkill in many instances, but if it is worth it, you'll never go without characters ever again. Secondly, there are some creative ways for you to use it as a cycling machine. DDM had an interesting Hunt Down that used a lone Womp Rat to constantly draw against Vader so that he could draw needed Imperials into hand. I also don't think that limited destiny draws as a bad thing- with you constantly weeding out low destiny characters your 2 destinies should be stronger than your opponent's. This is also yet another great battle winning effect that works with many of the other cards on this list.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
No argument here, and the two-copies thing is an important point I forgot to mention. I have seen this card used effectively in Hunt Down, BHBM, ISB, Ralltiir, and even some Combat Readiness (V) decks. Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's good because it rewards you for battling by giving you more characters to battle with. Unlike Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's far more deck-specific, but getting back characters is always a good thing.

Information:
Giving the Dark Side two Force icons for Force generation, and one Force icon for Force draining, this location may look average at first glance. However, if you consider the "Dejarik Rules" for a moment, you will see the true power of this location.

Only dejarik and hologram cards can exist at a holosite. Since there are so few of them in the Star Wars CCG card set, you're pretty safe from being battled at the Imperial Holotable.

Holosites allow dejariks and holograms to deploy and battle there as if they were characters. However, they are not characters and are not targetable as characters, interrupts or effects . . . they are dejariks and holograms! So you're completely safe from cards like Surprise Assault.

When you deploy a dejarik or hologram card to a holosite, use its destiny number as its deploy, forfeit, power and ability numbers. Battles at holosites are similar to battles at other sites (including destiny draws and attrition if you have 4 or more ability present). So Visage Of The Emperor (destiny = power = ability = 7) and Image Of The Dark Lord (destiny = power = ability = 6) are extremely powerful holograms to be reckoned with at the Imperial Holotable - the Light Side doesn't have any dejariks or holograms that can compete with these cards on a one-to-one basis!

I like to start with the Imperial Holotable, and pack two Visage Of The Emperor, two Image Of The Dark Lord, and two Monnok cards in my deck. This number of dejariks and holograms assures me a card that I can deploy to the Imperial Holotable on my first couple of turns, and gives me a nice, steady (and safe!) Force drain throughout the game.

Idea Behind Objective: A very stupid idea. At first, the original strategy was to play a deck with 25 of your planet's Operative because they were broken on their planet. Basically it worked like this; your objective pulled the sites, then once you controlled three, you flipped. The flip side made all lightside drains -1, your operatives added +1 to force drains, deployed for one, forfeit for like 4 or 5, added a destiny at all sites while you had just one operative on the planet, and you retrieved a force every time you simply deployed one to a site. They were even power +2 against a Rebel. This was totally not a Star Wars movie idea, just crap that hurt the game.

SPECIAL NOTE: Because of all the problems this objective caused. Decipher created three cards that completely hurt this deck as well as an errata to the rules saying that only one operative may be at a site, anymore would be lost. This objective is considered to be DEAD. Decipher created this idea with no thought of what they were doing. This objective is one that they wish they had never made. It won the '98 worlds for both sides because it was a broken idea.

What Changed Since 1st Edition: Nothing, the objective still stinks. You play it, you are doing it as a surprise factor only. The only reason you should win with this objective is against someone who isn't playing with the counter cards or who doesn't know how it works. STAY AWAY!!!
Rules: This objective may not start a ♢ site that may not deploy to a Renegade planet.

Lore: "Obi-Wan has taught you well."
Information:
Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

Last on the list because of how specific it is, but still a solid battling helper due to its ability to cancel just about every battle evasion method dark side can come up with. The trick is that it has to be targeting a Jedi, but frankly most light battling decks are going to be heavy on the Jedi anyway (Mace Windu (V), Qui-Gon Jinn, Obi-Wan Kenobi and possible a Jedi persona of Luke Skywalker). Cancelling battle evasion is obviously a very good thing for a battling deck, but the card doesn't stop there. If your main should survive the battle and are still at the site, and the dark player retaliates, you can use this card to take the first action of the weapons phase, which means you can strike out at one of your opponent's characters before they have a chance to do any tricks with Dr. Evazan or Dark Strike.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:
#5?? Aw, man it's my #1. I don't want to steal my own thunder- so read on. I think this was a very good card to come out of the player designed card experiment.
When you deploy to battle in modern SWCCG, the biggest thing you fear is the re-beat, where your opponent minimizes your offensive power, reinforces on their turn, and then beats you down. Evasion and character removal are two prime ways to slow down a feisty LS player. IMI takes care of it all. I don't think its specificity is a hindrance at all. Barrier will often be saved for your big guns (Jedi). Most battles involve Jedi (Stunning), and YAB will target those aforementioned big guns. Being able to battle on your own terms is very nice. The secondary text is quite nice as well, as Armaedes pointed out. Though protective in nature, it can turn a defensive battle into an offensive one quickly.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
I agree that this is a great card, but #1? This is a very deck-specific card, as it won't work in a battling deck that isn't mains, and even in a mains deck it won't help you with EPP Luke. A very nice card no doubt, as it made my own list, but not an auto-play by any means.

(AR 1.7.1, B-9)
The game text "may forfeit one of its weapons" means that a character, starship or vehicle may only forfeit a weapon deployed on that character, starship or vehicle. Thus a character cannot use this Effect to forfeit an artillery weapon at the same location, a starship cannot forfeit an Orbital Mine at the same system and so on. The game text that allows your forfeited weapons go to your Used Pile applies to any weapon you forfeit (including artillery weapons that already have a forfeit value).

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, F-1, Appendix A)
-----
Changes to "Characteristics" re: "(LS) Intruder Missile"

Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider:

http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16525

Changes to "Characteristics" and application to "(LS) Intruder Missile":

In an ideal world we'd have no characteristics rules and lists and instead just list all aspects of a card, on the card. Since that would require a revision to thousands of cards, that's simply not practical. Every effort has been made to identify and discern what are and are not characteristics. Some may be missing from the list, while others are deliberately absent. Discerning which is which requires a bit of research and judgment.

After investigating, we're adding skiff and sandcrawler to the list of characteristics which apply to vehicles.

This brings us to the matter of (LS) Intruder Missile. This weapon and its possible interaction with Outrider has been a matter the PC has been considering for some time. By the rules, the one could not deploy on the other, but we were not ignorant of the possibility that this was an error of omission. Having looked through the evidence, we're now confident that Intruder Missile was not intended to work with Outrider.

We do not make these decisions lightly, and attempt to be thorough in our research of the original intent of the card interactions. We searched the records of play testing that we have from the development of Shadows of the Empire (the set that was incorporated into Reflections 2). In an original version of the Outrider, it was created to work with Intruder Missile, both via game text and the inclusion of the "YT-2400" in the subtype box. However, the game text was stricken over the course of play testing, and the "YT-2400" text moved out of the subtype box into the lore. This move was significant - the characteristic rules were well in place at this time, and Decipher had ensured that references to starships were almost entirely to icons or the contents of the subtype box. The only exceptions to this were defined characteristics (all ships are enclosed and all TIE/sa and B-wings are bombers) or squadron designations (which could be found in title, lore, or game text). Decipher, in fact, released only one card which was referenced by its lore instead of subtype: Blockade Flagship, because "Droid Control Ship" would not fit in that box - and Decipher then made a note to declare Droid Control Ship a characteristic.

Neither of these cases applied to Outrider - our tests using the original templates showed that "YT-2400" would fit with room to spare, and we know that Decipher made no such announcement. In addition, the text on Intruder Missile states that it also may deploy on the Falcon. It was not until two years after Intruder Missile came out that a Falcon was created that didn't state "YT-1300" in lore (both the original and Lando in Millennium Falcon did). If Decipher intended to reference it in lore, this specific mention wouldn't have been necessary.

Given the state of the characteristic rules at the time by Decipher, the striking of the game text, and the deliberate choice to remove a referenced card aspect from the subtype box, we feel this is sufficient evidence to support the existing ruling: Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider.

Because this matter has confused many players over the years, we are going to issue the following errata to Intruder Missile (LS) in the hopes of minimizing further confusion:

LS Intruder Missile:
Deploy on your B-wing, Z-95, YT-1300 Transport, or Falcon. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.
Gametext: Deploy on your B-wing, Z-95, YT-1300 Transport or Falcon. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.

Information: Combo Card: Ommni Box & It's Worse
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-9)
When this Interrupt increases your opponent's Force loss, this is simply a modifier; it does not create a new, separate instance of Force loss. It Could Be Worse is played during the result step of a Force loss action, and therefore the chance for optional responses to that Force loss action has already passed. For example: the Dark Side player Force drains for 2. The Light Side player has no response to the Force drain (neither does the Dark Side player) and the Force drain now has its result. The Light Side player now plays It Could Be Worse and uses 2 Force. The Dark Side player responds to It Could Be Worse by playing It's Worse and using 5 Force. Neither player has any responses to the It's Worse (the Light Side player doesn't have his Sense in hand) and thus it has its result. The Force drain loss is now 7 Force and Light Side cannot play his Control because the optional response step to the Force drain is already over.
Cancels: It Could Be Worse

Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

If the power of Scum could be placed at the feet of one character, it would be this one, which is ironic since Jabba doesn't even really have feet. Jabba The Hutt (V) is very deck-specific, which is why he's not higher on my list, but in an alien deck he can end games on the 2nd or 3rd turn. I have personally had Jabba The Hutt (V) cause more than 50 overflow in games, and I know other players who have got that number even higher. With the number of ways dark side has to pull aliens from the deck, and with Jabba (V) doubling the power of almost all of them, you can create devastating beatdowns in record time. The best part is that the Audience Chamber deploys him from Reserve Deck and then Elis Helrot takes him wherever the fighting is. Truly a brutal battling card.

SHEWSKI'S TAKE:
Well, I might take exception on the power of Scum being focused on him, but you are right that he is a potent card. I mean, winning a battle by 20 and winning it by 40 both hurt your opponent, but both are likely game winners. I didn't rank him on my list since I don't really like what he brings to the world of SWCCG. I think there were plenty of other cool Jabbas that Scum decks could run, plus I have trouble envisioning Jabba being a flying beatdown machine.

Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

One of my pet peeves, briefly touched upon under #1, is character removal. The Dark Side is rife with popular ways to get rid of your heroes such as Dr. Evazan, Dark Strike, and Choke Vader. K'lor Slug (and Molator for the DS) helps you avoid painful beatdowns due to sudden losses of power and destiny draws. While this is more like IMI in that it helps your battles hold their effectiveness, the second part of the text goes very well with immunity mains. Your mains can get out at their normal cost, which greatly speeds up the time it takes to get them into play by a turn or more.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
Again, I find this less of an offensive aid than a defensive aid, and more of a battle-hindering card than anything else. The dark side's character removal is a big way dark wins battles, so in my opinion taking this away makes effective battling more challenging. I really like this card - I think it is a necessary component of the game - but I'm not sure I would classify it as a battling aid.

Lore: Hunters who track down escaped Wookiee slaves and report on their location. The Empire and Trandoshans pay a high price for that kind of information.
Pulls: One site to Kashyyyk.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Kashyyyk site, adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your Trandoshan is on Kashyyyk) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Kashyyyk from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-10)
While this system's game text "doubles" a character, it means that:
- Every printed number on that card is doubled (thus a 1 becomes a 2, a 2 becomes a 4, etc.)
- Every printed indication of number of uses is doubled (thus "once" becomes "twice," "twice" becomes "four times" etc.). Lore: Couriers. Watchful for any kind of activity by the Alliance or the Empire. Sell their information to anyone willing to buy.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Kiffex site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your spy is on Kiffex) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Kiffex from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: Special modification for starfighters. Size may vary depending on mass of starship. Allows a stable connection to a spacedock, uneven terrain or even another starship.
Information:
This device permits you to create an "Undercover" starfighter. You block your opponent's Force drain without risking loosing Force in a battle.

Of course, since you can only have two on the table at a time, you will still have to deploy other ships and attack, but now you have an ace in the hole. Not only do the ships present at the system engage the Imperial fleet, but your concealed starfighter "May detach at any time", thus increasing your power and ability total to give your opponent a run for his money.
IsPulled:
Corporal Beezer
Portable Scanner
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-10)
This device allows your starfighter to attach itself to an opponent's capital starship. To indicate that your starfighter is attached, place it across the table on the targeted capital starship card. While 'concealed':
- Starship is inactive, thus all cards aboard it are inactive (except for cards that indicate they still function, such as Homing Beacon and Landing Claw itself).
- Your opponent may not Force drain at same location. When you 'detach,' the starfighter returns to normal. While attached, if the capital starship is lost, the attached starfighter is also lost. A starfighter attached to a starship that lands is still considered attached. If detached (or if the Landing Claw is canceled) the starfighter becomes landed at that location (if this is not possible, then starfighter is lost).

(Appendix B)
While attached, if the capital starship is lost, the attached starfighter is also lost. The capital starship is considered to be 'carrying' the attached starfighter, so if the capital starship moves away, and the attached starfighter comes along for the ride, that starfighter is being 'carried,' not moving on its own. See Movement - carrying cards.

Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

Leia is a revolutionary card. She is a very cheap destiny draw that allows for an early disruption of the Dark Side's setup. Though envisioned as an anti-Senate card, she has many other strong uses. Most used is probably her leader canceling game text, which can set up some beats of her own. She can take the teeth out of Jabba, Xizor, P-59, Fel, Igar, Ephant Mon, Veers, Thrawn, and Tarkin. This text always works as well. Typically, such a powerful card wouldn't be so cheap, but she has been an early thorn in my opponent's side for some time now. Usually my choice for a utility Leia, but Princess Leia (V) deserves consideration as well.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
YES! Leia (V) is a fantastic battling card. Not only does she have strong gametext for battling herself, but she also takes a bite out of senate, which is a deck that makes effective battling by the light side more challenging. I would even put this Leia above EPP Leia for battling effectiveness. Great pick by Shewski!

Information:
This Rebel sharpshooter must have been born with a rifle in his hand. When using any weapon, not only is he +1 to weapon destiny, but if he makes it the target suffers not only the weapon hit effects, but is forfeit - 3 also. If that character is forfeit 3 or less, that's as good as a forfeit = 0 weapon, normally the realm of main characters only!

Hand him an A280 Sharpshooter Rifle and he gets even nastier. In the ideal circumstance, Greeve and his A280 are safely tucked away alone at an adjacent site to where the battle broke out. You have a pile of force. Thus you may fire repeatedly first shot free, subsequent shots at 2 Force, At the same target at +3 to your weapon destiny draw, and the hit characters are forfeit - 3. If you are drawing a few EPP enhanced battle destinies in that battle, the battle damage potential for Dark Side could be huge.

Lore: Colonel Dyer's aide. Coordinates scout actions. As a youth, raced swoops on homeworld of Corellia. Formerly served with Emperor's Demonstration Team.
Information:
Some have argued that this Imperials last name has been misspelt. Take out the the "r" and the "n" and your closer to his true capabilities in an Endor Booster Draft.

For one, he's a scout. Thus Pitiful Little Band can be used with him. He's power 2 and ability 2 for only 2 Force, and with Imperial Arrest Order on table he's forfeit 5!

But there's more! He can drive a Speeder Bike, as well as fly a starship. This makes him *invaluable* in a Booster Draft with your Lambda Class Shuttles. And then there's +2 attrition for your Biker Scout / Trooper pairs.

Lore: Former warrant officer from Concord Dawn. Promoted due to superb performance. Specializes in transporting high-profile criminals. Twin brother of a famous mercenary.
Information:
You've captured a group of Rebels and are escorting them to the Cloud City: Security Tower to do mean and nasty things to them. (OK, most of those things involve Force losses and torture with creepy devices, but still, that's pretty mean!) Heading down the Cloud City: Upper Plaza Corridor you're just about there, when suddenly the Light Side sets up an ambush. Things are looking bad as the Light Side wins a spectacular battle, but they overlooked one thing. You've got Lieutenant Sheckil. You play the interrupt Human Shield using its lost game text. Now any captive present may be forfeited to meet the attrition and battle loss. Lieutenant Sheckil adds 2 to any captive he is escorting, so you can easily meet the battle loss and attrition. Guess it wasn't such a good idea to attack!

Lieutenant Sheckil is an expert at escorting captives. He's also an expert at protecting the Dark Side from harm by using captives as shields. During your control phase, you may use 1 Force to take one Human Shield into hand from the Reserve Deck. Sheckil also adds 2 to the forfeit value of any captive he escorts. To take full advantage of him, you absolutely need the card Human Shield. This card in a Used form allows you to use captives as target fodder for your opponent's weapons. As a Lost Interrupt, you can use those captives he's escorting to meet battle damage and attrition, thus saving your own forces.
Pulls: Human Shield
IsPulled: Blizzard 4
Combo: Lieutenant Sheckil + Human Shield + Binders
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, A-11)
The name "Sumner" in this card's game text is a misprint and should read "Sheckil".
Gametext: During your control phase, may use 1 Force to search your Reserve Deck, take one Human Shield into hand and reshuffle. When escorting a captive, captive is forfeit +2 and Sheckil is immune to attrition < 4.

Lore: Pilot of the Radiant VII. Was personally requested by Captain Madakor to assist in the transportation of the Jedi ambassadors.
Information:
Have you ever looked at Zuckuss In Mist Hunter and wanted to sic that same torture on the Dark Side, just to see how they'd feel? Well, here's your chance! Lieutenant Williams on the Radiant VII gives you a very similar ability: if your opponent has total ability less than seven piloting at Williams's system, his total battle destiny is -3. Not quite as good as Zuckuss, but then again, Zuckuss doesn't have 7 power and immunity to attrition < 5.

Since Williams's ability only works while the Radiant VII is alone at a system, you'll want to supplement him with two other pilots to maximize the Radiant's power in space. But even if you don't find yourself in the need for space support, Williams works well as forfeit fodder on the ground, with reasonable stats to supplement your main characters in their quest for ground-poundin' dominance. And, since he's a Republic character, he's immune to annoying things like Scanning Crew.
Combo: Lieutenant Williams + Captain Madakor + Radiant VII

Radiant VII

Lore: Vader had to show Luke that giving in to the dark side of the Force was his only destiny.
Information:
The Lost game text on this Used or Lost Interrupt is, well, a little lost on us for the moment. A dueling version of Projective Telepathy, this card makes the Light Side choose to either lose 4 Force or cancel a duel they just initiated. At the moment, there are only two ways for the Light Side to initiate a duel. The first is through Jedi Test #6, a strategy not seen very often. The second (and more likely to be seen) is the Interrupt from Tatooine, You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises, which gives Luke some dueling ability. Lightsaber Parry will be useful against this card, as well as any future duel-initiating ability the Light Side might gain in the future.

Lightsaber Parry also provides some interesting Used game text. If the Dark Side has a lightsaber in a just-initiated battle, this card will eliminate the ability of all lightsabers present to target characters. At first glance, this might seem a little silly. After all, while the Light Side won't be slicing and dicing, the Dark Side can't use their lightsabers, either. But there is a method to the madness. The Light Side still outnumbers the Dark in number of characters who can use the various unique lightsabers. In addition, the Light Side has a little more versatility, with Anakin's Lightsaber being usable by either Luke or Leia. These facts add up to a decent chance that the Light Side will have more lightsabers in a battle than the Dark Side. Now, sacrificing Darth Maul's chance to hit an opponent is more than offset by the fact that you have saved several of your characters from the blade.

This text can also be useful when you have an important character with a low defense value in the battle. Characters with 1, 2, or even 3 ability are almost sure to be hit by a lightsaber. Now your Dark Jedi can keep that character alive and kicking for at least another turn. And since this part of Lightsaber Parry is a Used Interrupt, your Dark Jedi will be able to come to the rescue again, and again, and again...
Cancels: A duel.
Gametext: USED: If a battle was just initiated where you have a character armed with a lightsaber, characters may not be targeted by lightsabers for remainder of battle. LOST: If opponent just initiated a duel, opponent must choose to lose 4 Force or cancel the duel.

Information: While Trooper Davin Felth is on Tatooine Local Trouble is a Used Interrupt.
Rules:
Local Trouble Battle
A Local Trouble battle is one where a battle has been initiated by a card titled Local Trouble. During a Local Trouble battle, any other characters, vehicles, or starships at the site that are not participating in the Local Trouble battle are inactive for the duration of the battle, with two specific exceptions:
*If a character participating in a Local Trouble battle is on an open vehicle, that vehicle is not inactive.
*Cards that become inactive because of a Local Trouble battle are considered to be on table for the purposes of objectives.
Remember that these cards are inactive by rule, they are not considered excluded for any game-related purpose.
