Information:
Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck
http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2

Idea Behind Objective: A very stupid idea by Decipher. At first, the idea was to play a deck with 25 of your planet's operatives because they were broke on their planet. Basic it worked like this. Your objective pulled the sites, then once you controlled three, you flipped. The flip side made all DS drains -1, your operatives added +1 to force drains, deployed for one, forfeit for like 4 or 5, added a destiny at all sites while you had just one operative on the planet, and you retrieved a force every time you simply deployed one to a site. They were even power +2 against an Imperial. This was totally not a Star Wars movie idea, just crap that hurt the game. The reason this objective was even made was because Lucas denied the creation for some of the card designs only weeks before the release of Special Edition. To fix this last minute problem, the Operative strategy was added without ANY play testing.

SPECIAL NOTE: Because of all the problems this objective caused. Decipher created three cards that completely hurt this deck as well as an errata to the rules saying that only one operative may be at a site, anymore would be lost. They also no longer have presence, so they can't control a site by themselves. This objective is considered to be DEAD. Decipher created this idea with no thought of what they were doing. This objective is one that we all wish they had never made. It won the '98 worlds for both sides because it was a broken idea.
Rules: This objective may not start a ♢ site that may not deploy to a Subjugated planet.

Lore: Good-willed Mon Calamari merchant. Looking for work. Unfortunately, everywhere he goes he comes up empty handed.
Information:
Mon Calamari are:

Admiral Ackbar
Admiral Ackbar (V)
Captain Verrack
First Officer Thaneespi
Loci Rosen
Major Haash'n
-----
This Mon Calamari has the potential to have enormous power. He does have a drawback of allowing your opponent to recycle cards, but he will really make your opponent think how many cards he really needs in hand. After all, one more card in his hand could mean one more battle damage coming his way.

But the key to using him effectively is to get him into battle when your opponent doesn't see it coming. If you deploy him to a probable battle location, you can be sure his power will be taken down a notch before the battle. You will want to use cards that let him get to a battle without you deploying him to the battle location on your turn. For example, on Cloud City you can use Path of Least Resistance to get him where he's needed, or in Jabba's Palace you could use You Will Take Me to Jabba Now.
IsPulled: Admiral Ackbar
Gametext: Power +X in a battle at a site, where X equals the number of cards in opponent's hand. During your deploy phase, opponent may place any number of cards in their hand in their Used Pile.

Lore: "Wha-? Chuba da noya!"
Information:
You've always had the chance to stack your own destiny draws, but now you have the chance to stack your opponent's as well. If there's going to be a crucial destiny draw in a battle (and what battle doesn't?), you can stack a low destiny on top of your opponent's deck. You are retrieving a Force for your opponent, but he won't be thanking you when Admiral Ozzel is flipped for battle destiny.

The lost portion can also be useful in a podracing deck. You can repair your Podracer so you don't need to lose Force to keep the race going, or you can take a shot at damaging your opponent's Podracer to make him pay the price to stay in the race.
IsPulled: We Wish To Board At Once
Gametext: USED: During battle, place top card of opponent's Lost Pile on top of their Reserve Deck. LOST: Use 1 Force to 'repair' your Podracer. OR Target a Podracer. Draw destiny. If destiny > Podracer's destiny number, target is 'damaged.'

Lore: Primary Neimoidian senator who represents the Trade Federation in the Galactic Senate. Thwarted attempts by Amidala to end the blockade of Naboo.
Information:
Lott Dod works his magic in a variety of places. With his ambition agenda, he gets an extra bonus when drawn for destiny if you have flipped My Lord, Is That Legal? Since he has a trade agenda, if he's on This is Outrageous!, you can use him to 'trade' unneeded cards in hand for a shot at a needed card from your Lost Pile. His blockade agenda is also useful, even if he's not at the Senate. When on Our Blockade is Perfectly Legal, he helps you 'blockade' your opponent by hindering your opponent's out of phase movement.

But he also helps you when he's on the table, imagine that! With his blockade agenda, he lets you flip My Lord, Is That Legal? with one less senator. But perhaps more importantly, if you have political control of the Galactic Senate, he gives you access to an incredibly powerful ability. Letting you look through your Force Pile allows you to take a key card into hand; it could be a critical character you need to battle, a matching weapon for your Darth Maul, or any other card, it can all be yours, if you have a Senate majority. And in a pinch he helps his fellow Neimoidians out by adding to their forfeit.
Pulls: Any card from Force Pile

The Phantom Menace

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-11)
Luke's Backpack permits a character to carry another character around. This means that whenever the character wearing the backpack moves, the character in the backpack automatically moves with him or her per the carry cards rules (see Movement - Carrying Cards, Ch. 7). The character in the backpack is not enclosed within it and will still occupy capacity slots on vehicles and starships. Whenever either character is targeted by an action that will make them inactive (e.g., being captured, missing) the other will also suffer the same fate. When that happens, the character in the backpack automatically disembarks.
Gametext: Deploy on your character. May carry and use any number of devices. May also carry Yoda, Kabe or any one Jawa or Ewok (as if riding a creature vehicle). Adds 1 to training destiny when carrying the mentor.

Lore: Merr-Sonn Model 57. Part of an arms lot purchased for the Alliance from a black market dealer on Ord Mantell. Carried by Luke as backup for his father's lightsaber.
Information:
This weapon works well in a deck that relies on personal weapons to give bonuses. While Luke carries this weapon, Princess Leia is free to use Anakin's Lightsaber. The advantage of this card is that it does not even need to hit a character to have some nice bonuses, just target them.

The deploy cost can be a little high when compared with the personal sabers, but the advantage is that Luke's pistol will work a little more consistently in having its most powerful effect then the sabers will when facing high ability characters. Additionally, with a number of four destiny cards in the deck, pretty much everyone is vulnerable to this except Vader, Fett and IG-88.

Rebels and Aliens mix and match all the time in a Light deck (look at Han and Chewbacca! ), thus by playing this recyclable five destiny card to have a good chance of reducing attrition against you in a battle to zero sounds pretty good to me! And if Han shows up, you have even a better chance of avoiding battle damage in that battle!

Lore: Contains wrist lasers, rocket dart launchers, a flame projector, a projectable grappling hook, a concussion grenade launcher, four kinds of sensors and a broad band antenna.
Information:
It's a dangerous universe, and your characters need all the protection they can get. Blasters, Bowcasters even Lightsabers are constant hazards. What's the best way to protect them? Put them in a set of Armor. That's where Mandalorian Armor comes in.
In a word, Wow! This one device gives your valuable character the characteristics of everyone's favorite bounty hunter. Give your opponent something else to target with that armor of 5. Immunity to attrition is always a bonus, not to mention the power +2. Imagine Grand Moff Tarkin protected by armor 5, canceling battle destiny with his buddy Vader. Tarkin will no longer be Lightsaber bait! How about everyone's favorite Jawa, Dathcha, running around at power 4 with immunity to attrition of less than 3. Or, if you're into raw power, how about throwing Kitik Keed'kak into Mandalorian Armor. Power 10, immunity to attrition of less than 3 and armor to protect that ability of 1!
IsPulled: Any Methods Necessary (V)
Gametext: Use 3 Force to deploy on any alien or Imperial (except Vader or Boba Fett). Character is power +2, has armor = 5 and is immune to attrition < 3.

Lore: Most space-faring adventurers meet their fate with a calm, quiet dignity.
Information: This a rather bland card that may find a use against the many bounty hunter decks running around. If people continue to play with their favorite character, Boba Fett, we may see a use for the first part of this destiny 5, Used Interrupt. It allows you to draw destiny and to subtract that number from the opponents power and attrition total if Fett is defending in the battle. The second function simply cancels Jet Pack's game text or any weapon that fires repeatedly. Neither of these are used very often and despite the high destiny on the card, it will probably be too specific to see much time in the field.

Information:
There is no dark counterpart, but Sacrifice has similar text.
-----
One of the most useful Effects in the game for the Light Side. With Mantellian Savrip on table, you need not lose characters from the site/system, but satisfy that damage by losing a character or starship from hand.
One major problem is that most Dark Side players run a copy of Masterful Move in their decks.
-----
Hindsight deployed on C-3PO makes Mantellian Savrip immune to Alter.

Mantellian Savrip + BG-J38
Adds 2 to the destiny of each of your holograms and dejariks drawn for battle destiny or weapon destiny.
-----
Mantellian Savrip + Brainiac
Brainiac's forfeit is equal to the total number of cards in your opponent's hand, so he often may be sacrificed to the Mantellian Savrip to cover all battle damage and attrtion against you.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-11)
This Effect allows you to forfeit cards that have a forfeit value directly from your hand during the damage segment of a battle you have lost. This is treated the same as normal forfeiture, satisfying battle damage and/or attrition (simultaneously if both need to be satisfied). Cards forfeited from hand with Mantellian Savrip must be placed in the Lost Pile regardless of any other game text. For example, a character may not be forfeited from hand to the Bacta Tank, and the Star Cruiser Liberty may not be forfeited from hand to the Used Pile.

-----
Qui-Gon has the usual high stats you would expect from a Jedi Master who still actively serves the Old Republic. He's able to "teleport" by returning to your hand and then be available to be deployed elsewhere the next turn (or even deploy a different version of him instead). Using 4 Force is expensive but it can not be canceled by Sense or blocked by anything else normally.

The other good part about Qui-Gon is that he is immune to You Are Beaten, ensuring that he can not be excluded from a battle that way. You can count on him to be there to protect other characters with him, just like the true guardian he is.

It can set up the holotable rather quickly, but what's best is that it allows you to grab important cards such as Visage Of The Emperor, Monnok, Ghhhk, HoloNet Transmission, etc. when you need them. After doing this, the destiny 6 interrupt goes back into your deck!
The most important use of this card is that it cancels Mantellian Savrip, an Effect which severely hampers the Dark Side's ability to inflict battle damage effectively.

Lore: A Sith needs no introduction.
Information:
The biggest complaint about Darth Maul from Tatooine was that his support cards were a bit weak when compared to Darth Vader or Ben Kenobi. Some things just take time, and Maul can happily take a big step up the main character chain with Maul Strikes.

The three uses this card has are all extremely powerful. When you draw this card, one of its uses will almost certainly be needed immediately. Light Side players have been able to pull Lightsabers out of their decks for years with Gift Of The Mentor, and now Maul Strikes allows the Dark Side to finally have their turn at this great ability.

Another minor weakness of the Tatooine persona of Darth Maul was that his ability to duel was a bit restricted, since he had to essentially survive an entire turn before he had the chance to duel anybody. With Maul Strikes, however, the Sith Lord can bypass that restriction, and duel at any time by simply playing this interrupt.

And finally, if you're looking for just some good old beatdown, Maul can add battle destiny with this card too. Instead of just dueling Qui-Gon and making him lost, why not battle him, cut him, and draw three battle destiny as well? The answer is simple.

Lore: Advanced optics used by Darth Maul to help track Queen Amidala. Image enhancement features allow for better sensor readings.
Information:
They only deploy on Maul, but he should be in your deck anyway, right? And while the actual mechanic of fixing destiny is a bit different when compared to the Light Side, the raw power of it is still there.
While Maul's Electrobinoculars will eat up your Force Pile fast, the Dark Side also has an infinite number of situations where fixing up a destiny would be desirable, i.e., before a duel, or before drawing race/battle/weapon destiny.
You can also get to that one crucial card in your Force Pile without junking up your hand. Pay a Force to look, if it's not the card you need put it back, and continue the process until you get to the card you need!
Combo:
Maul's Electrobinoculars + any card that initiates a duel
Guarantee yourself a solid start on any duel you initiate. A great deal, considering winning a duel is a rather large step toward victory in any game!
Gametext: Use 2 Force to deploy on Maul. At any time you may use 1 Force to peek at the top card of your Force Pile. You may move that card to the top of your Reserve Deck.

Lore: Trained in the Sith arts, Maul's ferocity in combat is matched by no other. When armed with a lightsaber, his opponent's only option is usually that of escape.
Information:
Maul's lightsaber 'personas' are:

Maul's Double-Bladed Lightsaber
Maul's Lightsaber
Darth Maul With Lightsaber
Lord Maul With Lightsaber
 -----
When Maul is using this weapon, it cannot be stolen. This simple bit of gametext protects Maul's Lightsaber from annoying interrupts like Weapon Levitation, that can result in the Dark Side suddenly finding itself weaponless in a battle.

In addition, Maul can make excellent use of his weapon. Darth Maul (Tatooine Expansion) can effectively ignore the presence of Light Side characters of ability less than 4. This means he can Force drain while at their site, using Maul's Lightsaber to add 1 to the Force drain. He can also use cards like Sniper to take pot-shots at those poor, low-ability characters, gradually reducing their numbers at his site. Light Side alien swarm decks will want to avoid this armed Dark Jedi as much as possible.

Finally, like other lightsabers, Maul's Lightsaber gets two weapons destiny draws, making it easier to hit even high-ability characters like Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon. Maul also has the advantage of using Maul's Electrobinoculars to rig a high destiny draw, practically guaranteeing a hit against even a Jedi Master if you take the time!

Lore: Passenger and cargo transport built by Gallofree Yards. Enormous cargo bays can be outfitted to safely accommodate large numbers of troops, munitions or supplies.
Information:
If you put this ship into a situation where it is unlikely to be battled (i.e. - the Clouds on Dagobah) it begins to shine. The most common way that the Dark Side has to overrun the Clouds on Dagobah, is to move a Star Destroyer loaded with TIE's over to the Dagobah system, have the TIE's move into the clouds, and start Tallon Rolli-ng all the starfighters that they can get their sights on. Because the Medium Transport is a capital starship that moves and deploys like a starfighter, it is immune to this silly tactic. It's power works out to be the same as a Y-wing (0), it suffers no penalties to it's Maneuver (it doesn't have one), it has a permanent pilot, and it's forfeit is one better! If you're opponent is using Bounty Hunter ships (like Slave 1), then deploy the Medium Transport to Kessel, put any pilot main character (except Chewbacca) aboard, and you have a destiny draw as well! Granted, it's not as powerful as Boba Fett in Slave 1, but with Yoda on the Dagobah: Yoda's Hut you'll be able to reduce the Attrition by 2, and your opponents power will be -2 for being in the Clouds.

Because the Medium Transport can deploy and move like a starfighter, it can deploy to a Docking Bay, and land at exterior Sites. This has come in handy for me several times, when an emergency evacuation is called for on Tatooine, or when I want to deposit some characters on Dagobah, and have no Encampments or Great Warrior's handy. Finally, for a really big power boost, deploy a Cloud Car into the belly of the Medium Transport at Kessel, and move it to Dagobah, and then into the Clouds. Drop off a few Cloud Cars this way, and guaranteed your opponent wont be aching to initiate a battle there.

Medium Transport + Cloud Car (repeatedly)

-----

Makes the Transport hyperspeed +2, immune to attrition < 3 and it may move for free.

-----
Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005
Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski

One of my pet peeves, briefly touched upon under #1, is character removal. The Dark Side is rife with popular ways to get rid of your heroes such as Dr. Evazan, Dark Strike, and Choke Vader. K'lor Slug (and Molator for the DS) helps you avoid painful beatdowns due to sudden losses of power and destiny draws. While this is more like IMI in that it helps your battles hold their effectiveness, the second part of the text goes very well with immunity mains. Your mains can get out at their normal cost, which greatly speeds up the time it takes to get them into play by a turn or more.

ARMAEDES' TAKE:
Again, I find this less of an offensive aid than a defensive aid, and more of a battle-hindering card than anything else. The dark side's character removal is a big way dark wins battles, so in my opinion taking this away makes effective battling more challenging. I really like this card - I think it is a necessary component of the game - but I'm not sure I would classify it as a battling aid.

Information:
Combo Card: Evader & Monnok
-----
This little Dark Side dejarik Interrupt can ruin your opponent's day. In addition to being of use on a Hologame Board as a dejarik creature with a destiny, power, ability, forfeit of 2, this card has two card stripping functions (one used and one lost) that can really disrupt a Light Side strategy.

The lost function: This can be a devastating hit if the light side is holding a lot of cards even in a carefully constructed deck. The four Force cost to play this lost function makes this a costly Interrupt to attempt but it can pay off in spades if you combine it with a Scanning Crew! Pay one Force for the Scanning Crew to take a look at his hand and if you see some doubles you'll know whether you want to play the Monnok or not.

Played at the right time this card can deliver a lot of damage in lost cards but the more painful loss to your opponent will be the limiting of his options in accordance with his intended strategy. Usually the cards that are multiples in a deck are the cards that the player is wanting to have access to quickly or often. If this option is removed along with the units of force you are well on the way to victory for the Empire.

(Errata) See Grimtaash.

(AR 1.7.1, B-8)
Grimtaash
(Errata) When this Interrupt targets your opponent's hand containing 13 or more cards, this is a condition of initiation (see actions). Thus, if you initiate Grimtaash, your opponent plays one or more cards as responses and those card plays reduce opponent's hand size below 13, your Grimtaash still has its result.
Gametext: USED: If opponent has 13 or more cards in hand, place all but 8 (random selection) in Used Pile. LOST: Use 4 Force to reveal opponent's hand. All cards opponent has two or more of in hand are lost.

Lore: BlasTech DL-18. Carried by Jabba's guards. Typically used for covering fire, to protect a comrade or pin an enemy down. Nicknamed "Mos Eisley Special."
IsPulled:
Jabba's Through With You
Mara Jade, The Emperor's Hand
Gametext: Use 1 Force to deploy on your alien warrior (free if on Tatooine). May target a character for free. Draw destiny. Target is forfeit -2 for remainder of turn if destiny +2 > defense value.

Lore: Easily obtained by the Rebellion. Many are copies of the BlasTech DL-18 design. Plentiful on Tatooine. Used for suppressive fire.
Information:
The Mos Eisley Blaster enhances the Light Side's biggest advantage over the Dark Side in Star Wars, their forfeit values.
The Dark Side, especially the aliens in Jabba's Palace, has surprisingly low forfeit values, and a savvy Light Side player can quickly exploit that. The Mos Eisley Blaster helps that out tremendously, knocking off two forfeit in one destiny draw. Against powerhouses like Vader and Boba Fett, this is hardly a scratch, but the Dark Side aliens will struggle to have any forfeit at all after being hit with one of these.
IsPulled: Portable Scanner
Combo:
Mos Eisley Blaster + A Gift
Use these two cards together to gain a big advantage in the attrition race. The Dark Side loses two off of its destiny draws, reducing the attrition that you take. Add in the Mos Eisley Blaster, and your opponent takes the same amount of attrition, but that attrition tends to go a little bit farther, by reducing a key character (such as Ortugg or J'Quille) to attrition fodder.
Gametext: Use 1 Force to deploy on your alien warrior (free if on Tatooine). May target a character for free. Draw destiny. Target is forfeit -2 for remainder of turn if destiny +2 > defense value.

Lore: A regenerating, primitive, violent, desert dwelling, fearless, mercenary-joining Lirin Car'n-befriending, cyclopian Abyssin from Byss. Calling him 'monoc' will start a fight.
Information:
One of the prime drawbacks of the bounty hunting "Scum And Villany" is their lack of adequate forefeit value.

So Myo is a natural with bounty hunters, but be aware of a few drawbacks. His ability 1 makes him a prime target for weapons fire (especially sabers which may drop his forefeit to 0). Obi Wan (and those with his cape) loves messing with Myo's mind and can easily send him away from the battle where he was needed. Finally, his deploy cost of 4 makes him difficult to get out of your hand.
Combo:
Myo + Bounty Hunters = Protect your low forefeit bounty hunters by throwing Myo in the way.
-----
Myo + Lone Warrior + Moment of Triumph = You only lose the destiny adders.
Gametext: Power +1 if present with Lirin Car'n or any bounty hunter. If lost or forfeited as a result of a battle, Myo 'regenerates' (place on top of your Used Pile).

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, F-1, Appendix A)
-----
Errata to: Naboo: Battle Plains (LS and DS)

http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16546

The use of the word "tank" on the light and dark side version of the card Naboo: Battle Plains has led to some confusion.

This was in all likelihood due to an internal communication problem during the development of Coruscant and Theed Palace at Decipher, with the former set assuming they would be called "tanks" and the latter calling them "AATs." This problem was compounded by the fact that the "AAT" cards did not have "tank" listed on them, even though it has always been assumed that was what the site was referring to. For this reason, the site will have its game text errata'd so that the correct term, "AAT" is used.

Naboo: Battle Plains (DS) DS text will read:
Unless Gungan Energy Shield on table, your AATs are each power +2 here.

Naboo: Battle Plains (LS) DS text will read:
Your AATs deploy +1 here.

There has been some discussion recently about how applying the picture to the ways of identifying would solve this problem. In actuality, it will create more problems than it solves. A single exception was created for gender, since this was leading to problems that couldn't be resolved short of issuing a list of gender clarifications. Greg Anderson felt that players should be able to use the existing information on the card to identify a gender characteristic, a position that Chuck Sonnenburg continued to support when he took over. But it was agreed that this would be the only exception ever - that coming up with a list of what would and would not apply to the picture would only add another layer of complexity to the rules.

An effort was made to instead shore up the issues by cleaning up the characteristics list, which can be noted by a comparison between the AR and previous rules documents; things like DH-17 and fusion generator have been added, and ones that did not fit in have been removed.

In an ideal world we would reissue every single card with all the characteristics on the card and do away with these rules altogether - but at this time this is simply not feasible. We have, we believe, the best possible alternative in place.
DarkSideText: Unless Gungan Energy Shield on table, your AATs are each power +2 here.
LightSideText: Once per game may take Gungan Energy Shield into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: Strong-armed H'nemthe thugs working for the Hutts. Work alongside Rodians and other unscrupulous aliens.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Nal Hutta site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your gangster or Rodian is on Nal Hutta) and, once during each of your control phases, may deploy one site to Nal Hutta from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: Many Aqualish draft and maintain bounty hunting contracts for the Empire, the Hutts or anyone with credits. Fight against the Alliance to avoid losing their best customer.
Pulls: One site to Ord Mantell
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Rules:
Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider:

http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16525

Changes to "Characteristics" re: "(LS) Intruder Missile"

Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider:

http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16525

Changes to "Characteristics" and application to "(LS) Intruder Missile":

In an ideal world we'd have no characteristics rules and lists and instead just list all aspects of a card, on the card. Since that would require a revision to thousands of cards, that's simply not practical. Every effort has been made to identify and discern what are and are not characteristics. Some may be missing from the list, while others are deliberately absent. Discerning which is which requires a bit of research and judgment.

After investigating, we're adding skiff and sandcrawler to the list of characteristics which apply to vehicles.

This brings us to the matter of (LS) Intruder Missile. This weapon and its possible interaction with Outrider has been a matter the PC has been considering for some time. By the rules, the one could not deploy on the other, but we were not ignorant of the possibility that this was an error of omission. Having looked through the evidence, we're now confident that Intruder Missile was not intended to work with Outrider.

We do not make these decisions lightly, and attempt to be thorough in our research of the original intent of the card interactions. We searched the records of play testing that we have from the development of Shadows of the Empire (the set that was incorporated into Reflections 2). In an original version of the Outrider, it was created to work with Intruder Missile, both via game text and the inclusion of the "YT-2400" in the subtype box. However, the game text was stricken over the course of play testing, and the "YT-2400" text moved out of the subtype box into the lore. This move was significant - the characteristic rules were well in place at this time, and Decipher had ensured that references to starships were almost entirely to icons or the contents of the subtype box. The only exceptions to this were defined characteristics (all ships are enclosed and all TIE/sa and B-wings are bombers) or squadron designations (which could be found in title, lore, or game text). Decipher, in fact, released only one card which was referenced by its lore instead of subtype: Blockade Flagship, because "Droid Control Ship" would not fit in that box - and Decipher then made a note to declare Droid Control Ship a characteristic.

Neither of these cases applied to Outrider - our tests using the original templates showed that "YT-2400" would fit with room to spare, and we know that Decipher made no such announcement. In addition, the text on Intruder Missile states that it also may deploy on the Falcon. It was not until two years after Intruder Missile came out that a Falcon was created that didn't state "YT-1300" in lore (both the original and Lando in Millennium Falcon did). If Decipher intended to reference it in lore, this specific mention wouldn't have been necessary.

Given the state of the characteristic rules at the time by Decipher, the striking of the game text, and the deliberate choice to remove a referenced card aspect from the subtype box, we feel this is sufficient evidence to support the existing ruling: Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider.

Because this matter has confused many players over the years, we are going to issue the following errata to Intruder Missile (LS) in the hopes of minimizing further confusion:

LS Intruder Missile:
Deploy on your B-wing, Z-95, YT-1300 Transport, or Falcon. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.
Gametext: May add 2 pilots and 1 passenger. Utinni Effects which retrieve Force are immune to Alter, but are placed out of play when completed. While Dash or Leebo piloting, immune to attrition < 4.

Power 3, Ability 3, destiny 3 and Forfeit 5 - all for 2 deploy! Statistics alone are a very solid reason to consider the disguised Queen for your deck! But there's more!

For one thing, this version of the Amidala persona is a Republic character, thus unaffected by anything that targets Rebels. For example, Charming To The Last, Put All Sections On Alert and the popular Scum deck helper, None Shall Pass, all fall flat when faced with this Republican.

Of course, her real kicker is in her game text. Besides the fact that her Jedi protectors keep her safe from weapon fire, she can even 'download' them! Twice per game, deploy Qui-Gon or Obi-Wan to Padme's site. That's a very fast way to get out any version of two of your biggest characters. And of course, you could just use it to get Qui-Gon twice to stall an opponent's Hunt Down, or perhaps Ben Kenobi twice to push your Profit deck along.

So what are her disdvantages? Only one, but it is red, black and nasty - Darth Maul is looking for her. But even then, Padme benefits - if Dark Side is playing a 'Hunt The Queen' strategy (I Will Find Them Quickly Master and the Epic Event, If The Trace Was Correct) then she can deploy straight from your Reserve Deck.

Lore: Naboo blaster personally modified by Captain Panaka. Boosted by extra power packs that allow it to maintain sustained fire in tense situations.
Information:
Traditionally, non-lightsaber weapon cards haven't fared too well in SWCCG decks. For one thing, it is difficult to get both the character and his matching weapon into play together without packing extra copies of both cards. And once the weapon is in play, it tends to have a lower chance of hitting a high defense value target than those lightsabers that get two weapon destinies. Finally, most weapons don't have the extra damage that lightsabers can cause through Force drains. Panaka's Blaster looks to be the weapon that bucks the binder fodder trend.

Panaka's Blaster can easily get on the table, since Captain Panaka's game text allows you to deploy a blaster from your Reserve deck. That solves the problem of getting the weapon out where it will do some good. It also has a very respectable chance of hitting a target, requiring a weapon destiny +2 greater than the target's defense value. Of course, the weapon destiny draw can be boosted with cards like Blaster Proficiency.

Beyond these basic characteristics, Panaka's Blaster has two more things going for it. First, if the blaster hits a target in a battle, the Light Side's total power in that battle is +3. The final bonus comes from game text on Captain Panaka: if Panaka hits a character with a blaster, your opponent has to lose 2 Force. This text is an interesting bit of direct damage that encourages the Light Side to battle early and often.

And for those players who really miss the Force drain bonus of lightsabers, there's always the used interrupt Rebel Artillery, which causes a 1 Force loss at a site you control where a non-lightsaber weapon is present. In battle, this interrupt can also cause an additional Force loss when Panaka hits a character. Overall, Panaka's Blaster is one of the most attractive weapons without a glowing blade this game has seen.

Lore: Good-natured former pilot whose family owns a galactic transportation company. Years of travel has enabled her to learn many loopholes in spaceport protocol.
Information:
Ahhh.... the delectable Phylo Gandish. This seemingly-unassuming lady has actually spent more time travelling the highways and byways of the galaxy than you've had Juri Juices! She may look beguilingly gentle, and most the time she is, but behind that enigmatic smile lies a woman you want on your side when you lead your forces into opposition territory!

Ability 4 is a great start. Add the fact that she is an experienced and effective +2 pilot, and it's now definitely worth paying 4 to deploy her. She's even immune to M'iiyoom! Do you believe though that you can deploy her for free to any docking bay!? Usually not hard to find one of those in today's environment! The ability to deploy free is huge, and almost single-handedly justifies her inclusion in most Light Side decks. For example, stock a docking bay and Insurrection (who doesn't? Especially with a combo version imminent!) and she can now be added to even your world-beating Watch Your Step deck.

All this, and we haven't even got to the kicker. Get her to your opponent's docking bay, preferably with a little backup (cause she attracts a lot of attention!), and suddenly the opponent may be left regretting that he ever started with Imperial Arrest Order. Your characters there receive a boosted defense value, and even some immunity. This all represents the fact that this lady of the hyperspace lane knows her way around spaceports as if she was born there.

If your Phylo-led expeditionary force takes the docking bay for their own, your drains there are now +2. Thats a drain of 3 at every one of a dozen of your opponent's docking bays. If you are protecting her with an appropriately armed Qui-Gon (who is now defense value 8!), then that saber will be adding to the Force drain insult.

With that sort of damage, suddenly your opponent is being forcibly diverted from more important tasks (like flipping his objective) as he is comitted to throwing resources to defend what was only going to be a site for a little force-generation. That may well tilt the game your way.

So with this wonder woman on your side, what do you have to fear? Weapon fire and attrition are the biggest threats, as Gandish may very well be the only one of your characters at that location who is not immune. As for weapons, sabers will paint her with a big target sign, and 4-LOM may very well find her to be a firm favorite in his targeting reticle. If you want to play sneaky, put her inside a vehicle for a little weapon and choke protection, perhaps even aboard a Rogue Squadron snowspeeder for some immunity as well (if you can get the appropriate pilot aboard). Remember, she will still be working her magic, and also adding 2 power - more than she would if left exposed on the ground.

Keep an eye out for this great gal! You're going to be seeing a lot of her. And remember, beware the double-edged sword that is the unattended docking bay!
Gametext: Deploys for free at a docking bay. Adds 2 to the power of anything she pilots. While at opponent's docking bay, adds 2 to your Force drains there, and your other characters there are defense value +1 and immune to attrition < 4.

Lore: Pit droids are used by Podracer pilots to assist in the maintenance of their racer. While a high standard is usually maintained, sometimes things can get out of hand.
Information:
Pit Crews provides a versatile card for your podracing deck. It can be used offensively to make the opponent think twice about drawing race destiny, or it can be used to ensure that your own Podracer is in peak racing performance by quickly repairing any damage that you might encounter during the podrace.

Or, if you draw this card after the podrace has already been decided, you can play it very effectively against swarm decks who might think their duplicates are protected by Yarna d'al' Gargan. But even if not playing against a swarm deck, this can give you a quick look at their hand to plan your next turn more effectively.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Manufactured by Serv-O-Droid on Cyrillia. Collapses into a compact form when hit on the nose.
Information: This little droid can definitely give you the edge in any podrace. He all but guarantees you will never have to keep any low destiny and ensures your Podracer stays in the lead. If you draw low, you can redraw it right away, and if it's still low, you can try again in your next control phase before you would draw for that turn. He also makes sure your Podracer is never damaged, ensuring that you'll never have to lose force to draw destiny, except for when you're redrawing yours with his other ability.
Gametext: While at Podracer Bay, once during each of your control phases may lose 1 Force to target your Podracer. Place target's top race destiny in Lost Pile, and draw one race destiny. During any control phase may use 1 Force to 'repair' your Podracer.

Lore: Kel Dor Jedi Council member descended from a long line of Jedi. Known for exceptional sensory skills, Plo Koon's control of the Force is unmatched by most.
Information:
Like just about all the Jedi in The Phantom Menace, Plo Koon spends all of his time in the Jedi Council Chamber.
As a result, he can only deploy there, and his game text only takes effect while at that location. But that's okay, since his game text is global, he'll work just fine in the comfort of the Council Chamber. While there, this powerful character will be immune to attrition, making it difficult for the Dark Side to eliminate him from play.
And your opponent will want to eliminate him from play, since once per turn he has the ability to cancel and cause a redraw for any battle or weapon destiny draw. This text can be used offensively or defensively. If you just drew a system or a main character for battle destiny, cancel it and redraw, likely causing more damage to your opponent in the process. On the other hand, if Darth Maul just got lucky and hit Obi-Wan with his lightsaber, cause a redraw in the hopes that the second draw might not be as good.
This text can really come in handy in the endgame, when your opponent might have just enough cards in his Reserve Deck for that lightsaber swing and a battle destiny. If you cancel and cause a redraw, he'll likely not have enough cards left for battle destiny.

Using the Lost function of this Interrupt card replaces a single race destiny draw. Additional race destiny draws may still be drawn normally.
Gametext: LOST: Instead of drawing race destiny, use a card from hand. STARTING: Deploy Podrace Arena (with a Podracer, opponent may also deploy a Podracer there), Boonta Eve Podrace and any Effect that deploys for free. Place Interrupt in Reserve Deck.

Lore: Podracing demands constant attention to many variables as well as all opponents. Failure to do so can often result in reduced performance.
Information:
The Used portion of this Interrupt is same as in Changing The Odds from the Light Side.
-----
This card has two very useful functions. A lot of popular Light decks use recycling interrupts like Fall of a Legend or Throw Me Another Charge which look through their decks to recycle high destiny interrupts. This card lets you punish your opponent for using cards just to look through their reserve deck or playing interrupts which don't really do anything. The Used portion of this card lets you look through their Reserve Deck and place any interrupt you find there out of play. If you're packing a couple of this interrupt, you can make your opponent think twice before looking for a Weather Vane.

The Lost portion is also useful. If your Dark deck is podracing, you will definitely want to run multiples of this card. This interrupt will set Anakin's racer back, giving you more time to finish the race; even better, the card that goes back to the Light player's hand might be just enough to create a tie, which all but guarantees a Sebulba win.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Gametext: USED: If you just verified opponent's Reserve Deck, search that Reserve Deck and place one Interrupt found there out of play. LOST: Lose 1 Force to remove a race destiny (random selection) from any Podracer and place it in owner's hand.

Lore: In a military situation, on a regional or galactic scale, commands sometimes get misinterpreted. A local commander giving orders is far more reliable.
Information:
This card is a more specific counter than the general purpose Alter. With the addition to the play environment of cards like Control and Do Or Do Not/There Is No Try, specific counters are likely to start gaining in popularity.

For a Dark Side primarily ground deck (such as a bounty hunting deck or a Walker Garrison deck), the specific counters might be a very good direction to head in. Point Man can cancel some of the cards that can really give these decks headaches, especially Asteroid Sanctuary. It can also be advantageous to cancel Scramble. Order To Engage, and No Disintegrations in a deck of this type.

Point Man can be combined with Boring Conversation Anyway in a deck designed to hamper a Sense/Alter strategy with the Tentacle/Control tactic. This will allow a measure of counter card advantage.
Combo: Point Man + Boring Conversation Anyway + Tentacle

Lore: Coolant emitted by the TCF32 Carbonite Encasement Apparatus is rumored to have a mildly euphoric effect on Ugnaughts. Individuals on TCF32 duty are regarded with envy.
Information:
This card has a couple of uses, which complement each other nicely. If you're building a Carbon Freezing deck, this is a quick and convenient way to get a +2 on your destiny draw. A few other modifiers, and you'll be freezing everything that walks into the Carbonite Chamber.

Even if you're not playing a Carbon Freezing deck, this card can obviously benefit from the presence of Ugnaughts. Unlike most "defending" cards, this does not require your Ugnaught to be alone, so if you have an Ugnaught and 3 other ability present, you can get two destiny draws. Plus, their ability to get weapons and devices from your Lost Pile to your *hand* makes Ugnaughts useful even in a non-Carbon Freezing deck. And, if you are playing Carbon Freezing, you'll want plenty of Ugnaughts anyway. You might find yourself using both versions of Prepare the Chamber in the same game.

Combo: Prepare the Chamber + Carbonite Chamber Console + 3 Ugnaughts + Carbon Freezing

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-12)
Effects that are "always immune to Alter" means any Effect which is unconditionally immune to Alter according to it's own game text, as these conditions must be met before such an Effect is on table. Therefore cards that are immune to Alter based on a condition in their game text (such as Come Here You Big Coward) cannot be deployed with this starting interrupt. Cards which are immune to Alter in their game text but can have that immunity canceled by other cards may be deployed using this Interrupt. For example, Prepared Defenses could still be used to deploy Mobilization Points even if Don't Do That Again was on table. When deploying Effects using this Starting Interrupt, each Effect deploys separately, and all automatic actions resolve normally. Thus if this starting interrupt is used to deploy Naboo Occupation, No Escape, and Imperial Arrest Order, Naboo Occupation may be deployed first (and will be immediately lost), followed by No Escape (which allows the dark side player to take the top card of the lost pile into hand) followed by Imperial Arrest Order.
Gametext: USED: Add 1 to your battle destiny just drawn. STARTING: Deploy up to three Effects if each of them deploys for free, is always immune to Alter and has "deploy on table" (or "deploy on your side of table") in its game text. Place Interrupt in Lost Pile.

With Cloud City, we finally get a new version of everyone's favorite princess, Leia Organa. And this version certainly packs a punch!

Gone is the spy skill, but that's OK, she has other priorities now. She can pilot starships and vehicles adding 1 to power. She does have a deployment restriction, but it is a pretty good variety. She may also deploy as a "react" to Hoth or Cloud City if Han or Luke are there. She may also move as a react to their site.

Probably the biggest change in Princess Leia is the ability 4. Yes, that's right, Leia can now use Anakin's Lightsaber. Another bonus, Leia can step in for Son Of Skywalker and Jedi train. With her Reflection, Leia tests as if she were ability 5. This leaves your Son Of Skywalker free to right the wrongs of the universe and face Darth Vader on Cloud City!

One of the hallmarks of the set, the new Princess Leia is a terrific character, with one extreme drawback, in that you must deploy her as a captive. This is simplified if your opponent helps you out by deploying a bounty hunter or Jabba to a site alone, or near alone. Simply deploy her one turn, hold on to your attack force, and assault the lone hunter another turn. If your opponent is more built up, or playing a Bounty/All Wrapped Up based deck, you'll have to be more crafty, with weapons and destiny-adding interrupts.

Another strategy is to simply leave her as a captive. The reduction in your opponent's forfeit values can be near-devastating, since the Dark Side's aliens are already low in forfeit. Add in some high destinies during battle, and you can wipe out an entire site with surprisingly little effort.

Lore: Arakyd Viper probe droid. Has sensors specifically designed to detect traces of Rebel activity. Equipped with an auto-destruct mechanism. A highly durable spy droid.
Information:
You can't deploy to the same site as the Probe Droid (he has no ability), but you can Force Drain with them, and with a forfeit of 5 they can look after themselves too. You can spread them out and send them Undercover, spread them out to Force drain or use them to ambush a lone character.

The Probe Droid is the first and currently only non-unique spy in the Star Wars Customizable Card Game. While this can be a terrific advantage, the Probe Droid's deployment restriction makes it rather difficult for it to deploy in any deck except for a strict Star Destroyer deck. However, in that deck, the Probe Droid has little to no equal for ground defense. Being non-unique has tremendous advantages in that you never have to worry if there is another Probe Droid on the table. Plus, with Undercover, you could potentially have an Undercover Probe Droid at every site, aiding in the deploy of such powerhouses as Darth Vader and Boba Fett to a hard to reach location. With Cane Adiss, these Droids can even go to Dagobah, which can significantly help against a Dagobah Force drain deck.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-13)
Although this Effect is triggered according to the number of characters at same site, only those characters present with it are lost when it explodes. For example, Program Trap is deployed on a droid with Lando aboard an enclosed vehicle at a site. Veers and Chewie are standing outside the vehicle; thus, there are four characters at that site. If either player draws a destiny of 4 (anywhere), the droid explodes, causing itself and Lando (the only other character present with it) to be lost. Although Program Trap may be deployed on a droid anywhere, it may explode only when that droid is at a site.
Gametext: Use 2 Force to deploy on an opponent's droid (except R2-D2 and C-3PO), 1 on your droid. When either player draws a destiny matching the number of characters at same site, droid 'explodes' (all characters present with Effect are lost).

Gametext: If you initiate a battle where present, you must predict the winner before the battle starts. If correct, randomly retrieve one lost card. If incorrect, lose 1 Force. Immune to attrition < 3.

Lore: "Chewie, this won't help me. Hey! Save your strength. There'll be another time. The princess...you have to take care of her."
Information:
Protector, like Old Pirates, presents a new twist on the traditional "teamwork" cards, such as Don't Get Cocky and Gift Of The Mentor. Like the traditional cards, this may be played when you have Leia and Chewie together in a battle. Your benefit is 2 added battle destiny. This is an impressive twist, as all other of the destiny-adding teamwork cards involve Luke. In a Teamwork-based deck, this can surprise an opponent who expects these powerful interrupts only from combinations involving Luke. And no one can deny the power of an extra 2 destiny in a battle, especially in a high destiny deck, as a Teamwork deck tends to be.

The extra text is quite useful. In fact, I'd venture to say that it is the most powerful yet. It allows you, if Leia is in a battle, to forfeit Chewie from your hand to satisfy all battle damage and attrition. This is quite nasty in conjunction with a few other cards. Obviously, you can use this to keep a squad of characters on the Death Star while your opponent is forced to lose some of his built up defense, but there are more subtle strategies.

One is an odd twist on the familiar Ghhhk strategy. One would play a lone TIE Fighter at a system and drain. When the opponent deployed there, he would play a Lone Pilot and then Ghhhk to avoid the damage. You can do something similar with this, and, in fact, the effect is much more devastating. With Princess Leia on the table, if you play Warrior's Courage, you get 3 battle destiny when she's alone. Then, simply play Protector, and lose Chewie, and she stays on the table. Doubly effective if she's been trained, or if she's carrying a Lightsaber.

The added cancelling ability can be useful as well, cancelling two very annoying interrupts. Frustration can be a pain in a deck designed for it, and cancelling I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee can be an added reassurance that your cards are going to get into play.
Combo: Leia + Han + Chewie + Obi-Wan + Luke + Skywalkers + Don't Get Cocky + Protector + Gift Of The Mentor + Rug Hug
Cancels:
Frustration
I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee
Gametext: If Leia and Chewie are in a battle together, you may add two battle destiny. OR If Leia is participating in a battle, you may lose Chewie from hand to satisfy all battle damage and attrition against you. OR Cancel I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee or Frustration.

Lore: Proton-scattering energy warheads. Especially effective against ray- and energy-shielded targets. Ineffective against particle deflector.
IsPulled:

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-13)
Proton Bombs deploy on your bomber. They can be used repeatedly in one of two different "bombing modes" depending on the kind of site being targeted:
- Interior sites - You may perform "orbital bombardment" in an attempt to 'collapse' a related interior site (as long as it is not protected by shields). This form of bombardment can only be performed from the system (or a cloud sector), and the bomber does not move from that location. The related site may be collapsed as a response to the initiation of the Force drain, but the Light player has first chance to respond. Therefore the Light player may cancel the drain (such as with Control) before the Dark Side gets a chance to collapse a site.
- Non-interior sites - You may perform "carpet bombing" during a Bombing Run in an attempt to destroy characters, vehicles and starships at a related non-interior site. See Bombing Runs, Ap. C.
Gametext: Deploy on a bomber. When you Force drain at same system, may target a related interior site. Draw destiny. Site 'collapsed' if destiny > 4. May fire in Bombing Run battle. Draw destiny. All characters, starships and vehicles with that destiny number at same site are lost.

Lore: Ever since Lando's 'little' maneuver at the Battle of Taanab, his piloting skills had become legendary.
Information:
People often want to re-enact Star Wars' fantastic epic space battles in the card game. The Light Side often struggles against the overwhelming power of the Imperial Armada's Star Destroyers. Cunning, daring maneuvers, and a little bit of luck saved the Rebellion in the movies. In the game, it takes all those things and intelligent management of interrupts.

Punch It! is a vicious interrupt that you should use if the Dark Side isn't wary, particularly when you spring it on him as he is trying to clear away ships. Play Captain Han and Lando on the Falcon with some Corvettes, and wait for your opponent to become smug with Vader on the Executor. The two extra destiny from this, plus the extra destiny from Captain Han and a destiny for ability of 4, adds 4 destiny draws to an already formidable Force.

The card has an extra ability that's dangerous, too. With Captain Han on the Falcon, you can get him to the Death Star and sit and drain. If your opponent tries to battle you, you can play this card for the extra 2 destiny and for immunity to attrition. The destiny draws will boost your power somewhat, reducing your battle damage (which you could play It Could Be Worse to reduce even more). The Falcon, since it is immune to attrition, remains at the Death Star for the next turn.
Combo: Captain Han Solo + Luke + Falcon + Punch It! + Out of Nowhere + Don't Get Cocky
Gametext: If Han or your Lando is piloting a starfighter which is defending a battle at a system, add one battle destiny (add two if starfighter is Falcon). Also, starfighter is immune to attrition for remainder of turn.

Lore: Naboo leader. Frustrated by the Trade Federation's control of her planet, Amidala came to the Senate to plead her case in person.
Information:
Amidala personas are:

Padme Naberrie
Padme Naberrie (V)
Queen Amidala
Queen Amidala, Ruler Of Naboo
-----
Queen Amidala is back in town, and the Senate will never be the same!

Just like her Padme Naberrie persona, Amidala has very well-rounded stats, even for a Light Side character. A high destiny draw, excellent forfeit, decent power, a dash of Politics, and that all-important 4 ability put her over many Light Side characters in almost every desirable category. She's even immune to attrition < 3.

However, unlike Padme, who is a key to Jedi battle strategies, the Queen works best in the Senate, pleading for the rights of her downtrodden people. She may not be a Senator, but she still contributes to a senate majority with her 2 Politics. She can even be placed on Political Effects like a Senator. And, like all good little Senators, Amidala gives you an excellent benefit for achieving a senate majority: you can retrieve 1 Force for each Naboo site you control.

"What?!" you ask. "Naboo? But... but... this is the Coruscant set!"

So it is, but you'll find quite a few Naboo sites lurking behind the scenes in Coruscant. Not only are there a few great drain sites in the bunch, but you can supplement them with generic sites from Special Edition to create a completely site-based "Celebration" deck that uses the immensely more secure Senate over a beatdown-prone system to achieve its retrieval. Smells like a deck type to me.

Just watch out for Darth Maul...

(Light side Icon)

Qui-gon Jinn has the distinction of being the only Light Side character to participate in armed combat during the Tatooine-based scenes of The Phantom Menace. This combat was in the form of a brief duel with Darth Maul. It should come as no surprise that Qui-gon's gametext reflects this conflict with Maul. When at a site with Maul, Qui-gon gets a power bonus that brings him to the same level as his nemesis, allowing them to start a battle on even ground. In addition, if Maul is bold enough to start a duel against Qui-gon, the Jedi Master has the ability to cancel a destiny draw and cause a redraw. While this text doesn't give Qui-gon an advantage in the number of duel destinies drawn, it does give him the opportunity to potentially reduce a high Dark Side destiny or increase an unfortunate destiny draw of his own.

Finally, Qui-gon Jinn is able to reduce the effectiveness of opponent's aliens at the same site by reducing their power by 1. This trick can be very useful when presented with a swarm of aliens, bringing their high power down to a more manageable level.

'Qui-Gon's Lightsaber' has (better) destiny of 5 but does not add to drain.

Continuing in the great tradition of the most powerful weapons in the game, the Light side now has another powerful unique lightsaber to add to their arsenal.

In addition to the always strong "ordinary" uses, like adding to a Force drain or cleaving targets like a ginsu knife, this elegant tool has a few additional benefits. Many of the new "Jedi helpers" (A Jedi's Concentration, A Jedi's Focus, and A Jedi's Patience) require your Knight or Master to be armed with a lightsaber, and thus Qui-Gon will be at his most efficient when he has his. You'll also find that Qui-Gon armed with his weapon is a tank, and when he holds it he joins Jedi Luke as one of the few Light side characters able to safely hold down a site all by himself.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Characters, vehicles, and starships can be heroic (whether by their own game text or have it provided). Whenever a heroic card is targeted by a weapon, add 1 to the total weapon destiny. Also, in a battle where there's a heroic card, non-heroic cards cannot be targeted by weapons unless all heroic cards are hit, not participating in battle, or cannot be targeted by that weapon.
For example, if light has a heroic character (Chewie) in a battle, then any dark side weapons that can target him can only be fired at him, but if they don't (such as targeting only a vehicle, or a non-Rebel character, or a Jedi, etc.) they wouldn't have to, if he was excluded from battle they wouldn't have to, if he left the table they wouldn't have to, if he was inside an enclosed vehicle (where he can't be targeted) they wouldn't have to, or if he was finally hit they wouldn't have to. Light would be able to target whomever they wanted because you can't target your own cards with weapons.

Lore: Strange female Snivvian who frequents the cantina daily. Betrayed her loved ones, who then left her on Tatooine to die. Everything she's ever cared about is now gone or dead.
Information:
Although the 8th Snivvian in Star Wars CCG Rachalt is the first pilot of her species to make it onto a card.

Her lore tells a story almost as harsh as her features, but her game text provides an ability you may find useful! Sandwiched between a little drain-adding text and a pretty standard piloting bonus is a nice interrupt-removal text. Whenever your opponent draws an Interrupt card for any destiny during battle, use 2 Force and throw it out! The destiny draw still counts (it is not canceled!), but that pesky recycling 5 can be taken a little further away from a player who is a good destiny tracker.

You may also think that devoting a weapon to Rachalt isn't really worth the effort for a Force drain +1 (even with Inconsequential Losses), but don't forget that if the opponent isn't running Menace Fades, Honor Of The Jedi, or Jedi Test #1, this is a handy way to turn a site with no Dark Side icons into a pesky "pinger." Of course, Rachalt ain't too great at avoiding weapon fire herself -- so keep her safe aboard something enclosed, and lo and behold, her +1 to drains still works! Maybe this Dark Side uncommon will find a place in a few of your decks after all?

Lore: Optimized for diplomatic missions with sensor-proof pods that have ejection capabilities. Easily identified by its red coloration.
Information:
Radiant VII personas are:

Obi-Wan In Radiant VII
Radiant VII
-----
This little ship brought Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon to Naboo, but it can do much more than that.
For one thing, you never need to worry about drawing this ship into your hand, since the Used Interrupt We Wish To Board At Once will let you take the Radiant VII into your hand from the Reserve Deck. Once in your hand, you can use Squadron Assignments to deploy it with one of its matching pilots (Captain Madakor or Lieutenant Williams) with ease. Once Williams and Madakor are piloting the Radiant VII, it is bumped up to 9 power and immunity to attrition less than 5. Add a third pilot like Ric Olie to increase the ship's power to 12. In addition, if you have no other ships at the system, your opponent will be unable to draw more than one battle destiny here, and unless they have ability > 6, that destiny will be reduced by 3, making it difficult for the Dark Side to get this pesky little ship out of its sky.

Lore: Opportunists work with corrupt governments and Raithal casino operators. Keep the Empire informed of local Alliance activity, for a price.
Pulls: One site to Raithal
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Raithal site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your gambler or tax collector is on Raithal) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Raithal from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Information: Rayc, as a character, won't make it into many general use decks. He's a little expensive for a power 2, ability 2 character. However, in a space deck, he is near invaluable. Tallon Roll is one of the more effective means for the Dark Side to get rid of pesky starfighters (like the Falcon.) Rayc makes his starfighter immune to this tricky maneuver, protecting you from a world of hurt. Also, against an Asteroids deck, he can be extremely useful, avoiding the nasty Asteroid sector draw. Put him on a high maneuver ship, like an X-Wing on the Falcon, and he'll almost never be hit by a rock. Send him in to the Asteroids on Rycar's Run, which he performs better than any character in the game.

Lore: Nerf herder. Personally oversees the herding of Jabba's nerfs. Scruffy-looking appearance conceals his expertise in unusual combat techniques.
Information: Since the Hoth expansion came out, people have been wondering about Rennek: would it be a strange new alien, a Jawa or Han Solo's long lost brother? The answer came out with Jabba's Palace, when we learned that Rennek was the king of the sruffy-looking nerf herders. With Power and Ability of only one, the little Rennek seems pretty ordinary, but when you look at his game text, you realize he has the power to change the course of a game. First, he prevents all creatures from attacking at his site (except the almighty Sarlacc, who don't listen to anything but it's stomach), thus protecting you from such nasties as Bubo, the Wampas and especially the roaming Rancors. By keeping Rennek with your small power characters, you can use their game texts longer. The second part of his game text is also interesting: you can raise Rennek's Power three times per turn for only one Force each time! In the mid-game, when you have plenty of Force, Rennek is an argument that your opponent will have to consider. With Who's Scruffy-Looking?, you can double Rennek's Power, thus showing that unusual combat techniques are sometimes the best.
Combo: Rennek + Who's Scruffy-Looking?
Gametext: Creatures at same site (except Sarlacc) do not attack and cannot be attacked. Up to three times per turn, may use 1 Force to cumulatively add 1 to his power for remainder of turn.

Ultimatum
The text of this card comes into effect as an automatic action when you lose your second Force (and meet all other requirements of the card). For example, if you are being drained for 5 Force and you satisfy the battleground requirements of Ultimatum as well as having It Could Be Worse in hand and 2 Force saved. Lore: After seeing Vader strike down Obi-Wan, Luke attacked recklessly until he heard the old Jedi Master's voice warn, "Run Luke, Run!"
Information:
Just look at that face! Want to have luke in three places at once? That is just what this card allows Luke to do. With all the versions of Luke currently available, this card is a favorite in my tournament decks. With a destiny of 6, this card becomes even better.

Just think about this situation. Son Of Skywalker, carrying his trusty lightsaber, is standing at Cloud City: Incinerator with R2-D2 busy looking for C-3PO. He hears a clatter back at Cloud City: Guest Quarters where he left Princess Leia last turn. He hears a voice in the back of his mind saying "Run Luke, Run!" and dashes back to the Cloud City: Guest Quarters to find Boba Fett attacking the princess. This angers him and he becomes Power +2. Family pride, Skywalkers, increases the battle destiny to three draws. Boba better hightail it out of there or he's going to be toast.

If this wasn't enough, you can also use this card to avoid Epic Duels.
Combo: Run Luke, Run! + Son Of Skywalker
Cancels: Vader's Obsession
Gametext: At any time, move Luke as a regular move (using landspeed for free) to a battle just initiated at an adjacent site. Luke is power +2 during that battle, unless Vader is present or adjacent to the battle site. OR You may cancel Vader's Obsession.

Lore: Trade Federation settlement officer serving as legal council to Viceroy Gunray. Reputed to have one of the sharpest legal minds in all of the Republic. Neimoidian.
Information:
Rune Haako personas are:

Rune Haako
Rune Haako, Legal Counsel
-----
While he may not seem as strong as Lott Dod, Nute Gunray, or that stunted slime Daultay Dofine, Rune Haako definitely has his uses.

One of the first things you'll notice is that Rune has one of the highest forfeit values of any Dark Side character - a whopping 6 - making him ideal forfeit fodder. He also has 3 ability, 2 power, 2 destiny and remarkable game text that makes battle a snap.

While Rune is in battle, you may choose one number. If the destiny on the next card your opponent draws for destiny matches the number you called, it's reduced to zero. It doesn't matter if your opponent was drawing for battle destiny, weapon destiny, Fallen Portal destiny: as long as the number on the drawn card matches Rune's ever-tingling "destiny sense," it's effectively canceled.

Of course, it can be hard to call the right number at the right time. Fortunately for you, Rune has some other applications. For one thing, he's a miniature Scum And Villainy, enabling you to retrieve Force when you initiate battle at his site or an adjacent site. For another, Lott Dod can increase his forfeit value to an amazing 8. And then there's The Phantom Menace to contend with.

Lore: The infamous smuggler Rycar Ryjerd does this all the time. He's an idiot.
Information:
One of the many force retrieval methods for the Light Side, Rycar's Run stands above the rest. First of all, it is efficiant. Combined with an Asteroid Sancuary deck, you don't have to put in any useless cards to make Rycar's Run work. The only other things you need are Closers, and those have a destiny of 6, and they are used. Rycar's run also only takes 2 turns to pull off, if you use a Closer each turn. Also, you get 8 Force (assuming all asteroid sectors are present, which shouldn't be a problem in an Asteroid Sanctuary deck) for just losing 1 card and using others that you would be using regardless. No destiny draws, you know what you are getting, and it sets you up for another 'Run. You can't lose it by having your target/ship killed with an Interrupt like Gravity Shadow with Kessel Run, or Look Sir, Droids with Death Star Plans.

The problem arises with that one turn where your ship gets stranded out at the Big One. This is easily conquered with Cap'n Han on the Falcon with R2-D2, Chewie, and maybe even some Special Mods. Or even R2-D2 and Luke on Red 5. This pretty much makes your ship tough to get with battles, and nearly impossible (watch out for DS asteroid decks) to kill with Asteroids, ensuring that the 'Run goes through. So, what Rycar's Run actually does for your Asteroid Sancuary Deck is to make you last longer against ground-drain decks without incorporating unreliable undercover spies. I would recommend putting about 4 of them in a Sancuary deck, along with 6 Closers.

Lore: Female chosen as a handmaiden by Panaka due to her resemblance to Amidala. Trained to play the role of the Queen whenever it is considered that Amidala may be at risk.
Information:
Got Amidala in your deck? Then there is no reason not to play Sabe while you're at it as well.

Sabe provides two different benefits, depending on whether you have Amidala out on the table or not:

1. Amidala not on the table? Sabe is actually the better character to pull before Amidala herself. Sabe deploys for only two Force and lets you deploy Amidala out of your Reserve Deck or Lost Pile for free, so in a sense you're actually saving Force by using Sabe over a second copy of Amidala!

2. Already have Amidala out? Sabe provides extra power in this situation and also makes the queen immune to attrition. Even if you forfeit Sabe before a battle has concluded, Amidala will keep her immunity for the remainder of that battle. (See immune to attrition in the Glossary.)

Advantageous in either situation above, Sabe is great in any deck that revolves around the ruler of the Naboo.

Information:
CubsFan in the PC Rules Questions Forum Mon Aug 21, 2006 9:56 pm

Control may be played as a response to the deployment of Sandwhirl, before it has a chance to resolve. Therefore, you may cancel Sandwhirl before it makes the characters go lost.

This only works, however, if Control is actually declared as a response. If Sandwhirl is successfully deployed, Controlling it later won't help your poor missing characters.
-----
Sonn in the PC Rules Questions Forum Tue Aug 22, 2006 12:02 am

Any interrupt that cancels may be played during the optional response portion of the deploying action, and thus cancel it before it ever reaches play. This is why Surreptitious Glance can cancel Dark Deal against TDIGWATT, because the objective doesn't flip until Dark Deal hits the table.

Then play Close Call, causing them to reveal the top cards of their Force Pile, Reserve Deck, and Used Piles, and then to lose those cards of the lowest destiny greater than zero. If you are lucky, you might even knock off another card in addition to the one you removed from their hand.

Lore: Hold-out blaster utilized by Imperial scouts. Small size limits range, but concealability is often an asset.
Information:
A deploy free, fire free blaster for Biker Scouts is one of the most sought-after cards in booster draft play. It has average hitting power, destiny > defense value, but it can take out any pesky Ewok (like Wicket or Chirpa) or Rebel (like Kensaric or Beezer) who is giving you trouble. A Dark side spy can also fire for free, making this a very good weapon to use with Sniper. The destiny 4 number on this blaster is decent, too. Deploying Biker Scout Gear will make the Scout Blaster a 6 when drawn as destiny.

While the Scout Blaster is just like an everyday blaster to most characters, in an Endor deck it becomes quite the accessory. The ability to hold onto this weapon until after your opponent has initiated a battle brings the important advantage of surprise to your side of the table.

Lore: Bad tempered Dug from Pixelito. He was about to turn Jar Jar into orange goo, until Anakin intervened.
Information:
If Jar Jar is the problem, then Sebulba is the answer. Sebulba can permanently deal with Jar Jar if the Gungan is foolish enough to wander over to the same location as Sebulba. There won't be any more Brisky Morning Munchen once Sebulba is finished turning Jar Jar into orange goo!

Sebulba is also a solid choice for any alien based decks. 4 power for 3 deploy is a good deal, but with his ability to reduce an opposing character's power, it's almost as if he had 7 power! And he can help his good buddy Snoova and his Vibro Ax capture large hairy Wookies from time to time, too, making Chewie an easy mark.

Lore: Some hidden modifications mean Sebulba's Podracer doesn't conform to race specifications. The duplicitous Dug has equipped it with a flame emitter that can fry other Podracers.
Information:
If you're a Dark side player, and you want to win a podrace, then this is your best choice. He adds 3 to each of his race destinies, so depending on the destiny in your deck, he will usually finish the race for you in 4 turns.

To make it even more likely he'll win, he also gets a head start. Since he can prevent the opponent from drawing racing destiny if he's tied, you will always get a head start at the beginning of the race when both racing totals are zero. If your opponent manages to catch up to you, there's no worries, because you can stop the opponent from drawing destiny every time you're tied. This podracer is full of dirty tricks!
Gametext: Deploy on Podrace Arena. Adds 3 to each of your race destinies here. If you and your opponent have the same race total, may use 2 Force. Opponent draws no race destiny for remainder of turn (may only be used once for any race total).

Lore: "I think I got it."
Information:
Counter card against the Light Side Objective Hidden Base.
----- Oh.... you've got a Hdden Base? Have no fear, we'll find it..... This is one of the large nails that Endor put in the old school Hidden Base deck. It allows you to compete in space without having to devote as much starship power as the Light Side Hidden Base player probably has devoted. It carries two side effects. One is to discourage the Hidden Base player form attempting an early flip. Once probing begins and he only has 5 systems in play, you can knock them short time. Nasty damage for Light Side is the result. It pays for the Hidden Base player to delay for a few more systems, forcing that awful decision of whether or not the should flip early to go for the drains or hold out until they can scare you away from space altogether. The Imperial Navy is not easy to scare.

Additionally, your somewhat more meager fleet is protected form the perils of the outrageous one turn beat-down - a common complaint from old X-Wing S-Foil swarms which could devastate the Imperial Fleet as well as the Dark Side Reserve Deck in one blow! The other function just increases the utility of this card, adding a bit of Force generation - even providing a little extra help against Force Choke decks. But remember, you cannot begin probing until AFTER the opponent flips his Hidden Base Objective - be sure to time your moment well.

This ups his forfeit value to 5, but the ability to get out a Docking Bay is a sneaky way to complete your Spice Mines. Deploy Kessel, get out the Spaceport Docking Bay and drop your Spice Mines Of Kessel Utinni Effect there. One more Docking Bay for the planet you are on and retrieval + 4 is well on it's way.
