Lore: "...bring me the passengers. I want them alive!" Imperial soldiers use blaster stun settings to intimidate or to capture prisoners for questioning and interrogation.
Information:
Sometimes just getting rid of a character for even one turn can be a benefit. How many of you have lost a game by just a few cards? Pretty much everyone right? Those are the kind of games where you say, "Boy just one little change and I would have two points instead of zero." Well let's talk about some scenarios where getting rid of a character for a turn would make a difference. And keep in mind that when you send them back is just as important as who you send back.

A good target for Set For Stun is where the opponent has just enough ability to get a destiny draw. They have Owen and Beru at the Moisture Farm. Beru has ability of one, send her back to the opponent's hand and they have gone from four power and nine forfeit, to 1 power and four forfeit. Now deploy some characters and battle away, free of the uncertainty of a destiny draw.

How about getting rid of that Undercover Spy that's blocking your Force Drain of two or three. Play Set For Stun during your control phase and drain away. It's not as permanent as Sniper, but it only requires one card.

Sy Snootles (V)

Send a Rebel back into the hand then scan it right into the Used Pile.

Swamps are:

Naboo: Swamp
Swamp
-----
This is one expensive lady. For the 3 Force you are paying out, you are only getting an immediate power of 1 and ability of 1. Though she seems vulnerable to weapons fire (low ability number) actually, she does have armor of 3. Like the other Ishi Tibs, Shasa is power +1 at swamps. A rather useless game function currently considering the number of swamps that are played with. What she can do though, is mess with the order of your Force Pile. During your opponents control phase, you can pay 3 Force to sort throuh their Force Pile and rearrange the cards any way you choose. Quirky hun? It may take some time, but I wonder if anyone can find a cool way to use this game text? Finally, she is also a Representative for her race while she is in the Audience Chamber and will add +2 to the power and forfeit of all other Ishis.
Combo: Shasa Tiel + Frozen Assets
Gametext: Power +1 at any swamp. During opponent's control phase, may use 3 Force to examine the cards in opponent's Force Pile, reorder however you wish and replace. While at Audience Chamber, all your other Ishi Tibs are power and forfeit +2.

Lore: Mother of Anakin Skywalker. As Anakin grew, Shmi realized her son was special. Did her best to hide his abilities from Watto.
Information:
Everybody loves reducing opponent's battle destiny, and Shmi is no exception. If your opponent is drawing multiple battle destiny, Shmi can lessen the damage from each one. She can also sometimes prevent you from losing anything at all. Many times your opponent will draw a one for battle destiny, which normally would force you to lose something, but Shmi will reduce that one to a zero, saving all your characters.

She also lets you get Threepio With His Parts Showing from your Reserve Deck once per game. While that might not sound like a great benefit, the two characters work great together in battle. Threepio lets you put a card from your hand into your Used Pile, and when with Shmi in battle he lets you put the top card from your Used Pile on to your Reserve Deck which can enable you to get a guaranteed weapon hit, or any other action which requires a high destiny.
Pulls: Threepio With His Parts Showing
IsPulled: Tatooine: Slave Quarters
Combo:
Shmi + Threepio With His Parts Showing
Destiny tracking never so easy.
Gametext: Deploys for free to Slave Quarters. Once per game may take [Tatooine] Threepio into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. While in a battle at a site, subtracts one from each of opponent's battle destiny draws.

Lore: "R2-D2, you know better than to trust a strange computer."
Information:
Scrambled Transmission makes Shocking Information immune to Sense.
-----
At the moment, a lot of people are using variants of Mike Riboulet's Dark Sided Manipulator. This involves the opponent scanning your hand in many ways - including Onith and Scanning Crew. By having an Information up your sleeve, you can't cancel the scan but you can lose the card which allowed the scan and the DS lose 4 Force as well! If the opponent doesn't have any scanning cards in his deck, this card is not wasted - it's destiny 5, and a Used Interrupt which can be recycled with its other function. There is a DS version of this card, Shocking Revelation, but it's of much less value.


This card provides defense against some very strong Premiere strategies that have thrived on the tournament scene. Also, it provides an easy way to cycle itself back into the Life Force and prevent Monnok from causing the damaging loss of doubles. This card can be played on any location, regardless of whether there is a scomp link on the location card.

The five destiny can be cycled very easily, which is excellent for monitoring high destiny draws. Before this card, players would often have to rely on playing A Few Maneuvers or Dark Maneuvers, which also required a starfighter to be in play. The drawback is that the destiny number is slightly lower.

The most obvious use of this card is to protect against Scanning Crew and M'iiyoom Onith. The loss of four Force, plus the card causing the scan can suggest to the opponent that searching should only be done in the case of true necessity. This will help the Light Side player climb out from underneath a couple of extremely strong lock down strategies.

Hopping Mad
Scrambled Transmission
Combo: Shocking Information + Destiny adders
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-14)

Lore: "Oh! Go away! Go away! Beastly thing!"
Information: Bubo and the Rancor cause plenty of problems, but this Used Interrupt with a hefty destiny can help! If you have a droid on the table, you may either cancel and attack just initiated by a creature OR move one opponent's creature (except an attached creature) to an adjacent site, habitat permitting. Canceling the attack is very nice since you can then attack the creature with all your characters later, using any weapons you might have. Having Bubo chomp Han or Leia is very annoying, especially when playing Rescue The Princess or You May Either Profit By This... so that your objective gets messed up. Moving a creature over to where your opponent has the only characters is an excellent ulterior use of this card if that creature happens to be able to attack your opponent's characters. Something would most likely die, and the key thing is that it wouldn't be one of yours! All this and a destiny 6!
Cancels: An attack just initiated by a creature.

Lore: At his peak, no one could stand up to the Dark Lord of the Sith. His superior tactics devastated those who opposed him.
Gametext: USED: During a battle, lose one of your lightsabers in that battle to cause all non-unique aliens present to be lost. LOST: If a duel was just initiated, draw 2 destiny. Opponent draws 3 destiny. If the player with the lower total loses the duel, that player loses 6 Force.

Lore: Patrol droids utilized by the Sith. Each droid has several multispectral imaging devices and a communications package. Used by Maul to track down Amidala.
Information:
A no-brainer for any "Capture the Queen" deck, these little mechanoids have a number of outstanding features. Their retrieval text means that playing with a few of them can help out any deck. When you have a crucial card on the top of your Lost Pile, or if you had to forfeit a vital character on your opponent's turn, then the deployment of a Sith Probe Droid will allow for its rescue.

They also serve as the ultimate hunters and trackers of Amidala. You don't have to play with too many copies, either, since the Epic Event If The Trace Is Correct allows them to be "downloaded." Get 2 or 3 roaming the same planet as the Queen, and she will be unable to escape the reach of the Sith Apprentice for long.
IsPulled:
Captain Piett
If The Trace Was Correct
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-14)
The "limit 1 per location" text on this droid works as per the operative rules (see Characteristics - Operatives, Ap. D). A player may not voluntarily deploy or move a Sith Probe Droid to or across a location where another Sith Probe Droid is located. If this should ever happen accidentally, the owner must choose one to be lost. If they belong to different owners, the droid lost is determined randomly.
Gametext: When deployed, immediately retrieve 1 Force. Limit 1 Sith Probe Droid per location. If present with Amidala during your control phase may use 3 Force to relocate this Sith Probe Droid to Maul's site, and relocate Maul to same site as Amidala.

IsPulled: Dagobah: Training Area
Gametext: *Deploy on Dagobah: Swamp or Dagobah: Bog Clearing. *Target a mentor on Dagobah and an apprentice who has completed Jedi Test #3. *Attempt when apprentice is present at the beginning of your control phase. Draw training destiny. If destiny + apprentice's ability > 15, test completed: *Place on apprentice. Immune to attrition < 3. Once during each of your control phases, you may use 2 Force to take any one card into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: Repulsorlift engine. 9.2 meters long. Controlled by two directional steering vanes. Jabba's fleet of skiffs is maintained by Barada.
Information:
Skiffs are:

Racing Skiff
Skiff
-----
This open transport vehicle is one of the better rides available for Light Side and Dark Side characters alike. It deploys -1 to Tatooine sites, Tatooine being one of the fairly popular planets on the tournament scene.
A Skiff has excellent capacity, easily accommodating one driver and up to five passengers. Remember that the driver need not be a pilot, and doesn't add a piloting bonus to the transport vehicle if he/she is a pilot. However, the driver makes use of his/her personal power along with the passengers since they're all on an open vehicle. Although this makes them vulnerable to weapons fire, any or all the characters on board may surely fire back.
Dark Side Skiff users may wish to take advantage of an Anti-personnel Laser Cannon deployed on the vehicle as well. The most powerful feature of the Skiff is its ability to move as a react. Being able to move as many as six characters to a battle or Force drain is always advantageous. To protect those characters, they may all disembark should the Skiff become lost, unlike most other vehicles. Taking into account of its attractive features, the Skiff is best utilized with mains and other tough characters to protect multiple exterior sites by reacting to where they're needed. (Just beware of Sense!) Skiffs can play a powerful role in many decks encompassing ground forces by keeping them highly mobile. Mobility is a definite tactical advantage.
Gametext: Deploy -1 to a Tatooine site. May add 1 driver and 5 passengers. May move as a 'react.' If lost, any characters aboard may "jump off" (disembark).

A much more modern version of your transport vehicles. This is a truly a card showing you get what you pay for. For your 3 Force you are getting a 3 power, forfeit, maneuver and landspeed. Not too bad. It will deploy for a -1 on Tatooine and may carry 6 passengers. I can really see this becoming this years exciting new model, while Deserts are on the table.

Lore: Regarded as whiners. Skrillings are a scavenger species. Steal from corpses left behind on battlefields. Feed on carrion and uncooked meat. Avoided by many species.
Combo: Skrilling + Tusken Scavenger
Gametext: Once per turn, may steal a weapon or device from an opponent's character just lost or forfeited where present. When you play Tusken Scavengers, may steal vehicles, weapons and devices found (place them in your Used Pile).

Lore: Bidlo Kwerve was involved in both the procurement and (posthumously) the loss of the rancor.
Information: The Skull is a strange card in that it actually forces you to put your own character out of play. In general, this is a bad thing, but it's important to note that the out of play rules don't affect non-unique characters. Also, they don't stop you from putting multiple copies of a unique card out of play. If you can manage to get a high destiny character into your Lost Pile early (like Wedge Antilles or Leesub Sirlin), then you can use their skulls for a massive power boost. Jawas are naturally a destiny of 3, making them very good choices for skull-throwing.
Pulls:
Blast The Door, Kid!
Fallen Portal
Combo: Skull + Fallen Portal -- This combo is obvious, but is very helpful. Fallen Portal is a powerful card, especially if you can lure your opponent into one of the sites mentioned on the card. With the low-ability aliens running around, Fallen Portal can be a surprisingly effective way of taking out your opponent's characters.
Gametext: During a battle or attack, place out of play one non-droid character, creature or creature vehicle from your Lost Pile. Add its destiny number to your total power. OR Search your Reserve Deck, take Fallen Portal or Blast the Door, Kid! into hand and reshuffle.

Lore: To simply be a sitting member of the Galactic Senate consumes a lot of time and energy. The opposition that is arrayed against you does not make it any easier.
Information:
This is the ultimate utility card for your senatorial needs. If you're using the new objective My Lord, Is That Legal?, you'll want to use multiples of this card to get your key senators and their bodyguards, Coruscant Guards, out. And once you have all the key characters you need at the senate, this doubles as late-game force retrieval.

But you can also use this in a non-senate deck to get a key senator on a matching effect. For example, you can use Squabbling Delegates to get Orn Free Taa to put on Motion Supported and get a very useful ability, all without needing the Galactic Senate.

Combat Response
Once an unpiloted starfighter (or pilot) is revealed, if no matching pilot (or unpiloted starfighter) is found, the opponent is permitted to verify. Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-14)
Although this site is not a docking bay, starfighters may deploy here as if it were a docking bay. The site's game text is clarified as follows:
Shuttle - Your cards that may shuttle to this site's star destroyer may instead shuttle here; likewise, your cards here may shuttle to a site related to that star destroyer.
Transfer - You may dock another starship with this site's related star destroyer (following the normal rules of moving between docked starships) and transfer cards between that starship and this site (when doing so, the cost of docking is free).
Embark - Your starships may land at this site as if it were a docking bay.
Disembark - Your starships may take off from this site as if it were a docking bay.
These actions cannot be combined with similar actions involving this site's star destroyer; for example, you may shuttle a group of characters to this site and a group of characters to the star destroyer itself, but these are both separate actions and are handled accordingly (the ones shuttled to the star destroyer would not be free).
DarkSideText: Your TIEs deploy -2 here. You may shuttle, transfer, embark and disembark here for free.
LightSideText: Starships captured by Star Destroyer go here and may be Besieged. Immune to Revolution.

Lore: Stormtroopers are trained to stun, not kill, priority targets in order to split enemy forces and hold the leaders for interrogation. Stun effects wear off, requiring efficient action.
Information:
This is another equalizer for you anti-Mains and Toys players out there, especially with the release of Cloud City. Two things in Cloud City made this card especially great: interior draining and Trooper Assault.

Since Stunning Leader only works at interior sites, most people found little use for it before Cloud City. After all, the best draining sites for the Dark Side were almost exclusively exterior! Virtually every Dark Side site with a Force drain for two or more was an exterior site like the Tatooine: Lars' Moisture Farm, Tatooine: Jundland Wastes, or Hoth: Defensive Perimeter.
With the release of Cloud City, the Dark Side now has a set of interior sites with decent draining opportunities. Unlike the Death Star or Executor sites, these have Light Side icons allowing a modest drain. Adding Dark Deal to a Cloud City deck could be devastating to an ill-prepared Light Side deck. With lightsabers and Dark Deal, Cloud City is an okay place to Force drain for the Dark Side. Oh, and don't forget about Bounty Hunting opportunities.

Along with Cloud City's interior sites came a nice Used Interrupt called Trooper Assault. This card simulates the endless hordes of troopers the Imperial Army seems to muster by making all Dark Side troopers in a battle power +2 and immune to all attrition. This one interrupt almost single-handedly made troopers viable again.

So where does Stunning Leader fit into the equation? Well, consider a Cloud City Force drain deck with troopers as its primary site defenses. Every site (don't use the Docking Bay) is interior, meaning Stunning Leader can be played at a site battle anywhere. All troopers are ability 2 or lower, so they won't be excluded from the battle when Stunning Leader is played - this interrupt isolates your troopers against the Light Side's non-mains.
Combo:
Stunning Leader + Cloud City sites + Lift Tubes
A great point defense system that'll allow you to spread a bit thinner than normal and still be able to bring all your low ability characters to brawl in a mainless battle.
-----
Stunning Leader + Ability > 2 Imperials + Stormtroopers + Trooper Assault
This is awesome because you get a speed gain and a defensive gain; the Stormtroopers deploy for free and Stunning Leader excludes the high ability Imperial, leaving only totally immune troopers in the fight. Add a Comlink for more fun.
-----
Stunning Leader + Cloud City Troopers + Imperial Trooper Guards + E-3P0
Bring out the odds cards! With this kind of Cloud City defense force, you could have a blast with Light Side Mains. Trooper Assaults would make the power here obscene. Don't forget the E Chu Ta for maximum insult to injury.
-----
Stunning Leader + IT-0 + IG-88 + Probe Droid
How about a droid strike team? Exclude all their mains and send your droids on suicide missions. Retrieve with the Cloud City: Incinerator and repeat ad infinitum. With a spy on the team, it can't be kept out of the action.

(AR 1.7.1, B-9)
Inconsequential Losses
The game text "may forfeit one of its weapons" means that a character, starship or vehicle may only forfeit a weapon deployed on that character, starship or vehicle. Thus a character cannot use this Effect to forfeit an artillery weapon at the same location, a starship cannot forfeit an Orbital Mine at the same system and so on. The game text that allows your forfeited weapons go to your Used Pile applies to any weapon you forfeit (including artillery weapons that already have a forfeit value).
Gametext: Deploy on table. Each turn, each of your characters, vehicles and starships may forfeit one of its weapons (except a lightsaber) using forfeit value = 3. Also, your forfeited weapons go to Used Pile. (Immune to Alter.)

Lore: Although Finis Valorum maintains the Galactic Senate's ultimate title, his real power is mired by endless bureaucracy, petty corruption, and incessant plotting.
Information:
People call Finis Valorum the Bill Clinton of Star Wars. I like to call him the General Zod of SWCCG. If you plan to base your deck around the Galactic Senate, or if you just want to mop the floor with those weenie Dark Side Senators for laughs, Supreme Chancellor Valorum is your man.

With a hefty 5 Politics, Valorum has the highest concentration of political power in the game. Even better, Valorum has excellent stats outside of the Senate, with 4 Ability (all the better to draw battle destiny when alone at the Senate) and a whopping 7 Forfeit. Top it all off with a multiple-use-friendly 3 Destiny, and the Supreme Chancellor's a shoe-in for any deck.

But it's his skill in the Senate that makes Valorum a top choice for any deck. While in a Senate majority, he's a one-man Tarkin, with the power to cancel an opponent's battle destiny at any site, anywhere, any time, for only 1 Force. That's what I like to call sledgehammer politics. And it's all from the safety of the Galactic Senate, where Walkers and Sith Lords are strictly pooh-poohed.

Of course, Valorum's power comes with a price. You remember all those "baseless" accusations we heard about in the movie? Well, they're back with a vengeance. As long as your opponent has Force to spend, he can reduce Valorum's Politics infinitely. While this doesn't hinder Valorum when it comes to guerilla "votes" in the Senate, it does make controlling the Senate with him alone a risky proposition. Be prepared to back him up with other political figures, like Queen Amidala... or a certain future Supreme Chancellor...
IsPulled: Supreme Chancellor Valorum (V)
Combo:
Supreme Chancellor Valorum + General Solo + Chewbacca: cancel two battle destiny? I'm there!
-----
Supreme Chancellor Valorum + Stay Here, Where It's Safe: Extra power, extra politics, and attrition immunity. No one is safe from Zod - er, Valorum!
Gametext: Agendas : justice, order. While in a senate majority, once per turn may use 2 Force to cancel a just drawn battle destiny at another site where you have a Republic character. Opponent may use X Force; Valorum is politics -X for remainder of turn.

Lore: Imperial troops with strict orders are often caught off-guard by innovative Rebel ambushes, sneak attacks, or sabotage efforts.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-15)
See Counter Assault.

(AR 1.7.1, B-4)
Counter Assault
The total power and number of destinies to be drawn is determined immediately when this Interrupt card begins resolving, and neither changes during the resolution. Thus if a character, starship or vehicle is introduced to the location during resolution of the Assault (such as via Tauntaun Bones) it does not add power and does not permit an additional destiny draw. Similarly, if cards are removed from the location during the resolution (such as by a Program Trap), they will still contribute power and still add a destiny draw for purposes of resolving the Counter Assault. This Interrupt does not cause a battle and thus cards may not be forfeited to reduce Force loss. Remember that, at a system location, characters and vehicles aboard starships are not present at the system. Therefore, for Counter Assault there will ordinarily only be one destiny draw per starship at the system but none for any cards aboard. Counter Assault may technically be played at a holosite but, since there are no characters present (only dejariks and holograms), no destiny will be drawn and zero will be compared to the opponent's total power.
Cancels: Surprise Assault may not be played when The Way Of Things on table.

The Light Side version of the Special Edition card Counter Surprise Assault is certainly a handy way to kick your Ewok deck into fast deploy!

Often an issue with "weenie decks" is that you take a bit longer to get enough into hand to deploy "safely". This usually translates to having to put more of the weenies in your deck, reducing room for other vital defences. Surprise Counter Assault will get your fuzzies our quick smart, and what's cheaper than free?

Use this to get your Ewok Tribesmen, Ewok Sentries and Ewok Spearmen onto Endor in large quantities. Equally useful in an Ewok based Endor Booster Draft deck, as lesser quantities available in your Deck can often make them a little harder to find when you need them.

Lore: After working together for a long time, Lando and Lobot developed a speechless form of communication.
Information:
Cloud City is flooded with cards that work as teamwork cards do, but with different effects. The only true requirement to these cards is, they must be played where two "mains" are present. This adds to the popularity and strength of the main characters as a whole, especially for the Dark Side.

Surreptitious Glance is easy to play with, simply because of Lobot's deployment restrictions. Chances are, he's going to appear where Lando is. With Surreptitious Glance, you can duplicate Tarkin's ability with Vader, canceling your opponent's destiny draw. The advantage is obvious. The Light Side has an edge, though. Kal'Falnl C'ndros lets you (semi-reliably) cancel your opponent's draws, since the Light Side tends to have better destiny draws. Unfortunately, recent rulings have weakened Kal when she is present with Tarkin. Captain Han Solo forces your opponent to re-draw a destiny. Understand, he might just draw a better destiny!

You can use Surreptitious Glance as a safety net should any of these strategies fail. Saving this card for when you truly need it tests your patience, but you can't wait too long, as Lando and Lobot tend to die faster than other mains.

It's sub-text also makes it extremely useful, cancelling the Dark Side version of Echo Base Operations, Dark Deal, which is ordinarily extremely hard to counter.
Cancels:
One opponent's destiny draw.
Dark Deal
Gametext: If Lobot and your Lando are in a battle together, cancel one opponent's destiny draw immediately after it is revealed. OR use 4 Force to cancel Dark Deal.

Lore: It's the bottom of the ninth level of Cloud City. Vader steps up to the platform. Here's the delivery. . . oooh, he took a big cut there! The Force sure wasn't with him on that one!
Information:
This card can be used to augment the strength of the Light Side players characters during ground battles. It can be used in a variety of different defensive situations, and is a Used Interrupt. This can be a nice advantage as many of the cards that it cancels by title are Dark Side Lost Interrupts. It is also a nice advantage to have the defense from lightsabers recur throughout the course of the game.

With the addition of a couple more relatively high ability Light Side character cards in Cloud City, subtracting one destiny from the total of a lightsaber draw may go a long way to making the Light Side safe from marauding Dark Side saber users. Also, since Swing-And-A-Miss has three dots, it may be played at three separate times throughout the course of a turn, protecting from lightsaber swings as well as some of the Dark Side's nastier battle related interrupts from the Cloud City set.

In battle heavy Cloud City playtesting, this card led to one of my favorite exchanges of quotes as the Dark Side player used Mostly Armless accompanied by the Pythonian quote "Your arms off", to which the Light player responded "No it isn't," when they played Swing-And-A-Miss.
Rules: This Interrupt subtracts from the total weapon destiny for a lightsaber, not from an individual destiny draw.

Information:
Suppose you have General Veers in your hand and you're playing on Hoth. Use Tactical Support to bring three Stormtroopers into your hand. Deploy General Veers and the Stormtroopers, and for three Force you've just given yourself a power of 9 and a bunch of forfeit. The trick with Tactical Support is to do it before you activate any Force so that way you don't have to worry about your troopers being in your Force pile instead. The fact that you have to lose a force to use it isn't great, but I think it's a fair trade, especially if you make sure you lose from your hand so you don't end up losing a key character.

Information: This card can be useful in constructed, but also strong in an Endor Booster draft. To use this card to its fullest in draft takes a commitment to draft scouts. This usually means drafting mostly Rebels since most Endor Rebels are scouts. Also, doing this reduces your reliance on Ewoks and makes the opponent's cards which target Ewoks a little less effective. The more common use for this interrupt is the Used portion. Adding up to 6 attrition can really help clear out the site, especially in draft where the opponent is likely to have low forfeit characters. The lost version can also be useful. You can use it to save an undercover spy from a Bubo attack to get one more turn of blocking drains, or if not all your ability is from scouts and spies, you can use it to add a few more power in battle either increasing damage for your opponent or saving you a few cards.

Lore: Male Elom. Former spy for the Rebellion. Hired by the Alliance to carry messages between Alderaan and the Rebel base on Yavin 4.
Information: Tanus Spijek is a card that allows the Light Side an opportunity to use Alderaan for its own benefit. His text for the +1 Force drain bonus at the Alderaan system for each Yavin 4 site you control is simple to use because there are a decent amount of Light Side Yavin 4 sites, and most are without Dark Side icons, which serves two purposes. This allows the Light player to accumulate Force without supplying the Dark player with much and it keeps most Dark characters away. However, spies should not worry you.
IsPulled: Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control).
Combo:
Tanus Spijek + Double Agent
-----
Our Most Desperate Hour + Tatooine System + 3+ Ability Characters
Since you're already playing the Alderaan system, why not use it to your advantage. Captain Han in the Falcon works well in pulling this one off, plus you can avoid all the nasty stuff down below by remaining in space and on Yavin 4. One of the easiest ways to retrieve Force.

Death Star Docking Bay + Death Star Trash Compactor + Death Star Plans + A Droid
Fairly simple to pull off since you're playing all the Yavin 4 sites. Simple cards like Tunnel Vision or Hiding In The Garbage will help you get those Death Star sites.

Kessel System + Kessel Run + A Smuggler
OK, I like to retrieve Force. A Force drain for three may be easier than usual because many Dark players are focused on capturing at sites with Bounty Hunters. Deploy another ship to the Alderaan system where Captain Han is hovering in the Falcon and send him to Kessel.

Effective Repairs + Utinni Effects
Not only does it cancel the annoying Limited Resources, but this card also allows you to retrieve any Utinni Effect into your hand, which is what all those precious Force retrieval cards just happen to be.

Tanus Spijek doesn't actually play much of a part in the Force retrieval, but after reading his card I came up with all of this. The few card which his game text makes essential for a deck around him is so nicely complimented by the Force retrieval opportunities. This deck has already won a couple times for me and is a lot of fun to play. Your opponent begins to become angry the third or fourth time you've successfully retrieved your entire Lost Pile! If you're still worried about Dark Side spies popping up or other ways for the Dark player to infiltrate Yavin 4, a card like Houjix is excellent in case you get totally taken by surprise and majorly overpowered in a battle, but the deck is character-heavy and those high destinies on the Force retrieval cards will serve you well in firing weapons and battle destinies.
Gametext: When at a Yavin 4 site, adds 1 to your Force drains at Alderaan system for each Yavin 4 site you control. While at Audience Chamber, all your other Elom are power and forfeit +1.

X = ability of one of AT-AT's pilots.
Y = total Hoth sites you control.

Rules:
Bluff Rules

Bluff rules means that the Dark Side may place "bluff cards" (a card from hand) at the Tatooine: Bluffs site. Thus, Revolution, Expand The Empire, or canceling the
game text of only one side of this site has no effect; the Light Side cannot bluff, and the Dark Side may not bluff at other sites.

Once during each of your turns (at any time) you may place a bluff card face down under the Bluffs site. Each bluff card cumulatively adds 1 to your total Force drain at that site. During your deploy phase, your opponent can choose to flip over any of your bluff cards:
If it is a character or vehicle, you may attempt to deploy it (deploy cost = 0) to the Bluffs using normal rules of deployment (obeying uniqueness, deployment restrictions [including having presence or Force icons], etc.).

If it is not one of those cards, or you could not legally deploy it there, you lose 2 Force and the bluff card.

LightSideText: "Bluff Rules" in effect here.

This non-unique location's game text prevents characters with landspeed less than 2 from moving away; however, it does not affect the movement of vehicles or other kinds of movement such as shuttling, landing and taking off. Information: The first non-unique site, the Desert increases further the vast wasteland that is the Tatooine Desert. The vast nature of the desert can be used as an effective deterrent for the Dark side if he is attempting to reach Jabba's Palace or Obi-Wan's Hut from Mos Eisley. Also, 2 Deserts make for incredibly slow travel, and can be extremely annoying in conjunction with sites such as the Light Side Jundland Wastes.

Information:
Since the Dawn Of Time (or at least the Premiere release), Tatooine: Jundland Wastes has been the best starting location for the Dark Side in sealed deck competition. Now each Light Side player gets a chance to bounce that evil site back to the Dark Side player's Reserve Deck.

The Light Side Jundland Wastes also gives a Force drain bonus when a Vaporator is played there. This provides a boost when combining with other cards often found in Premiere packs for sealed-deck competition.

In constructed-deck play, this site becomes an effective weapon to fight a ground-based, Tatooine Force drain strategy. The ability to convert the site and capitalize on its own Force drain bonus lets the Light Side grab the initiative.

Information:
Tatooine: Mos Eisley is the cornerstone for a Tatooine ground Force drain deck. The key to this strategy is to stay away from the Dark Side ground forces while continuing to force drain. Eventually, an opportunity usually presents itself to make a crippling counter-attack. This site, when combined with Tatooine: Cantina, form a strong site combination.

Of primary importance is the ability to move Light Side characters for free during the control phase. This affords the Light Side player a number of large strategic advantages. First, this provides excellent force generation and Force drain opportunities. That the Dark Side gains some force generation is somewhat negated by the fact that they will have to play a sufficient Force at both sites to force a battle. With the Tatooine: Mos Eisley game text, avoiding the Dark Side task force is free, while the Dark Side player must pay to chase from site to site. The Light Side player can keep her entire force strong and protected at one location and still Force drain at both sites. If the Dark Side has no presence at either site, and the Light Side has at least two characters deployed at one of the sites, just move one character to the second site, execute both Force drains, and then move the rest of the characters over. Keep in mind that this counts as their movement for the turn.
To completely halt the force drains, the Dark Side will have to split her forces between the two sites. When it is advantageous, the Light Side player can use the free move in the control phase to move her whole Force over and attack immediately.

Two types of cards will augment this deck greatly. First, the Light Side player must keep the Dark Side from deploying and immediately initiating a battle. Narrow Escape and Rebel Barrier can both help with this, and the A NEw Hope cards I Have a Very Bad Feeling About This and R2-D2 with a Fire Extinguisher work as well. If the battle does start, Houjix can keep the results from being crippling by eliminating force loss. Lightsabers and Lightsaber Proficiency increase the Force drain at the sites, also a key. Quite a Mercenary will keep the Dark Side from launching a surprise attack via Elis Helrot. Include multiple Tatooine: Mos Eisley to keep them from being reversed.

Cards to watch out for: Dark Side Tatooine: Mos Eisley, Counter Assault.

So, stack your characters on one of those two sites to better withstand a battle, then on your control phase move some of them over to the other, drain at both, and then move the ones you didn't move yet to re-consolidate your forces.

Circus Maximus. Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Tatooine: Podrace Arena. What do they have in common? SPEEEED! And what greater way to drive like a madman than podracing at the Podrace Arena?

But if you want your deck to speed up on podracing, don't forget to pack Start Your Engines! and a Podracer to get a jump start. Sebulba's Podracer is a fan favorite, but don't preclude Teemto Pagalies' Podracer, which can race pretty well on its own too.

Check out the Light Side version of the Podrace Arena for a few additional tips!

But don't forget the game text of the site. It is a great way to hide your weaker characters for the first few turns. You can deploy support characters such as Mirax Terrik or Leesub Sirln to help you manipulate your deck or do some direct damage to your opponent. Just watch out for local indigenous creatures like Bubo.

Information:
Not the greatest of locations judging by the Force icons, but looks are deceiving as they say. If you are heavily into podracing, this site can be a great boon. As long as you control the site, you can swap a card once every turn at just about anytime. So, now you can purposely lose high destiny cards and switch them as soon as you lose it.

But to get better use of this site, you should use Entering The Arena. Not only will the interrupt fetch the site, it will help you keep the site clear of any opposing forces. Also, since Entering The Arena has high destiny, it would be ideal to swap it with the top race destiny to ensure that you win the race.

Information:
Cool! Another 2/0 site like Obi-Wan's Hut for Tatooine! With "Shmi's Hut" you can get her out to quickly set up for Threepio With His Parts Showing. Although both characters are not very strong, their strength lies in their game text.

One good use of another 0 Dark Side Force icon location is to set up Tatooine so that you can control where the actions take place. By placing locations in a certain order, you can make Tatooine into a rat trap for the Dark Side. You can put one battleground in between the Slave Quarters and Obi-Wan's Hut. Doing so will force the opponent to deploy to the middle and if they try to escape, you can nab them at either non-battleground with less fear of a counterattack. Another way is to put both Slave Quarters and Obi-Wan's Hut together to create a partial haven for utility characters (e.g., Figrin D'an or Oola).

Information:
Expanding on the already-sprawling planet of Tatooine, Tusken Canyon helps a Sealed Deck game in a number of ways, as well as opening up interesting options in standard Swiss play.

First, in Sealed Deck, the Gaderffii Stick is now a card to be reckoned with, giving a drain of three at a site. It also expands on the capabilities of Tusken Raiders in Sealed Deck.

In a non-Sealed Deck game, this site provides an additional Force drain location, while not giving your opponent too much Force. Combined with a Trooper strategy, Tusken Raiders can be fearsome, giving an immense amount of power in 4 characters. Add in a few Gaderffii Sticks to increase this site's Force drain and make this group even deadlier.

If your opponent threatens to kill Vader or one of the Raiders, simply knock away his weapon as quickly as possible. Add in Snipers to take care of Undercover spies, and you have a fairly stable Force drain.

Lore: Trade Federation-owned protocol droid used by the Neimoidians to distract the Jedi until a plan could be conceived to deal with them.
Information:
With the introduction of so many new Light Side Jedi, the Dark Side needs everything it can muster to deal with these powerful characters. TC-14 makes things tough on them in a couple of different ways, and should join IG-88, 4-LOM, U-3P0 and the new Destroyers as one of the most versatile droids in the Dark side arsenal.

Most of the Jedi choose to stay within the comfy confines of the Council Chamber where they are best able to use their game text. You can still expect to see others, like Mace and Ki-Adi-Mundi, join the ranks of the existing heavy hitters (like Luke, Obi, and Qui-Gon) on the front lines of battle in cameo support roles.

When TC-14 joins your forces against one or more Jedi, your opponent will be faced with two choices when it is their turn. Stay, and put their strong Force-wielding hero at risk, or run away (at a cost of 3 Force each). If they decide to stick it out, TC-14 can be sacrificed (during EITHER player's control phase) to make the Jedi of your choice vulnerable and weak.

The ability to turn Jedi Luke from an 8 to a 0, where even a destiny draw of 1 can take him out, is well worth TC-14's life.

Lore: Ithorian senator. Called on by his people to represent them in the Senate, even though his heart is not in politics. Voted against the taxation of trade routes.
Information:
One of the bad things about Senators is that they tend to have low power when they're called upon to fight outside of the Senate. Not so with Tendau Bendon! This little Ithorian Senator is handy both in the political arena and in the knock-down, drag-out brawl of the SWCCG universe at large. With 3 power and 4 forfeit for only 2 Force, he's a bargain anywhere.

But lots of Light Side characters have similar stats, and Bendon's Politics is a less-than-impressive 2. So why use him? Because he's a walking Reactor Terminal, that's why! While Bendon's in a senate majority, you can place your hand - no matter how large - in your Used Pile to draw up to four cards from your Reserve Deck. If you need a new hand, need to reduce your hand size, or just need to increase your differential to top off a tournament win, Tendau Bendon is your man.

He's also an integral part of any "Senate Invasion Package," along with Valorum, Amidala, and other Senators who can fight both inside and outside of the Senate. Once an opponent's political dreams are dashed, Bendon is a handy way to keep recycling any duplicate Senators you may have back into your deck while constantly drawing new resources. New cards, extra Life Force, Politics and power?

Information: Tessek's game text is very useful in that, over time, he pays for himself. Chances are your opponent is going to play as many as three or four 1-destiny characters. After 3, he's paid for himself, and you begin to bring a profit from his text. His ability to add to Force drains as well as reduce deploy costs can be extremely helpful, especially if you spread out across multiple planets. Most decks aren't prepared to handle a battle on many fronts, unless they use Elis Helrot. With Quite A Mercenary, you can nail quite a few characters. Make sure you have a weapon to fool him into thinking you're saving the Force for something else, though, or have All Wrapped Up on the table.

First, while you have The Camp out, your opponent will be less likely to activate a high amount of Force on turn 2 like in the past. No more camping at non-battleground docking bays with some cheap characters using the Imperial Arrest Order + Mobilization Points combo. If they want to, they must pay the price... occupy or control a battleground docking bay instead. Some will say that this will hurt decks like Ralltiir Operations, but that deck worked fine without that combo, and note that it affects both players. This card puts the "Wars" back in Star Wars. :)

Second, this card mitigates the bonuses the Dark Side reaps with Scum And Villany. Alien base decks can still be popular but they won't get the nearly free deploy that they used to get. Most aliens will end up costing what is printed on the card, but they should stay far away from the Jedi since that is Maul's and Vader's department.

Personas - Palpatine, Sidious, And The Emperor
While in the saga of Star Wars we learn that the Emperor, Senator Palpatine, and Darth Sidious are one in the same, for game purposes they are treated as three distinct people. They will be referred to as Emperor, Palpatine, and Sidious, respectively.
Gametext: Deploys only to Coruscant or Death Star II. Never moves to a site occupied by opponent (even if carried). If Vader or Xizor here, and Luke is not on table, adds 2 to attrition against opponent at other locations. Immune to attrition.

Lore: Vader thought that by capturing Luke, he would crush the Alliance's last hope. But, there was another...
Information:
When a slam-bang card like The Emperor's Prize comes along, jaws drop. It will hack off half your opponent's Force, unless it takes you so long to pull it off that there's not much left. So speed it up. You'll find the cards you need to inflict massive damage in most Bounty or Carbon Freezing decks.

First, get Docking Bay Control Room into play. It lets you spit out every Docking Bay in your deck, including those for Cloud City and the Death Star.

Starting with the Detention Block Corridor or Carbonite Chamber is good too.

Second, weasel your opponent into playing Luke. Play Mii'yoom Onith and conveniently forget to use her for a couple of turns. See if your opponent puts Luke out. Or start early with a Scanning Crew philosophy, and see if that brings Luke out to play. When Luke is on the table, the number one rule is: don't kill him unless you have a We Have A Prisoner in your hand. You can afford to take some losses in this effort, you'll be doing a whole lot more later on.

Third, get Luke frozen. Whether this means jacking up a Force drain at the Carbonite Chamber, and then pushing him in with All Too Easy, or going the long route and capturing him, and then Carbon Freezing him, Luke has to be frozen.

Fourth, and this is what you have to stock up for, put out the Prize, and make sure it and the frozen Luke are well protected. Make sure you have a steady stream of characters escorting Luke so that he's never alone. He'll be frozen for the rest of the game, but you don't want your opponent piling up with him. You'll also want to keep pesky rebels out of the Detention Block Corridor. This will make your life a whole lot easier.

This card's problem is actually getting Luke to the Detention Block Corridor after he's Frozen. There just isn't too much mobility in the game for interior sites, except for the card that could save your life. Lift Tube is a Premiere common that rarely sees use, but, if your plans are centered around the two systems with mobile sites, Lift Tubes can be invaluable. It can carry four passengers, more than enough for Luke and some protection, and, since both docking bays are Mobile sites, it can move through the Docking Bay, although you shouldn't need it on the Death Star.

After that, you're set. Half of your opponent's Life Force is gone, and you'll have a nice little force with which to Force drain. It seems like a very hefty task, and it will probably take up most of your time simply trying to pull it off. Once you do, however, you notice quickly that is was all worthwile.

We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Combo:

Not only do you deal massive amounts of damage, but you also retrieve a hefty amount of Force as well. As long as Vader is nearby, which he should be if you want to keep Luke unharmed, you can regain a lot of the loss that you'll take in setting up this combination.
Gametext: If Luke was just 'frozen,' deploy on Emperor or Detention Block Corridor. Target Luke and Vader. When reached by targets, place Utinni Effect on Luke and opponent must lose half of Life Force (round down). If Luke released, lose Utinni Effect. (Immune to Alter.)

If you can drop someone with a taxation agenda here (Horox Ryyder or Yarua), then on your turn you can recycle a card to force your opponent to use 1 or lose 1 (opponent's choice). That's a nasty way to remind the Dark player to save some Force during your turn or pay the penalty.

Players will compare this to the Light Side counterpart Our Only Hope (from the DSII set) but there is a subtle difference. Note that the Lost part of this card has no special restrictions like Our Only Hope. Lore: "You like me because I'm a scoundrel. There aren't enough scoundrels in your life." "I happen to like nice men." "I'm a nice man." "No you're not, you're ..."
Information:
Don't you just hate it when your opponent draws a Battle Destiny of 1 and it forces you to lose a great character like Lando? Well, now you can virtually give all your characters an immunity to attrition with the Used Interrupt: This Is More Like It.

Although it makes you still lose Force to reduce attrition against you, at least you can protect an important character or even group of characters and have them around for future battles. In many games that I have played, I'm certain that the outcome would have been different if I had a particular character around for just one more turn.

Besides this excellent use, it has a secondary use as well...it cancels This Is Just Wrong. Two uses in one card is great, especially since there are so many cards and only 60 card deck sizes.
Combo:
This Is More Like It + Obi-Wan OR Son of Skywalker OR Princess Leia OR anyone else with a minor immunity to attrition: Reduce any excess attrition just enough to protect your heroes.

This Is More Like It + Any other valuable characters: If the attrition against you is minimal, you can eliminate it totally.

This Is More Like It + Courage of a Skywalker + Luke OR Leia: Give yourself a power boost, and if your opponent causes any attrition upon your now un-immune Skywalker, who cares? :)

This Is More Like It + Force Retrieval cards: Get the Force back that you lost from This Is More Like It via On/Off the Edges, Death Star Plans, Kessel/Rycars Runs, Reflection, etc.

The golden droid has finally secured himself a new persona! Threepio is built for Endor and Ewoks, but is handy anywhere in a pinch. Just like the real droid!

For one thing, he makes a host of you mains immune to the deploy costs of Bad feeling Have I on the same planet. Captain Han Solo, Lando Calrissian, Princess Leia, Princess Leia Organa, Tamtel Skreej, General Solo, Daughter of Skywalker and Chewbacca of Kashyyyk. Theres got to be something in there that takes your fancy!

His "go to Used Pile" ability is dovetailed from his role in the movies - although Threepio seemed to always be in sticky situations, his good fortune seemed to always hold up! As far as the Imperials were concerned, he was impossible to kill! And at forfeit 5, sending him to the Used Pile may just save most of your other characters at the site.

Lore: Protocol Droid designed by Anakin in order to help his mother. C-3PO was not to be sold when Anakin left with Qui-Gon Jinn for Coruscant.
Information:
C-3PO personas are:

Artoo & Threepio
C-3PO (See-Threepio)
See-Threepio
Threepio
Threepio With His Parts Showing
-----
The Episode 1 version of Threepio is a great card for anyone who likes to have full control over their deck. Threepio shares Mirax Terrik's ability to circulate high destiny cards back into your deck and replace them with new cards from the Reserve Deck. What's even nicer about Threepio's ability is that, unlike Mirax, his ability can be used for free, and instead of placing the card on the bottom of the Used Pile, he places it on the top of the Used Pile for easier tracking when your Reserve Deck is larger.

The other nice thing about Threepio's ability to place a high destiny card on top of your Used Pile is that if he's in a battle with Shmi, he can then take that high destiny card and place it on top of your Reserve Deck, ensuring a nice pull for weapon or battle destiny. And since Shmi can download Threepio right out of the Reserve Deck, the odds of you having them in a battle together are pretty good.

The fact that this is a persona of C-3PO also has enormous benefits. Because most versions of C-3PO have only been strong in specialized decks, many of his support cards are quite powerful. For example, Were You Looking For Me? is a handy 5 Destiny Used Interrupt that allows you to pull Threepio and/or another protocol droid (like R-3PO) from your Reserve Deck. You can also use the same Interrupt as a Lost Interrupt to either retrieve Threepio from the Lost Pile or to add a battle destiny when Threepio is helping his friends out in battle (two battle destiny if he happens to have a few furry friends with him). Unlike most "back" cards, this card is very appealing because it's recyclable, free, high destiny, and has the battle destiny bonus.

There are tons of other C-3PO suppport cards, including the ever-popular How Did We Get Into This Mess?, but one of my favorites is Artoo, I Have A Bad Feeling About This, which has three different uses, the best of which allows you to squash your opponent's battle destiny completely if both Artoo and C-3PO are together in battle. Put Shmi, Artoo and Threepio together in a battle, and with the right support cards you can really put the hurt on the Dark Side.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, D-2)
Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex).
Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows:
- You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title.
- If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost).
- Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.
Gametext: While at a Tibrin site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is forfeit +1 (and power +1 if your Ishi Tib is on Tibrin) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Tibrin from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Lore: Anakin needed all the help he could get to evade Sebulba's tactics.
Information:
This interrupt is a great alternative to Put That Down from the Cloud City set. While it doesn't guarantee the ability to cancel a weapon from targeting one of your characters, this version is much cheaper - it's free! Instead of having you use 3 Force, you make your opponent use 2 Force or they missed with their weapon.

As an added bonus, you can also use it to prevent your opponent from using tricks like Hit Racer or Podracer Collision while your Podracer attempts to take the checkered flag.
IsPulled: We Wish To Board At Once
Combo: Too Close For Comfort + Put That Down: A bit excessive, but this will really frustrate your opponent when they use 2 Force and miss regardless.
Cancels:
Hit Racer
Podracer Collision
Gametext: USED: If your character was just targeted by a weapon, opponent must use 2 Force or the targeting is canceled. LOST: Cancel Hit Racer or Podracer Collision.

Lore: Massive cargo vessels that were converted by the Trade Federation into armed battleships. Each is equipped with a large contingent of droid starfighters and battle droids.
Information:
The Trade Federation Battleship is the standard capital ship in the Trade Federation fleet. Its solid stats include a healthy power, armor, and forfeit.
With four empty pilot slots to fill, this ship can quickly become a juggernaut when piloted by Neimoidian Pilots or "classic trilogy" pilots like Danz Borin.
With space to carry 4 starfighters, the Trade Federation Battleship can easily transport its own armada of Droid Starfighters. This combination of ships is further encouraged by the deploy bonus Droid Starfighters get when they deploy at the same system as a battleship.

The Trade Federation Battleship benefits from these starfighters by drawing a battle destiny if unable to otherwise when present with a fighter. This text comes in handy when you have a squadron of Droid Starfighters that lack the ability to draw destiny on their own.
Combo:
Trade Federation Battleship + Naboo + Neimoidian Pilots
Neimoidian Pilots deploy free and activate 1 Force each time they deploy. How often do you have more active Force after your deploy phase than before?
-----
Trade Federation Battleship + Droid Starfighters + Battle Deployment
Each player's ships are power -2 at systems where he doesn't have both a capital ship and a starfighter. Since Trade Federation Battleships and Droid Starfighters are meant to go together, you already have that covered. Does your opponent?
-----
Trade Federation Battleship + Sil Unch
Gametext: May add 4 pilots, 4 passengers, 2 vehicles, and 4 starfighters. Has ship-docking capability. Permanent pilot provides ability of 1. While with any starfighter, draws one battle destiny if unable to otherwise.

Lore: These heavily modified battleships are used to control and direct the Trade Federation automated army. Easily identified by its array of sensors and antennae.
Information:
This unique ship... wait a second, let's look at that card again! This ship isn't unique. Instead, the diamond-shaped symbol before the title indicates that the Trade Federation Droid Control Ship is limited to one copy per system. Previously, these markings have mostly appeared on locations. Indeed, this is the first ship to use this icon.

The numbers on Trade Federation Droid Control Ship compare favorably with the non-unique Trade Federation Battleship. Its power and forfeit are reduced by 1, but this reduction is balanced by the increased armor, ability, and the reduced deploy cost.

The Droid Control Ship is crucial for the proper functioning of the Trade Federation's droid starfighters, reflected by both the power penalty the droid starfighters suffer when not present with this important ship as well as the deploy bonus they receive when deploying to the same system. Needless to say, it is recommended that your droid starfighters stay close to this ship.

Deploy the Laser Cannon Battery aboard to not only hit your opponent's ships, but cause a 1 Force loss to direct damage when you do so. Add Imperial Artillery to add another Force loss, either during your Control phase or after successfully hitting a ship with the Battery (or both, since Imperial Artillery can be used twice per turn!). Deploy the Neimoidian Pilot aboard (for free at Naboo) and activate an extra Force when doing so. Tey How can also make herself useful here, giving you the ability to reduce Force lost to drains at nearby parsecs.
Combo:
Federation Droid Control Ship + Neimodian Pilot + Tey How + Droid Starfighter
Power 12 plus 2 battle destiny. Add a few more pilots and/or ships to maintain control of a system while Tey How reduces your Force loss to drains at systems within 2 parsecs.
-----
Federation Droid Control Ship + Sil Unch
Gametext: May add 4 pilots, 4 passengers, 2 vehicles, and 4 starfighters. Permanent pilot provides ability of 2. Has ship-docking capability. While a droid starfighter here, adds one battle destiny.

Lore: Lutrillian. Primary saleswoman and executive planner for Planet Dreams, Inc. Monitors production schedules and accounting. Really enjoys making a sales pitch.
Combo:
Treva Home + Draw Their Fire
If you have a deck which is designed around setting up big beatdowns (eg. with Jedi Presence and supporting cards like Courage of a Skywalker), Treva is your most effective way of stopping your opponent using Ghhhk to avoid the battle damage when combined with Draw Their Fire. The other methods of achieving this result - Frozen Assets and Beggar - are each canceled by the Fanfare shield, so Treva is probably the best way to abuse Draw Their Fire in this way. (Psychobabble)
Gametext: During your control phase, may 'sell' one Interrupt card from hand. Opponent must use X Force, where X = destiny of that card or entire Force Pile (opponent's choice). Place sold card on opponent's Used Pile and activate X Force.

Play Sabacc to get cards in their used pile, then the other 2 Interrupts to make them lose force/other cards. (maxbeedo)
Gametext: If there are cards in the opponent's Used Pile during your battle phase, draw one destiny. All cards there with the same destiny number are lost.

Lore: An assault of stormtroopers caused Leia, Chewie and Lando to retreat. When working together, the troopers' powerful onslaught can appear unstoppable.
Information:
This card gives a shot in the arm to trooper decks. With this card and a couple of little tricks can allow troopers to be competitive in a number of different environments. Of course, the key to this deck is protecting the Trooper Assaults from Sense. Seven or eight Controls and a couple of Tentacles might be the advisable course of action for this mission.

This deck can revolve around the classic Force drain locations such as the Moisture Farm, Judland Wastes, Cantina and Defensive Perimeter. Control of the location can be established with about 4 Imperial Trooper Guards. With a Trooper Assault in hand, these guys are power 24 and immune to attrition. If more characters show up for the Light Side, a few more guards can be thrown into the mix and they all add six power each.

This is great for defending these locations, but of course doesn't do much for the attack. This is where another card can come in handy. Deploy Trooper Davin Felth or an Imperial Squad Leader and give them a Light Repeating Blaster Rifle and a power source. Blasted Droid will then allow the trooper to fire the LRBR with a destiny bonus pretty much until the Dark Side runs out of Reserve Deck. If the power source is a Portable Fusion Generator and the trooper is at the Moisture Farm or Defensive Perimeter, all of the shots will be at weapon destiny + three. Even Obi-Wan is fairly likely to run into a 4 destiny Trooper Assault from the Reserve Deck, wiping him out. And since the Imperial Trooper Guards are destiny 3, Son Of Skywalker can be hit when they are drawn using the LRBR add all of it's adders. Again, this combination needs protection from Sense.
Gametext: If a battle was just initiated at a site, each of your troopers present is power +2 and immune to attrition for remainder of turn.

Lore: Imperial troopers are fearless and totally indoctrinated. Backed by the most powerful weapons and starships in the galaxy, they tend to consider themselves invincible.

Lore: Dispatched to Tatooine to apprehend renegade droids fleeing the Tantive IV. Suspected to have misgivings about Imperial methods. Allegedly shot his commander in the back.
IsPulled: Blizzard 4
Gametext: While he is on Tatooine, Local Trouble and Look Sir, Droids are Used Interrupts. Opponent may select target when using Friendly Fire at same site as Felth.

Lore: Corrupt captain of the Cloud City Wing Guard. Began working during the administration of Baron Raynor. Easily bribed. Keeps the peace through intimidation.
Information:
He looks pretty weak...after all, your opponent can make Blendin not battle just by using two Force. And, admittedly, you probably don't want Blendin to be the focus of your deck, because of his unreliability. But Trooper Jerrol Blendin can help you make a few key moves and give you the advantage you need.

The first thing to look at is Blendin's deploy cost -- he doesn't have one! That isn't a bad thing. And, if you initiate battle, he gets +2 power (4 total). He can be great for catching an opponent who doesn't keep anything in his Force Pile. For zero Force you can get +4 power in a battle and, effectively, increase the damage to your opponent by four. And, when the battle's over, you can forfeit Blendin to ensure that you don't get burned by his detrimental game text.
Combo:
Blendin + Trooper Assault + Trooper Charge : Power *8* if you initiate the battle, all at the cost of zero Force! Makes a great surprise for your opponent in a 'react' deck.

Blendin + Lone Warrior : Leave him alone at a site and give him defensive cards. Then, if your opponent chooses not to let him participate in a battle, the battle is just cancelled.
Gametext: Deploys only on Cloud City, but may move elsewhere. Power +2 when participating in a battle you initiate. Opponent may use 2 Force to 'bribe' (exclude) Blendin from battle.

Lore: Sabacc is a popular pastime for off-duty Imperial stormtroopers throughout the galaxy.
Gametext: Requirements: A gambler or trooper at a site. Wild cards (2-7): Imperial and Rebel leaders. (Troopers may use weapons as wild cards.) Clone cards: Locations and droids. Stakes: One transport vehicle without armor or one character weapon.

Lore: Troopers stationed at various outposts play this sabacc variant to pass the time between assignments.
Gametext: Requirements: A gambler or trooper at a site. Wild cards (2-7): Imperial and Rebel leaders. (Troopers may use weapons as wild cards.) Clone cards: Locations and droids. Stakes: One transport vehicle without armor or one character weapon.

Lore: Imzig Cloud City trooper and Wing Guard leader. Attempts to protect Cloud City citizens from less reputable members of local constabulary. Never accepts a bribe.
Information:
Looking for a boost for that Lobot Cloud City Trooper deck? Make sure you have Trooper Utris M'Toc stocked in your deck, ready to serve.

Trooper Utris M'Toc is a power 2 ability 2 character with a destiny of 2. If Lobot is present at a site, M'Toc would deploy for free as a Cloud City trooper. He also deploys free to the same site as Lando. This works with either the Dark Lando or even the Light Lando, so it could be an effective way to ambush the Dark Side Lando. He is power +2 when defending a battle, so that could be a nasty surprise for the Dark Side if they choose to attack. When present with M'Toc, all of your other Cloud City Troopers are forfeit +2, allowing you to suck up more damage in a fight.
-----
Your Cloud City Troopers deploy free and are power +1 at same site as Lobot at a Cloud City site.
-----

Cloud City Trooper
Sergeant Edian
Trooper Utris M'Toc

Although a small combat vehicle by power standards, these supply craft are designed to transport and unload mechanized forces. Thus lots of passenger capacity, and you can 'unload' a battle droid leader during each of your deploy phases. That gives you three choices with Theed Palace. OOM-9, the Battle Droid Officer, or the mighty OWO-1 With Backup. May be worth the investment!

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-16)
U-3PO's game text that adds his power to the light side is applied even though he is not participating in the battle and is inactive. This is a singular exception to the normal rules of undercover spies and participating in battle. If stolen while Undercover (e.g., by a Caller), U-3PO moves to your side of the location and becomes an Undercover spy for your opponent. The Light Side player may choose to not accept this Dark side droid when its cover is broken, in which case it becomes a Dark Side non- Undercover droid.
Gametext: Deploy on opponent's side as an Undercover spy (except that if present during a battle at a site, adds its power to Light Side). If spy's "cover is broken," the above "game text" is canceled and Light Side may use as if stolen.

Lore: Ugnaught assigned to determine how to use carbon-freezing on humans. Placed in charge of the Ugnaught workers on Cloud City. Formerly enslaved by humans.
Information:
Here is another one of the Carbon-Freezing enhancers from Cloud City. This is the card that will allow the Dark Side to play with only three to five non-unique ugnaughts in their deck, and still have a relatively decent chance of pulling off freezing.

The power +2 bonus is nice, but not really why this character is on the table. Another small, but nice feature is that if pressed into service, Ugloste is a warrior that can be armed and sent out with a We Have A Prisoner in hand to go and do the capture work to get a potential freezing candidate. The bonus that he gives to the other Ugnaughts with him gives the Dark Side a decent chance of coming out of the battle without too much trouble. With the added bonus from Prepare The Chamber to battles, they may even be a force to be reckoned with.

The real advantage of this guy is that he doubles the additions by the Ugnaughts, making freezing a real possibility when taken in conjunction with other cards such as Prepare The Chamber and Carbonite Chamber Console.
IsPulled: Carbonite Chamber Console
Gametext: Power +2 at Trash Compactor, Droid Junkheap, Incinerator or Carbonite Chamber. Functions as a leader if present with another Ugnaught. Where present, other Ugnaughts are forfeit +2 and double their bonus to Carbon-Freezing destiny.

Lore: Cheap manual labor from Gentes in the Anoat system. Make up Cloud City's second largest population. Responsible for maintenance and menial chores throughout the city.
Information:
Here is an answer for everybody that wants to know how to draw more than 10 for Carbon-Freezing destiny. Much in the way that Death Star Gunners and Rebel Techs are necessary to make a Commence Primary Ignition or Attack Run deck go, these little guys are the key to making Rebels 'well preserved'. The Ugnaught advantage though, is that there are some other cards that allow them to play a more useful role.

Obviously, their prime purpose in the game is to pull off Carbon-Freezing. To do this, they each add one. Throw in Ugloste and this bonus just soars. What should not be overlooked is the ability to sacrifice a card to go and get a few things to facilitate the freezing process. This means that you can lose the key cards to the freezing process early, knowing that you can get them back later in the game. Get the Carbonite Chamber Console and not only do you get the bonus to freezing destiny, but suddenly more Ugnaughts, and even the Carbon-Freezing effect itself show up. Prepare The Chamber also helps both the destiny draw, and the Ugnaughts themselves.

Another advantage to these guys is that they can help outfit your bounty hunting crew. Who wouldn't lose two Force to give IG-88 a Light Repeating Blaster Rifle an a Portable Fusion Generator. Give him some Binders and he can do all the collection work for you. Also, with Ugloste, Ugnaughts provide a decent little fighting force on their own, especially with Prepare The Chamber.
Pulls:
On weapon from Lost Pile.
On device from Lost Pile.
IsPulled: Carbonite Chamber Console
Combo:
Ugnaughts + Prepare The Chamber + Carbonite Chamber Console + Ugloste
A guaranteed freezing draw.
-----
Ugnaughts + weapons + bounty hunters. These guys can serve as the ultimate armorers. You don't have to worry about hanging on to combinations of weapon cards until you actually have the warriors to use them.
Gametext: When at Carbonite Chamber, cumulatively adds 1 to each Carbon-Freezing destiny draw. During your control phase, may lose 1 Force from hand to search your Lost Pile and take one weapon or device into hand.

Information:
Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.

Ultimatum is arguably the most powerful card in the entire expansion. With the ability to force your opponent out into the open, decks can now be more focused on battling, rather than Force draining. The Light Side might be a little bit more prepared for this event, especially in space. With Captain Han and the Falcon, you can be prepared for just about any Dark side assault. On the ground, none match Son Of Skywalker's versatility. With a deck made for fighting, Ultimatum can be the key to bringing your opponent to you, rather than waiting for him.
IsPulled:
The Signal
We Wish To Board At Once
Combo:
Ultimatum in a Teamwork deck -- The ultimate fighting deck gets infinitely better with the addition of this equalizer. Not only can you drop a nasty surprise on your opponent in the form of multiple destiny adding interrupts, but you can weaken his strategy if he does not fall for you ruse. Either way, you have the advantage.

Ultimatum in an Asteroid Sanctuary deck -- Note that neither Resistance nor Ultimatum affect Asteroid Sanctuary in the slightest, giving the Asteroid Sanctuary deck a slight edge over its opponent, who is probably using either Force drain or inserts as a damage dealing strategy. Load up with Tentacles and Controls to stop Alter, and protect the Asteroids. Add Rycar's Run for some Force retrieval.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-16)
The text of this card comes into effect as an automatic action when you lose your second Force (and meet all other requirements of the card). For example, if you are being drained for 5 Force and you satisfy the battleground requirements of Ultimatum as well as having It Could Be Worse in hand and 2 Force saved. If you choose to play It Could Be Worse to reduce the Force loss by 2, you have not lost any Force to the drain, and must still lose 2 Force before Ultimatum will take effect (and you then will not have to lose any more Force).
Gametext: Deploy on your side of table. While you occupy at least 3 battlegrounds or opponent occupies no battlegrounds, you lose no more than 2 Force from each Force drain or 'insert' card. (Immune to Alter.)

Lore: The rage of the Dark Lord.
Information:
This card is a must in decks that intend to confront the Dark Side in a direct confrontation at sites. Uncontrollable Fury could also be useful at systems, but the benefits of Vader (especially when combined with Tarkin) are not quite as powerful at systems and sectors due to the fact the Light Side cannot lose the forfeit value of cards due to Vader and his lightsaber while in space.

Since the Premiere edition of the game, Light Side players have been searching for a way to counter the deadly combination of Grand Moff Tarkin and Darth Vader. Some solutions that have worked to one extent or another have been Demotion, Tarkin Seeker and playing space decks. An opinion that some top ranked players hold is that Vader is wasted in space when compared with his devastating effectiveness at sites. Uncontrollable Fury is another tool in this war. While there is a Dark Side card that can cancel it, the power of Uncontrollable Fury probably makes it more than worth the risk.

There are numerous avoidance strategies that can make use of the Force loss part of the card. The easiest of these is just to use Nabrun Leids to move away from Vader in each of the Dark Side's battle phases, and cause them to lose two Force per opponent's turn. Of course, that requires the Dark player to use Vader, but he is usually to good to pass up.

Lore: Vibrating blade powered by an energy cell hidden within the shaft. Used by many moisture farmers to prod banthas and other animals.
Information: The Vibro-Ax seems like a better card for the Dark Side at first. However, the edges that the Light Side has can make it just as deadly for the Light as the Dark. First, the Light Side has the highest power for ability alien in the game, in Chewbacca. Granted, Kitik Keed'kak has a higher power, because of his low ability and low Forfeit, he rarely, if ever makes it into play, especially for his massive deploy cost. Therefore, Chewie can reasonably swing a Vibro-Ax with impunity, with his power boosted marginally by the Ax, and when present with Han, his power becomes 8. Also, the Light Side has considerably better destiny than the Dark, making hitting with the Vibro-Ax even better.

Lore: "Vote now! Vote now! Vote now!"
Information:
Do you like drawing extra cards? Do you like recycling cards? If so, then this is the card for your Light Senator deck.
No matter whether the game just started, or it's almost over, this is never a bad card. Early on, you can play this and if you're lucky, you can draw some extra cards, but even if not, you've still recycled a 5. In the mid to late game when you may have set up some destinies, this can give you some guaranteed card draws, if you're in control of the senate. And what's even better, if you've somehow lost control of the Senate, you can still play it as a recyclable 5.

Lore: Security officer from Kiffex searching for the Tonnika sisters. In love with one of them, he's not sure which.
Information: Ok, all of the players who have played longer than a year raise your hands. Ok, all you players who have dealt with the horrific Tonnika Sisters raise your hands. Thought so. Despite the fact that the Tonnika Sisters came from way back when, they are still a headache to all Lightside players to date. Well, now it is the Light players turn. Enter, Vul Tazaenne. This guy is actually pretty good in the navy. As a starship pilot he can not only add 2 to the power of any starship he pilots but, can add 2 to any destiny of 2 for only 2 force, twice per battle. What that means in English is that the you can modify a battle significantly if you so choose. Not bad for a destiny 2 card with 2 ability.
Combo:
Vul Tazaenne + Red Leader in Red 1/Gold Leader in Gold 1 + 2 Landing Claws + Kiffex = The coolness of this is it's simplicity. This is not a 6 card combo, but a situation that you can prepare for. You will have the ability to drain for two at Kiffex while keeping a safe distance from your opponent. If they decide to battle you, hide. If you draw any of these cards for destiny, they are all a two's. Also, if you control Kiffex itself with the two starships, Vul will add 4 to all 4's. Not bad for a little 2 deploy character.

Vul Tazaene + Kiffex
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-16)
See Kiffex.

(AR 1.7.1, B-10)
Kiffex
While this system's game text "doubles" a character, it means that:
- Every printed number on that card is doubled (thus a 1 becomes a 2, a 2 becomes a 4, etc.)
- Every printed indication of number of uses is doubled (thus "once" becomes "twice," "twice" becomes "four times" etc.). Apply any additional modifiers and other effects to the new values (e.g., a doubled Tonnika Sisters with Mandalorian Armor is power = 6, and a Vul Tazaene that has competed Jedi Test 3 will be ability 4, not ability 6).
Cancels: If present with Tonnika Sisters, Vul and Tonnika Sisters are lost.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-16)
When capturing a just forfeited character using this Dark Side Effect, that character is captured after applying forfeit value but before being placed on the Lost Pile. When captured, the characters values that would normally be restored upon leaving table (e.g., forfeit being reduced by 2, power being reduced to 0) has those values reset. In this way, cards deployed on that character (for example, Bounty or a weapon) are not placed in the Lost Pile. Additionally, if the card was 'hit', it is no longer 'hit'. This is a specific exception to the just lost ruling.
This Interrupt's first function may capture a character lost or forfeited from a system or sector, if you have a potential escort available aboard a vehicle or starship at that location.
Gametext: Use 1 Force if opponent's character is about to be lost or forfeited from battle. It is captured instead (character is first restored to normal). OR Use X Force to capture all characters on board a captured starship, where X = twice the number of characters.
