Lore: Vader confiscated Han's blaster, his ship, his Wookiee, his girl and his only hope of escape.
Information:
When using this card as a Used Interrupt, you may search your Used Pile. Doesn't sound overly interesting. However, after deploying something like an Executor, or a normal star destroyer with pilots, you should have an interesting Used Pile. If you have plenty weapons in your deck, chances are good that you find a weapon there. This is also a very strong point, as you can take ONE weapon. It does not specify which weapon. Find a Superlaser there ? Take it. Vader needs his custom slice-toy and it's in the Used Pile ? Pick out Vader's Lightsaber and take it into your hand. Want to arm that star destroyer ? Weapon Levitate the Turbolaser Battery or Ion Cannon you see in your Used Pile. The possibilities are only limited by the weapons in your deck.

There is another use, the Lost Interrupt variant. For fun I'll give an example which actually happened. I had an unarmed Darth Vader at a site. Here comes Obi-Wan with a generic Jedi Lightsaber (his own toy was not deployed yet). Obi starts to battle and suddenly he feels the lightsaber wrenched from his grip, sees it flying through the room and into Darth Vaders hands. The last thing Obi-Wan ever saw, was Darth Vader slicing him with Obi's own surrogate toy.

In the game, Obi-Wan started the battle and I played Weapon Levitation as a Lost Interrupt. I snatched the Jedi Lightsaber and, as it can be used by any warrior, used it to slice Obi-Wan to ribbons. However, things get a little more interesting. The game text states, that you may 'steal' one character weapon present. OK, so you will not run off with a Planet Defender Ion Cannon. However, did you see Luke waving his Blaster Pistol (and you fear he will target you, to make Darth lose the immunity to attrition) ? 'Steal' the pistol. It is a character weapon. Do you see Djas Puhr against a Light Side character with a Blaster Rifle and your opponent starts the fight ? Use Weapon Levitation to 'steal' the rifle. You see, the great part is, that neither specific weapons, nor specific characters are mentioned. Any character of ability >3 can steal any character weapon (so you might even get a weapon back thet the Light Side once stole from you !).

In short, a good card to include in any deck, especially if you have a lot of weapons, a lot of ability 4+ characters, ... or both.

Strong points:
* Weapon Levitation = Destiny 4 - good to upgrade average destiny, good to draw destiny.
* Weapon Levitation = Two cards for the price of one (Used and Lost variant).
* Weapon Levitation = Uncommon, thus it should not be too hard to get.
* Weapon Levitation = Surprise, as in, surprise your opponent by using his weapons against him, or at least get your weapons fast.


Weak points:
* Weapon Levitation = Not immune, so a Sense could ruin this little plan.
* Weapon Levitation = Unique. You can't search a weapon, not find it and then use a second Weapon Levitation to 'steal' in one turn.
Pulls: One weapon from Used Pile.
Combo:
Weapon Levitation Control = Who said anything about 'Sense' ?
-----
Weapon Levitation + opponent's Polarized Negative Power Coupling = You SEE your Used Pile, you know what cards go there.
-----
Weapon Levitation + many weapon cards in your deck = many weapons on the table fast, destiny 4 card recycled each time.
-----
Weapon Levitation + many characters of ability >3 = You do not need your own weapons if you have enough Weapon Levitations.
Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-16)
You may not initiate a Weapon Levitation (Lost function) if the stealing character is incapable of "carrying" a weapon. For example, a B'omarr Monk, or a Disarmed character.
Gametext: USED: Search your Used Pile, take one weapon into hand and reshuffle. LOST: If a battle was just initiated, one of your characters of ability > 3 present may 'steal' one character weapon present.

Lore: A Jedi is taught to use the anger of his opponents (and their weapons) against them.
Information:
This is a multi-useful, unique Light Used or Lost Interrupt with a destiny of 4. Its Used function searches through your Used Pile to take one weapon into hand and reshuffle. This can come in handy when looking for that elusive matching weapon that could make a difference in a key battle. One of its Lost functions flat-out cancels the nasty interrupt You Are Beaten, a card that should be canceled when at all possible. Apart from Sense, this is the best way to cancel that Dark interrupt. The final Lost use of Weapon Levitation plays if a battle was just initiated, allowing one of your characters present with ability greater than three to steal one character weapon present. Stealing a troublesome weapon may come in handy from time to time, but all three functions and its attractive destiny number make it a good utility card to include in certain decks.

The Dark Side has enjoyed this fantastic interrupt since Cloud City, and, finally, the Light Side gets its turn. Weapon Levitation can be a great way to swipe an important weapon such as Vader's Lightsaber, without putting yourself in too much of a random situation (like Sabacc.) While Luke cannot use Vader's Lightsaber, he can prevent it from being deployed again. He can also steal other important weapons like Thermal Detonators, Boba Fett's Blaster Rifle, and Dengar's Modified Riot Gun.
Pulls: One weapon from Used Pile.
IsPulled: Yoda's Hope
Combo: Weapon Levitation + Sabacc -- Using these two strategies together, you can completely deprive your opponent of weapons, but there are more subtle parts to this strategy. Sabacc is a great way to manipulate your own Used Pile, so that if you draw Anakin's Lightsaber with Sabacc, you can use Weapon Levitation to get it back out of your Used Pile.

Lore: When Vader dueled Luke at Cloud City, he fought a son trained by his former master and a weapon constructed by his former self.
Information: A unique Used or Lost Interrupt with a 5 destiny, using one of these in a deck helps to make weapons and devices less card-intensive to make use of. First, the Used function plays when a lightsaber was just used to enhance a Force drain, and puts that lightsaber into the owner's Used Pile. This is very obnoxious to do after Mara or Son Of Skywalker has used their "once per game" ability. Putting an opponent's lightsaber into the Used Pile is beneficial since it takes away the Force drain bonus for the following turn, and it removes the battle / duel advantage that a saber provides. Also, late in the game, you can put one of your lightsabers into your Used Pile to help boost your differential. As a Lost Interrupt, this works even better for this purpose, as you may place any or all of your devices and character weapons on table into your Used Pile. These counterparts are a must in any deck utilizing a quantity of devices and character weapons, and allows them to be used without the disadvantage of being too card-intensive. For a funny Light Side combo, put a bunch on high destiny devices into the Used Pile while Descent Into The Dark is out, then battle or Surprise Assault.
Gametext: USED: If a lightsaber was just used to enhance a Force drain, place it in owner's Used Pile. LOST: Place any or all of your devices and character weapons on table in your Used Pile.

Lore: The metal rods extending from the bottom of Cloud City are part of the city's flotation system. Sensors detect the velocity of wind and the content of local clouds.
Information:
Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.
-----
This is a card that adds a lot of strategy and fun to the Cloud City set. While you're battling on Cloud City, there is always the danger of your characters being thrown into a ventilation shaft and winding up dangling from a small metal rod below the city.

Since there's only room for one on that rod, it's really in your best interest to control the Bespin: Cloud City sector, and get your characters out of there as fast as possible. Otherwise, the next person to get thrown (or to voluntarily jump) off of a catwalk is going to knock your character into the clouds below.

Information:
There are two major types of anti-dueling cards - "escape the duel" cards and "help win the duel" cards. This Immediate Effect walks a fine line between them both!

Initially, it provides you with a duel canceler. Unlike A Jedi's Resilience, though, you must make your cancel decision as the duel is initiated. This one does not give you the option to await the outcome!

But it does come with an added benefit. Now that you know your Jedi is being targeted, and your assailant has been drawn out (most likely? the duel-happy Darth Maul), use this knowledge to your advantage to put all your Jedi on high alert! All your duel destiny draws are now +1, regardless which character is under attack. And it will last as long as you can keep the Jedi with What Was It? on him alive!

Lore: Lacking foresight, Luke suffered the consequences of rushing into battle unprepared.
Information:
The Dark Side often has a problem with farmboy Luke and friends playing interrupts to enhance destiny draws. From Gift of the Mentor to Skywalkers, the Light Side has plenty of interrupts to throw at you. There are times when you just plain don't have enough Senses and Alters to take care of the job. So, what do you do?

There are a number of what we like to call "tension" cards that the Dark Side may use to its advantage. These cards show relationships between Light Side characters at vulnerable moments. Scruffy Looking Nerf Herder is the first and best-known of these tension cards. In Scruffy Looking Nerf Herder, Leia and Han's usual strong bond hits a weak spot and allows the Dark Side to draw two destiny and to subtract that amount from the Light Side opponent's attrition and total power.

Since every Light Side deck uses Luke in one form or another, including a card to counter an opponent using one of the personas of Luke is a good idea. Why Didn't You Tell Me? cancels Gift Of The Mentor and the popular Force regeneration card, Noble Sacrifice. It's a rare game when Yoda doesn't bite the big one because of Noble Sacrifice (gaining the Light Side 9 Force!), so canceling it is good idea.

In a battle against Luke, Why Didn't You Tell Me can hamper your opponent significantly. Some of the Light Side strategies deal with simply deploying a main character, and trying to chip away at the an opposing vehicle, character, or starship, and hope that the other cards' Forfeit guides them through the Force loss. With a good destiny draw, this hope can be at least stemmed, as those cards battle destiny dwindles from a five or six to a mere one or two. Not a problem, simply add another counter to your Septoid Droid.
Combo: Why Didn't You Tell Me? + cheap characters of 2 Power, such as DS-61-2 = One of the more annoying things that happens in a game is when your opponent notices you've played a 2 Power pilot and sacrifices Yoda. Why Didn't You Tell Me? gets rid of that fairly easily.

Gametext: USED: Cancel Noble Sacrifice, Gift Of The Mentor or Old Ben. LOST: If Luke is defending a battle, draw one destiny. Subtract that amount from opponent's attrition and total power (cannot fall below zero).

This makes the Sandcrawler a power 11. Plus you have a huge gun, and the Sandcrawler just became immune to attrition < 5.

Lore: Wookiees have been known to dislocate more than just arms.
Information:
This interrupt from Cloud City has the potential to give you an advantage in certain situations... That is, if you have a Wookiee around to grab your opponent's non-droid characters by the throat.

For instance, say your opponent has Davin Felth and two Stormtroopers at the Death Star Docking Bay, where you have Chewbacca and Lando Calrissian present. Your opponent's total power is four and ability is four (therefore a battle destiny), while your total power is eight and ability is five (also a battle destiny). Because your opponent draws a battle destiny, chances are that you will have to forfeit either of your characters. However, if Chewbacca Wookiee Strangles a Stormtrooper first, your opponent will not be able to draw battle destiny anymore and since you still do, you will probably be able to cause a lot of battle damage.

Wookiee Strangle is also just good for eliminating annoying characters such as the not-so-good doctor himself, Dr.Evazan, and even your opponent's Undercover Spies! Bye-Bye Garindan and Labria, you should never upset a Wookiee. :)

Lore: "Steady. Hey! Steady, girl. Hey, what's the matter? You smell something?"
Information:
First, deploy a Wampa, for free, to the Wampa cave. Then put a few Banthas outside (to answer the question I hear every time I do this, no Banthas do NOT deploy only to Tatooine!). During your move phase, the Wampa goes outside to find a few tasty morsels hanging around. Target the first one and draw destiny. As long as you draw a 1, the Bantha is eaten, (Wampa is ferocity 3 + destiny). After that you don't need to worry about missing a draw! Eat a few more, then set the Wampa loose against your opponent!

Hoth offers the Dark Side some great Force drain and fighting locations. Once you have a 9 + destiny ferocity Wampa running loose, you'll find those AT-A's to be wonderful havens and your opponent will be wishing he had a snowspeeder or two to hide in! The Wampa attacks anything present at the same site, so the Light Side undercover spies won't stand a chance, and you can keep draining without hindrance! And if your opponent decides to stand and fight, you can thin his forces before a shot is fired (Remember, creature attacks occur at the beginning of EVERY battle phase). Even if an opponent's character survives a Wampa attack, that character can't participate in any battles that turn.

Lore: Senator who opposes the taxation of trade routes. Some say that a recent move from his homeworld to a luxurious Coruscant abode is evidence of his corruption.
Information:
With his trade agenda, he works well with This Is Outrageous! by allowing you to exchange cards you don't need from your hand for (hopefully) better cards in your Lost Pile.
And with his wealth agenda, he allows you to fully utilize Motion Supported to enhance your battle destinies. But the rest of his game text is what sets him apart from the rest of the senators. Looking at your opponent's destinies would be a very useful ability by itself. It lets you decide whether it would be a good idea to battle since you check whether your opponent's weapon destinies will be dangerous to you, or if you can handle that draw against you for battle destiny.
But Yeb Yeb goes further by tilting the tides of chance in your favor. If the destiny is low, you can leave it on your opponent's Reserve Deck, but if it's a high destiny you can make it lost and try your luck with the next card.

Lore: Kadas'sa'Nikto. Smuggler who stole from shipments going in and out of Jabba's Palace. Part of Jabba's sail barge crew. Not trusted by anyone.
Information:
First point of note is that he is a smuggler. This means an option for your Watch Your Step deck. What's more, he's a pilot, capable of Kessel Running if Dash is on holidays. There are a few other related benefits for smugglers such as cheap deploy to Kashyyyk, or meeting a requirement in your Profit deck so you can play Jabba's Palace sabacc! Beware a Death Mark, though.

His text provides him with a great all-round ability against opponent's vehicular threats. Power -2 against combat vehicles at same site (note that Yotts does not have to be present, so feel free to hide him inside a vehicle of your own!), and a once-per-game grab of Free Ride (steal a vehicle) and/or Mechanical Failure (Lateral Damage a vehicle!). If you are playing either of these cards, Yotts may beg for consideration!

Free Ride & Endor Celebration

Lore: "It is useless to resist. Don't let yourself be destroyed as Obi-Wan did."
Information:
You Are Beaten is one of those multi-use cards that is probably mostly used for only one of it's abilities while the other one is completely forgotten. It is the only card which cancels Uncontrollable Fury (one of the best cards from Cloud City, in my opinion, I won two games in a tournament because of it), but it's other ability can also be a game breaker.

For example...your opponent is draining at the Cantina for two...oh let's say three, you deployed a Presence Of The Force early and lost control of the location...no, make that four, he has Obi deployed there with HIS saber...no, okay five, Luke is there with Anakin's Saber...oh by the way, he played a Lightsaber Proficiency on his last turn...look, Billy, that's a drain for six every control phase!!! You have a Vader and Vader's Saber in your hand, but aren't sure if you can beat Obi, Luke, Han, and Kal'Fnal Cndros (yep he's there too) with Vader, Ozzel, and Veers (by the way, they're in your hand too). Oh my goodness, you have a YOU ARE BEATEN in your hand!!!

Things are looking MUCH better, you have a lot of Force to use, so you deploy Vader, his Saber, Ozzel, and Veers, then activate that one more that commits you to do battle with your nemeses. Oh wait...what are those other Force there for? YOU ARE BEATEN!!!!! Target OBI, oh, my dear, what's that? Obi CAN'T PARTICIPATE IN THE BATTLE OR MOVE until the end of your NEXT turn. It helps a little, don't ya see? Oh and the other use, if you're playing with I AM YOUR FATHER in your deck, is to go through and grab it after you beat down Luke's happy butt and cause your opponent to lose two MORE Force every turn and Luke won't stand much of a chance against Vader anymore.

Lore: Echo Base was no match for the Imperial war machine.
Information:
Startable with Prepared Defenses.
-----
This card heralds the return of the almighty Walker Garrison deck. Being able to start this effect with Prepared Defenses is a great boost to this classic deck type. On your first turn, you can immediately go and grab the 3rd Marker, which combined with the 5th Marker gives you 4 red icons and a +1 Force Drain location, while the Light Side only gets one blue icon from you in the bargain. Plus, you are guaranteed to have a Walker Garrison in hand right from the get-go, so you are all set to drain like mad once you've got all your Walkers in position.

The best part of this card, however, is its ability to deal direct damage just by occupying Hoth marker sites with AT-ATs, which any self-respecting Walker Garrison deck has in abundance. If you choose No Escape as one of your starting effects, this direct damage will not be cancelled by Honor of the Jedi, which is a good thing since your force drains at non-battlegrounds will be negated by that powerful Light Side card. Be sure to pack a couple Presence of the Force to help turn those Marker Sites into battlegrounds and add to your drains in the bargain.

For a third starting effect for this deck type, you probably want to start with Imperial Arrest Order. This will give a big boost to all your Walker pilots, and allow you to deploy the Hoth: Echo Docking Bay right away, a great place to plop a Walker to help drain with Walker Garrison. Unfortunately, the Docking Bay isn't a Marker Site, but it's still a great battleground to drain at with your Walkers. An alternative starting effect is Imperial Decree, which is pretty easy to keep active with this deck and which can really hurt those cowardly Rebels.

Lore: Even though he wasn't fully prepared to face the Dark Lord of the Sith, Luke rushed to save his friends.
Information:
At first glance, you might say, "Hey, why would I play this card?" After all, although it gives the Light Side a chance to duel, it automatically starts you at a disadvantage, giving the Dark Side two destiny to your one. And although having Luke placed out of play might seem appealing versus a Bring Him Before Me deck, you can't play this card when that Objective is out (due to the Objective's card text).

So what's the point? Well, if you're willing to devote a few extra cards to your Mains deck, this card can certainly be an unwelcome surprise for the Dark Side. Most decks carry a Vader or three, so devoting a bit of your strategy to this card can usually be effective. And it is a 6 Destiny card, so it will always have that bit of usefulness. Now, play two or three of these cards in your deck, and you've got some of the high destiny you need to succeed with this card.

Also, pack Courage of Skywalker to give you another destiny to even things out a bit with the old Dark Lord. And let's not forget Glancing Blow, which allows you to cancel one of the Dark Side's duelling destiny draws or, if you play You'll Find I'm Full of Surprises during the weapons segment of a battle, you can use Glancing Blow to nail Vader's power, knocking it to an unmodifiable zero, which means he won't even get the +2 power from holding his lightsaber granted by the Interrupt. Suddenly, Vader's chances of winning have become quite slim, and it looks like he's going away for a very long time.

Having this sort of a side strategy not only lets you beat up Luke's favorite sparring partner, but also gives you a plethora of cards to defend yourself during duels initiated by the Dark Side with such cards as Epic Duel or new cards like Darth Maul.

Some new Tatooine cards that can help you win the day versus Vader include A Jedi's Focus: which lets you add the destiny of the top card of the Lost Pile to your total, A Jedi's Patience: which lets you redraw one of your bad duelling destiny draws, and most importantly, A Jedi's Resilience, which allows you to cancel a duel AFTER you've lost it AND take the duelling card back into your hand!

But watch out for the new Dark Side card, Lightsaber Parry, or your duel might suddenly become very expensive!
CardName: You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises
Gametext: If Luke and Vader present at same site, use 1 Force to initiate a duel between them. Either is power +2 if armed with a lightsaber. Draw destiny. Opponent draws two destiny. Both players add power. Loser is placed out of play.

Lore: Male Ugnaught. Left Cloud City after the Empire took control. Works for Hermi Odle, helping to supply him with various weaponry. Hopes to someday return to Cloud City.
Information: Overload is a potent card for the Dark side to remove an annoying Lightsaber from time to time. Yoxgit, while not affecting the unfortunate zero drawn for the Overload, can help you get those Lightsabers back into hand, as well as an Electrobinoculars, or any other useful weapon or device. As a character, he is relatively weak for a 2 deploy cost, except on Cloud City. If you have a Light side Cloud City Scenario deck, this character is possibly your best bet for a quick, cheap, powerhouse.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, F-1)
Out Of Play Interrupts are identified by their interrupt icon in the upper-left corner of their card, and "Out Of Play Interrupt" in their subtype box. Out Of Play interrupts (or interrupts with an Out Of Play function) are played under normal interrupt rules. Once resolved, they are placed out of play. Once played as an Out Of Play Interrupt, no card of the same title may be played again as an Out Of Play Interrupt (though if it can be played as a Used or Lost Interrupt, it may still be played using its Used or Lost function).

Rules: If you play this as a Starting Interrupt, you must draw at least 8 cards. You do not need to declare how many cards you will draw, you may continue to draw until you wish to stop (or have drawn 12 cards). The Used Interrupt function may not be used to deploy an Effect that lists any deploy cost in its game text (such as Beggar) or is conditionally immune to Alter (such as Well Guarded).

Rules:
Draw X Choose Y
When a card instructs you to draw x destiny and choose y, perform the following steps:
Step 1) Draw a destiny. This draw can be modified, canceled, reset, or otherwise responded to normally just after it is drawn; however, after being drawn, unless canceled, it remains an Unresolved Destiny Draw and is not yet placed in Used Pile. The draw is considered a weapon destiny, battle destiny, etc. where appropriate, and counts against any applicable limits. If a limit prevents a player from drawing more than x destinies, they instead draw a number of destinies equal to the limit. Repeat this step until x destinies have been drawn.
Step 2) Once x destines have been drawn, choose a destiny from among the Unresolved Destiny Draws and resolve it normally. Repeat this step until an appropriate number of destinies have been chosen as specified by y.
Step 3) Place any remaining unresolved draws in used pile (unless otherwise instructed) in the order they were drawn (if possible).


Note that this means any just action responding to a just drawn destiny in a Draw X Choose Y situation must do so when it is DRAWN (in step 1) and not when it is CHOSEN (in step 2). Once the process has moved on to Step 2, with the player who drew choosing which destinies to use, the draws can no longer be responded to as just drawn.

Also worth noting is that all destinies drawn with a Draw X Choose Y card count against applicable limits or other cards that count the number of destinies, even if they are not chosen. That is to say, limits count the number of destinies drawn, not the number of destinies chosen. To illustrate, here are a few examples:

Example 1: Dash in Rogue 10 (applicable text: During battle, if with another T-47 and about to draw a battle destiny, may draw two and choose one.) is in a battle with another T-47, and the Light Side player is limited to ONE battle destiny. In this situation Dash in Rogue 10's 'draw 2 and choose 1' text cannot be used because both destinies drawn with Dash count as battle destiny draws.

Example 2: If a similar situation played out, but the Light Side player was limited 2 battle destinies instead of 1, the Light Side player using Dash in Rogue 10's text on 1 destiny would reach the limit of two battle destinies on its own, because even though only one such destiny would be chosen, two destinies were still drawn. If the light side player had a way to add a battle destiny in this example, they would be better off NOT using Dash in Rogue 10's text and simply drawing 2 normal destinies, because using Dash in Rogue 10's text on the first destiny would cause them to reach the limit of 2, preventing them from drawing the added battle destiny after.

Example 3: Dash in Rogue 10 is in a battle with Commander Luke Skywalker v piloting Rogue 1 (so that Luke draws 2 battle destiny if unable to otherwise). Luke's text will be usable because when it checks how many destinies Light Side is scheduled to draw at the beginning of the power segment, it will only see 1. (Luke's text only counts one destiny able to be drawn because Dash in Rogue 10's text has not triggered yet - it is only usable when the Light Side is about to draw a battle destiny) While the Light Side may theoretically use Dash in Rogue 10's text to draw 2 and choose 1 on the first destiny drawn, they would no longer be able to draw the 2nd destiny with Luke's text, because players may never combine multiple destiny drawing to draw more than the 'if unable to otherwise' text allows (see "Battle Destiny - Draws X Battle Destiny If Unable To Otherwise" on AR page 6-6). In this case, drawing 2 and choosing 1 on the first destiny and attempting to draw the second would mean the Light Side would be drawing 3 battle destinies, which would be prevented by 'if unable to otherwise' rules. If the first destiny with Luke's text is drawn normally, the Light Side player may not use Dash in Rogue 10's text on the second destiny from Luke's text, because again, that would result in the Light Side player drawing 3 destinies and would be prevented. In short, like example 2, the Light Side player would be better off simply drawing 2 normal battle destinies rather than using Dash in Rogue 10's text in this situation.
Gametext: May add 1 pilot. Permanent pilot is •Dash, who provides ability of 3. During battle, if with another T-47 and about to draw a battle destiny, may draw two and choose one. Immune to attrition < 4.

Rules:
(AR 1.7.1, B-4)
Once an unpiloted starfighter (or pilot) is revealed, if no matching pilot (or unpiloted starfighter) is found, the opponent is permitted to verify. If a match has been found but the player does not have enough Force to deploy the cards (or there is no location where they can be legally deployed), then the card revealed from hand is returned to hand, and the card taken from the Reserve Deck is placed back in the Reserve Deck; reshuffle.

Personas - Palpatine, Sidious, And The Emperor
While in the saga of Star Wars we learn that the Emperor, Senator Palpatine, and Darth Sidious are one in the same, for game purposes they are treated as three distinct people. They will be referred to as Emperor, Palpatine, and Sidious, respectively.
